· Track record of extending payments beyond 15 years. This is driven by continuous improvement of collection strategies and data analysis. As an example, we have collected 5.3x the purchase price for our 2000 vintage and still expect to collect e6.3 million, which is 0.6x the purchase price, over the next 15 years, resulting in a total expected multiple of 5.8x. For pre-2006 vintages, we estimated at the time of portfolio acquisition that we would be able to collect 2.6x times the aggregate purchase price. As of June 30, 2014, we have collected 2.5x times the aggregate purchase price of the pre-2006 vintages, and as of that date expected to collect 3.2x times the aggregate purchase price over the life of the portfolios purchased prior to 2006.

· Efficient conversion of profit into cash flow. From 2011 to 2013, 91-95% of Adjusted EBITDA was converted into operating cash flow (before income tax expense and net financial items), resulting in aggregate operating cash flow (before income tax expense and net financial items) over this period of e650 million. Total debt purchases over this period totaled e506 million.

Experienced executive management team with strong support from operational and market specialists
· Strong leadership of experienced senior management. We are managed by a strong executive team comprising individuals with many years of relevant experience and providing leadership across all functional areas of the business. Endre Rangnes, our CEO, held various managerial roles at IBM in Europe and was the Country Manager of Norway from 2000 to 2003. Between 2003 and 2010 Endre was the CEO of EDB Business Partner, a publicly listed information technology company. Our CFO, Scott Danielsen, is a Certified Public Accountant (inactive) and was formerly CFO of publicly listed European debt purchaser, Aktiv Kapital, after spending 21 years at Ernst & Young and PricewaterhouseCoopers.
· Supported by a strong team in our group central functions and local markets. Our senior management team is supported by a skilled team of managers operating our central functions and assisting in the execution of our strategy at group level. In addition, our expert regional and country managers are responsible for the local execution of our strategy in the various countries where we operate. Our regional and country managers have significant experience and knowledge of the specificities of our local markets.

Our Strategy
We believe that we have a well-developed strategy for pursuing growth within our existing regions and through geographical expansion. Our strategy includes:

Building on our strong relationships with originators
Over the coming years, we expect significant opportunities in the CMS market. We will strive to maintain our leading market position by establishing new bank partnerships, acquiring new portfolios and by entering into service agreements with new clients.
We believe that we are in a strong position to successfully enter into new partnerships, conclude future acquisitions of portfolios and collection platforms and maintain and expand our existing client

5

relationships, in particular with financial institutions, due to our strong reputation for ethical, fair and efficient debt collection as well as our track record of successful acquisitions. In addition to our strategy of capturing market growth opportunities, we plan to continue to emphasize our high level of underwriting discipline in order to maintain forecast accuracy and to ensure that we only acquire portfolios that generate attractive returns.
Continuing to drive operational scale and excellence across countries to capture full value potential
To maintain our market position and extract further value from our large and scalable platform, we are continuously looking for improvements across the organization to strengthen our client offering and operate more efficiently. We have developed and introduced a ``Global Operating Model'' to set one common operational blueprint and consolidate our general IT infrastructure platform across countries. We will focus on further optimizing our cost structure by continuing to streamline our operating platform, centralizing internal procedures and functions and by improving our IT efficiency through the consolidation of our collection systems. These efficiency improvements strengthen our client offering by extracting further value from portfolios and optimizing cash flows over time. We believe there are still meaningful variations in performance across geographies and we intend to increase portfolio yields and profit margins in the future through the full realization of multinational synergies.
Maintaining a disciplined portfolio acquisition process
Our strict pricing discipline and institutionalized investment process has allowed us to collect 106% of our original investment case cash flow forecasts from January 1, 2011 to June 30, 2014. We plan to continue to emphasize our high level of underwriting discipline in order to maintain forecast accuracy and to ensure that we only acquire portfolios that generate attractive returns. We will continue to build and leverage our extensive databases and sophisticated data analysis tools in the processes of pricing portfolios ahead of acquisitions, and to establish more efficient debt collection strategies.
Selectively considering expansion into selected new geographies
We have a strong track record of selective expansion into new markets and we have established operations in 11 countries. This expansion has been driven by a combination of strategic acquisitions and our ability to leverage strong client relationships. We believe that our strong relationships with international clients will lead to attractive opportunities to enter new markets by following our clients to other markets in which they operate as we have done in the past. We also foresee the potential for attractive portfolio acquisitions and carve-out opportunities for debt collection platforms and may enter selected European countries in the coming years. Our potential for expansion is evidenced by our recent entrance into the Italian market through a purchase of a portfolio in Italy which was part of the approximately e50 million of debt that we purchased in July and August. In addition to our strategy of capturing market growth opportunities, we plan to continue to emphasize our high level of underwriting discipline in order to maintain forecast accuracy and to ensure that we only acquire portfolios that generate attractive returns.
Certain statements in the section titled ``--Our Strategy'' constitute forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future financial performance and our actual results could differ materially from those expressed or implied by these forward looking statements as a result of many factors, including but not limited to those described under ``Forward-Looking Statements'' and ``Risk Factors.'' Investors are urged not to place undue reliance on any of the statements set forth above.
Recent Developments
On July 28, 2014, we agreed to acquire a collection unit from Banco Sabadell in Spain for a purchase price of e162,000,000 (the ``Spanish Acquisition''). As part of the proposed transaction, the acquired unit will enter into a service agreement with an expected initial term of 10 years with the seller to perform debt collection services on the seller's entire portfolio of existing overdue debt and receivables, the seller's entire portfolio of overdue debt and receivables generated in the next two years (subject to the seller's right to retain up to 5% of overdue debt and receivables collection for itself) and 80% of the seller's portfolio of overdue debt and receivables generated thereafter (subject to potential adjustments based on certain performance benchmarks set out in the service agreement). Based on publicly available
6

information made available by Banco Sabadell, the total amount of Banco Sabadell's non-performing loans was e24.9 billion as of December 31, 2013, e24.6 billion as of March 31, 2014 and e 24.1 billion as of June 30, 2014. Closing of the acquisition is expected to occur in the fourth quarter of 2014 and will be subject to regulatory clearance (if applicable) and certain other customary closing conditions. The potential transaction is fully in line with our European strategy executed to date.
For the twelve months ended April 30, 2014, we estimate that the pro forma adjusted EBITDA of the acquired unit, adjusted to include the entry into the service agreement as if had occurred on May 1, 2013, would have been approximately e38 million (the ``Spanish Acquisition EBITDA Estimate''). We derived the estimated pro forma adjusted EBITDA by (A) multiplying (i) the debt under management for the period by (ii) an estimated solution rate; (B) applying the fee structure set out in the 10-year service agreement referred to above; and (C) adjusting the historical cost structure provided by the seller for certain synergies we expect to achieve. We believe that the transaction will be accretive to our profile and our operating cash generation. The Spanish Acquisition EBITDA Estimate has been derived from information made available to us by the seller during the acquisition process and our own and our external consultants' analysis of such information and is based on certain assumptions that we believe to be reasonable based on our expertise and experience in the industry. The Spanish Acquisition EBITDA Estimate has been prepared by and is the responsibility of management and has not been audited, reviewed or verified by any accounting firm. Such estimate may not be indicative of the actual results we would have achieved if the Spanish Acquisition had occurred on May 1, 2013 or of any future results. Actual results of the Spanish Acquisition could vary from these estimates and these differences could be material. The EBITDA generated by the acquired collection unit over the life of the service agreement will depend on a number of factors, including the evolution of the stock of overdue debt and receivables we are entitled to collect on and in turn on the level of Banco Sabadell's loan origination and non-performing loans in the future. As a consequence, the EBITDA generated by the acquired collection unit may decrease over the life of the service agreement. In addition, the Initial Purchasers have not independently reviewed the accuracy or completeness of the Spanish Acquisition EBITDA Estimate and no representation or warranty, express or implied, is made by any Initial Purchaser as to the accuracy or completeness of the Spanish Acquisition EBITDA Estimate and nothing contained in this or the preceding paragraph shall be relied upon as a promise or representation by any Initial Purchaser as to the past or the future performance of the Spanish Acquisition. For certain risks relating to the Spanish Acquisition and the Spanish Acquisition EBITDA Estimate, see ``Risk Factors--Risks Related to the Transactions.''
Trading Update
Based on preliminary results, our group revenue for the three-month period ended September 30, 2014 was e119 million, an increase of 11% from the e107 million for the three-month period ended September 30, 2013. For the nine-month period ended September 30, 2014, our group revenue increased to e345 million, or by 4%, from e333 million for the comparable period in 2013. The increase in group revenue was mainly driven by the acquisition of a collection contract in Spain in December 2013 and a high level of portfolio capital expenditure in the first half of 2014, with contracted portfolio purchases growing from e26 million in the three months ended September 30, 2013 to e56 million in the three months ended September 30, 2014 and growing from e110 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2013 to e200 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2014. We also have a pipeline of e18 million of committed forward flow volumes from existing clients for the remainder of 2014. Due to the increase in portfolio purchases, our ERC increased from e1,685 million at September 30, 2013 to e1,930 million at September 30, 2014.
Based on preliminary results, our Adjusted EBITDA for the three-month period ended September 30, 2014 was e70 million, an increase of 13% from the e62 million for the three-month period ended September 30, 2013. For the nine-month period ended September 30, 2014, our Adjusted EBITDA increased to e199 million, or by 4%, from e191 million for the comparable period in 2013. The increase in Adjusted EBITDA was mainly due to a favourable change in our business mix driven by growth in our Debt Purchasing segment, and continued improvements in our Collection segment.
The above information is based solely on preliminary results and estimates and is not intended to be a comprehensive statement of our financial or operational results for the three-month or nine-month periods ended September 30, 2014. Our preliminary results in relation to the three-month and nine-month periods ended September 30, 2014 are based on a number of assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties and subject to change. While we believe these estimates to be reasonable, the
7

above information may be subject to modification during the preparation of our consolidated financial statements and review thereof by our independent auditors. Accordingly, our actual results for the threemonth and nine-month periods ended September 30, 2014 may vary from our preliminary results and estimates above, and such variations could be material. As such, you should not place undue reliance on them. See ``Forward-Looking Statements'' and ``Risk Factors'' for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance and results of operations.
The above preliminary financial information has been prepared by, and is the responsibility of, our management. PricewaterhouseCoopers AB has not audited, reviewed, compiled or performed any procedures with respect to such preliminary financial information. Accordingly, PricewaterhouseCoopers AB does not express an opinion or any other form of assurance with respect thereto.
Changes to the Senior Management
Endre Rangnes has resigned his position as our CEO and Oddgeir Hansen has resigned his position as our COO. The existing management team will be augmented by Peter Sjunnesson as interim CEO and member of the Board of Directors. The recruitment of a permanent CEO is underway.
The Transactions
On July 18, 2014, Senior Secured Notes Issuer, as purchaser, and Altor Funds, Investor and certain minority shareholders, including members of management who hold an interest in one or more of the Target Companies, as sellers (the ``Sellers''), entered into the Acquisition Agreement regarding the direct or indirect, as applicable, acquisition of all the shares of the Target Group (the ``Acquisition''). Under the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will directly or indirectly, as applicable, acquire all of the issued and outstanding capital stock of the Target Companies as of the consummation of the Acquisition (the ``Completion Date''). The consummation of the Acquisition pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement will be subject to the clearance of (i) the EU Commission, (ii) the Russian Federation and (iii) the Norwegian Financial Supervisory Authority (together, the ``Acquisition Conditions''). If the Acquisition is not consummated by the one-hundred-fortieth (140th) business day after the signing of the Acquisition Agreement, the Acquisition Agreement may be terminated by either party. In connection with obtaining the approvals of the applicable regulatory and competition authorities, we may agree to divest certain of our assets or operations. We currently do not expect that we will be required to divest assets or operations that generate a significant portion of our revenue. See ``Risk Factors--Risks Related to the Transaction.''
Pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will acquire all of the issued and outstanding capital stock of the Target Companies for e1,352 million (the ``Purchase Price''), subject to certain purchase price adjustments. The interest on the Purchase Price shall be calculated on the basis of an agreed rate at eleven and a half (11.5) per cent per annum, and shall be calculated for the period between May 1, 2014 and the Completion Date (the ``Interest Payment Adjustment''). Further, the Purchase Price shall be adjusted upwards with respect to certain other components, such as the net cash amounts in some of the Target Companies and compensation due to certain intra-group loans. In addition, the Purchase Price will be reduced by the amount of any dividends or similar payment, asset transfers or certain other transfers of value from the Target Group to the Sellers that occur prior to the Completion Date that are not permitted under the Acquisition Agreement and certain payments to employees or directors or finding fee arrangements triggered as a result of the Acquisition.
The Acquisition Agreement includes customary restrictions on the activities of the Target Group prior to the Completion Date, including restrictions on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, as well as limited representations, warranties and covenants that are subject to limitations and exclusions. The Acquisition Agreement does not prohibit the Company from incurring additional debt under its existing revolving credit facility. Any such additional debt borrowed will be refinanced on the Completion Date as part of the Transactions. See ``The Transactions.''
8

Principal Shareholders Nordic Capital Funds The Nordic Capital Funds are a leader within private equity investments in Northern Europe. Since inception in 1989, the Nordic Capital Funds have successfully raised close to e12.5 billion and in total made more than 80 platform investments and 130 material add-on acquisitions. The Nordic Capital Funds invest in medium and large sized companies and support value creation in their investments through committed ownership and by targeting strategic development and operational improvements. The Nordic Capital Funds have a long track record of making successful investments supported by close to 60 investment professional advisory team members spread out over 6 offices. The team also has an extensive experience in the financial services space through its investments in Point International, Resurs Group and Euroline. The Lindorff investment will be made from Nordic Capital Fund VIII, which closed in December 2013 with total commitments of e3.5 billion. To date one investment has been closed in Nordic Capital Fund VIII, with five additional investments pending (including Lindorff). Altor Funds The Altor Funds are private equity funds focused on investing in and developing medium sized companies with a Nordic origin. The investment strategy is based on identifying and realising sustainable performance improvements in areas such as revenue growth, margin expansion and capital efficiency. The Altor Funds control a broad portfolio of businesses that operate in a wide range of sectors. The Altor Funds do not actively carry on any other business activities. Investor Founded by the Wallenberg family a hundred years ago, Investor is a leading owner of high quality Nordic-based international companies. Through board participation, its industrial experience, network and financial strength, Investor strives to make its companies best-in-class. Investor's objective is to build the net asset value, operate efficiently and pay out a steadily rising dividend. Over time, this should allow Investor to generate an attractive total shareholder return.
9

(3) Prior to the Completion Date, the Senior Notes will not be guaranteed. On the Completion Date, the Senior Notes will be senior obligations of the Senior Notes Issuer, guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, and secured by the Senior Notes Completion Date Collateral. Within 10 business days of the Completion Date, the Senior Notes will also be secured by the 10 Business Day Senior Notes Collateral. Within 90 days of the Completion Date, the Senior Notes will also be guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis by the Post-Completion Date Guarantors. In addition, the Senior Notes Issuer will agree to use its commercially reasonable efforts to cause the Additional Spanish Guarantors to guarantee the Senior Notes on a senior subordinated basis within six months of the Completion Date. See ``Description of the Senior Notes--Guarantees'' and ``--Security''. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement the Senior Notes will be subject to payment blockage, standstill and turnover provisions. See ``Description of Other Indebtedness--Intercreditor Agreement''.
(4) On or about the Completion Date, the Senior Notes Issuer will lend the proceeds of the Senior Notes to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer (the ``Senior Notes Proceeds Loan''). Together with the proceeds of the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Notes Proceeds Loan, the equity contribution from Nordic Capital Fund VIII, the Altor Funds, Investor and certain co-investors and the proceeds from the Shareholder Notes, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will pay the purchase price under the Acquisition Agreement, pay fees and expenses related to the Transactions and on-lend the remaining proceeds to the Target Group to repay, together with certain cash on hand, the Existing Credit Facility and the Existing Vendor Loan. To the extent additional sources are required on completion of the Acquisition, the Issuers may utilize the Revolving Credit Facility (in an amount up to e50 million) and/or proceeds from additional equity contributions.
(5) Prior to the Completion Date, the Senior Secured Notes will not be guaranteed. On the Completion Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be senior obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and secured by the Senior Secured Notes Completion Date Collateral. Within 10 business days of the Completion Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured by the 10 Business Day Senior Secured Notes Collateral. Within 90 days of the Completion Date, the Senior Secured Notes will also be guaranteed on a senior basis by the Post-Completion Date Guarantors and secured by the Post-Completion Date Collateral. In addition, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will agree to use its commercially reasonable efforts to cause the Additional Spanish Guarantors to guarantee the Senior Secured Notes on a senior basis and to grant the Additional Spanish Collateral within six months of the Completion Date. See ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Security''. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of the enforcement of the security, the holders of the Senior Secured Notes will receive proceeds from the Senior Secured Notes Collateral and certain distressed disposals only after super-senior obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations have been repaid. See ``Description of Other Indebtedness--Intercreditor Agreement.''
(6) On or about the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, as original borrower, will enter into the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement which provides for the e225 million Revolving Credit Facility. To the extent additional sources are required on closing, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may utilize the Revolving Credit Facility (in an amount up to e50 million) and/or proceeds from additional equity contributions. The Revolving Credit Facility will be guaranteed on a senior basis together with certain hedging obligations by the same entities that guarantee the Senior Secured Notes and will be secured on a firstpriority basis over the same collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes. See ``Description of Other Indebtedness-- Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.''
(7) Represents Lindorff Institutional Management AB and Lindorff Co-Invest AB. Lindorff Institutional Management AB and Lindorff Co-Invest AB are expected to merge following the Completion Date. Regardless of whether they merge, they will become guarantors of the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes within 90 days following the Completion Date.
(8) Indif AB and Lindorff AB are expected to merge following the Completion Date. Regardless of whether they merge, they will become guarantors of the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes within 90 days following the Completion Date.
(9) NOK 1.68 billion NOK Floating Rate Notes is equal to approximately e199.6 million equivalent (based on the exchange rate of e1.00 = 8.4150 NOK).
(10) The Company and the Guarantors (including the Additional Spanish Guarantors) represented more than 80% of consolidated EBITDA of the Company for the year ended December 31, 2013 and more than 90% of consolidated assets of the Company as of December 31, 2013. Excluding the Additional Spanish Guarantors, the Company and the Guarantors represented more than 75% of consolidated EBITDA of the Company for the year ended December 31, 2013 and more than 80% of consolidated assets of the Company as of December 31, 2013. All of the Guarantors will be, following the Transactions, wholly owned Subsidiaries of the Issuers.
(11) SEK 1.85 billion SEK Floating Rate Notes is equal to approximately e200.3 million equivalent (based on the exchange rate of e1.00 = 9.2350 SEK).

THE OFFERING
The following is a brief summary of certain terms of the offering of the Notes. It may not contain all the information that is important to you. For additional information regarding the Notes and the Guarantees, see ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes,'' ``Description of the Senior Notes'' and ``Description of Other Indebtedness.''

SEK Floating Rate Notes . . . . . . . August 15, 2022.

Interest Payment Dates:

Euro Floating Rate Notes . . . . . . . Quarterly in arrears on each February 15, May 15, August 15 and November 15, commencing on February 15, 2015.

NOK Floating Rate Notes . . . . . . . Quarterly in arrears on each February 15, May 15, August 15 and November 15, commencing on February 15, 2015.

12

Euro Fixed Rate Notes . . . . . . . . . Semi-annually in arrears on each February 15 and August 15, commencing on February 15, 2015.

Euro Senior Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . Semi-annually in arrears on each February 15 and August 15, commencing on February 15, 2015.

SEK Floating Rate Notes . . . . . . . Quarterly in arrears on each February 15, May 15, August 15 and November 15, commencing on February 15, 2015.

Denomination . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Each Euro Floating Rate Note and Euro Fixed Rate Note will have a minimum denomination of e100,000 and be in integral multiples of e1,000 in excess thereof. Euro Floating Rate Notes and Euro Fixed Rate Notes in denominations less than e100,000 will not be available.

Each NOK Floating Rate Note will have a minimum denomination of NOK 1,000,000 and be in integral multiples of NOK 10,000 in excess thereof. NOK Floating Rate Note in denominations less than NOK 1,000,000 will not be available.

Each Euro Senior Note will have a minimum denomination of e100,000 and be in integral multiples of e1,000 in excess thereof. Senior Notes in denominations less than e100,000 will not be available.

Each SEK Floating Rate Note will have a minimum denomination of SEK 1,000,000 and be in integral multiples of SEK 10,000 in excess thereof. SEK Floating Rate Note in denominations less than SEK 1,000,000 will not be available.

Ranking:

Senior Secured Notes . . . . . . . . . The Senior Secured Notes will:

· be senior obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and will rank equal in right of payment with all of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer's existing and future obligations that are not subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations;

· be senior in right of payment to any subordinated indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, including its guarantee of the Senior Notes;

· be effectively senior in right of payment to any existing or future unsecured obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, to the extent of the value of the Senior Secured Notes Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the Senior Secured Notes;

· be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Senior Secured Notes Guarantors, subject to the guarantee limitations described herein;

· be effectively subordinated to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer's existing and future secured indebtedness that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness; and

· be structurally subordinated to all obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer's subsidiaries that are not Senior Secured Notes Guarantors.

13

The Senior Secured Notes will be secured by the Senior Secured Notes Collateral as described under ``--Security''; but will receive proceeds from enforcement of security over the Senior Secured Notes Collateral only after any creditors that are entitled to receive such proceeds on a super-priority basis, including lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging counterparties, have been paid in full.

Senior Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The Senior Notes will:

· be senior obligations of the Senior Notes Issuer and will rank equal in right of payment with all of the Senior Notes Issuer's existing and future obligations that are not subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Notes;

· be senior in right of payment to any subordinated indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer;

· be effectively senior in right of payment to any existing or future unsecured obligations of the Senior Notes Issuer, to the extent of the value of the Shared Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the Senior Notes after all prior-ranking claims have been paid and discharged in full;

· be guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis by the Senior Notes Guarantors, subject to the guarantee limitations described herein;

· be effectively subordinated to the Senior Notes Issuer's existing and future secured indebtedness that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Senior Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness; and

· be structurally subordinated to all obligations of the Senior Notes Issuer's subsidiaries that are not Senior Notes Guarantors.

Guarantors:

Senior Secured Notes . . . . . . . . .

On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will not be guaranteed. Within 90 days of the Completion Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the Post-Completion Date Guarantors, which include Lindorff AB, Indif AB, Lindorff Institutional Management AB, Lindorff Co-Invest AB, Lindorff Second Holding AB, Lindorff Group AB, Lindorff Finanzholding GmbH, Lindorff Holding GmbH, Lindorff Deutschland GmbH, Lindorff Sverige Holding AB, Lindorff Capital AS, Lindorff Sverige AB, Lindorff Finland Oy, Lindorff Oy, Lindorff Invest Oy, Lindorff Netherlands Holding B.V., Lindorff Netherlands B.V., Lindorff B.V., Lindorff Holding Norway AS, Lindorff Norge AS, Lindorff AS and Lindorff Danmark A/S.

In addition, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer has agreed to use its commercially reasonable efforts to cause the Additional Spanish Guarantors to guarantee the Senior Secured Notes on a senior basis within six months of the Completion Date.

Senior Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

On the Issue Date, the Senior Notes will not be guaranteed. On the Completion Date, the Senior Notes will be guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. Within 90 days of the Completion Date, the Senior Notes will be

14

guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis by the Post-Completion Date Guarantors.

In addition, the Senior Notes Issuer has agreed to use its commercially reasonable efforts to cause the Additional Spanish Guarantors to guarantee the Senior Notes on a senior subordinated basis within six months of the Completion Date.

General . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

The Company and certain of the Guarantors (including the Additional Spanish Guarantors, but excluding Indif AB, Lindorff Institutional Management AB and Lindorff Co-Invest AB) represented approximately e136.3 million or approximately 97% of consolidated EBITDA of the Company for the year ended December 31, 2013 and approximately e3.5 billion or approximately 100% of total net assets of the Company as of December 31, 2013. Non-guarantors represented approximately e12.8 million or approximately 9% of consolidated EBITDA of the Company for the year ended December 31, 2013 and e(3.9) million or approximately 0% of total net assets. The Company and all of the Guarantors (including the Additional Spanish Guarantors Indif AB, Lindorff Institutional Management AB and Lindorff Co-Invest AB) represented approximately e136.3 million or approximately 97% of consolidated EBITDA of the Company for the year ended December 31, 2013 and approximately e3.9 billion or approximately 111%1 of total net assets of the Company as of December 31, 2013. Non-guarantors represented approximately e4.4 million or approximately 3% of consolidated EBITDA of the Company for the year ended December 31, 2013 and e765,000 or approximately 0% of total net assets. Excluding the Additional Spanish Guarantors, the Company and the Guarantors represented more than 75% of consolidated EBITDA of the Company for the year ended December 31, 2013 and more than 80% of consolidated assets of the Company as of December 31, 2013. See ``Summary-- Corporate Structure and Certain Financing Arrangements.''

Ranking of the Guarantees

The Guarantees will be subject to release under certain circumstances. See ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Guarantees'' and ``Description of the Senior Notes-- Guarantees.'' The Guarantees will be subject to significant contractual and legal limitations, including under applicable law. See ``Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests.''

Ranking of the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees . . . . . . . . . . Each Senior Secured Notes Guarantee will:

· be the senior obligation of the relevant Senior Secured Notes Guarantor and will rank equal in right of payment with all of such Senior Secured Notes Guarantor's existing and future obligations that are not subordinated in right of payment to the relevant Senior Secured Notes Guarantee, including obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations;

1 As the consolidated financials exclude Indif AB, Lindorff Institutional Management AB and Lindorff Co-Invest AB, but such entities are guarantors, the percentage is greater than 100%.
15

· be senior in right of payment to any subordinated indebtedness of the relevant Senior Secured Notes Guarantor, including that Guarantor's Senior Notes Guarantee;
· be effectively senior in right of payment to any existing or future unsecured obligations of the relevant Senior Secured Notes Guarantor, to the extent of the value of the Senior Secured Notes Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the applicable Senior Secured Notes Guarantee;
· be effectively senior in right of payment to any existing or future obligations of the relevant Senior Secured Notes Guarantor secured on the Senior Secured Notes Collateral on a basis junior to the Senior Secured Notes, to the extent of the value of the Senior Secured Notes Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the applicable Senior Secured Notes Guarantee;
· be subject to limitations described herein, including those set forth in ``Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests''; and
· be effectively subordinated to such Senior Secured Notes Guarantor's existing and future secured indebtedness that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes Guarantee of such Senior Secured Notes Guarantor, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness.
Each Senior Secured Notes Guarantee will be secured by the Senior Secured Notes Collateral as described under ``--Security''; but will receive proceeds from enforcement of security over the Senior Secured Notes Collateral only after any creditors that are entitled to receive such proceeds on a super-priority basis, including lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging counterparties, have been paid in full.
Ranking of the Senior Notes Guarantees . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Each Senior Notes Guarantee will:
· be a general senior subordinated obligation of that Senior Notes Guarantor;
· be subordinated in right of payment to any existing and future senior indebtedness of the relevant Senior Notes Guarantor, including that Senior Notes Guarantor's guarantee of the Senior Secured Notes, and the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations;
· rank pari passu in right of payment with any future senior subordinated indebtedness of that Senior Notes Guarantor;
· rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future indebtedness of that Senior Notes Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Senior Notes Guarantee;
· be effectively senior in right of payment to any existing or future unsecured obligations of the relevant Senior Notes Guarantor, to the extent of the value of the Senior Notes
16

Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the applicable Senior Secured Notes Guarantee;

· be effectively senior in right of payment to any existing or future obligations of the relevant Senior Notes Guarantor secured on the Senior Notes Collateral on a basis junior to the Senior Notes, to the extent of the value of the Senior Notes Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the applicable Senior Notes Guarantee;

· be subject to limitations described herein, including those set forth in ``Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests''; and

· be effectively subordinated to such Senior Notes Guarantor's existing and future secured indebtedness, including the Senior Secured Notes, certain hedging obligations and indebtedness under the Revolving Credit Facility, that is secured by the Senior Secured Notes Collateral and by other property or assets that do not secure the Senior Notes Guarantee of such Senior Notes Guarantor, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness.

Security . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Each holder of a Note, by accepting such Note, will be deemed to have agreed to and be bound by the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. Pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement, the liens securing the Senior Secured Notes will be senior liens over the Senior Secured Notes Collateral that rank equally with the liens that secure: (i) on a super-priority basis (A) obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and (B) obligations under certain super-priority hedging arrangements; and (ii) on an equal and ratable basis, (A) certain other future debt permitted to be incurred under the Senior Secured Indenture, including certain acquisition indebtedness and (B) obligations under certain hedging arrangements. The Senior Notes will be secured by the Shared Collateral on a second-ranking basis and by the Senior Notes Only Collateral on a first-ranking basis. Following a Senior Distress Event (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) or a Senior Payment Default (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement, and subject to a monetary threshold specified therein), no debtor may make any payment on the Revolving Credit Facility, the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Notes and certain other obligations, except to the Security Agent. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, amounts received or recovered in respect of enforcement of the Collateral (other than in respect of the Senior Notes Only Collateral) are required to be turned over to the Security Agent. Subject to the payment of fees and expenses of the agent under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Trustee, certain other creditor representatives and the Security Agent, amounts received by the Security Agent are paid by it first to the repayment in full of the obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility and certain super-priority hedging arrangements, second to the repayment in full of the Senior Secured Notes, certain other hedging arrangements and other indebtedness sharing in the first-ranking security interest including certain acquisition indebtedness and, to the extent that such amounts represent proceeds of enforcement of the Shared Collateral, third to the repayment of the Senior Notes. Subject to the

17

payment of fees and expenses of the Senior Notes Trustee and the Security Agent, amounts received by the Security Agent in respect of enforcement of the Senior Notes Only Collateral will be paid by it to the holders of Senior Notes.

In addition, the Intercreditor Agreement contains provisions regarding subordination, standstills on enforcement, payment blockages, release of Collateral and Guarantees, turnover of receipts, application of proceeds and other terms in respect of the Senior Notes.

The Security Agent may refrain from enforcing the Collateral (other than the Senior Notes Only Collateral) unless instructed by the requisite majority of creditors under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and certain hedging obligations or the Trustee for the Senior Secured Notes (as instructed by the requisite majority under the Senior Secured Notes) and the requisite majority of creditors under certain pari passu debt and certain hedging obligations, in each case, in accordance with the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement. The Security Agent may refrain enforcing the Senior Notes Only Collateral unless instructed by the Trustee for the Senior Notes (as instructed by the requisite majority under the Senior Notes), and the requisite majority of creditors under certain pari passu debt obligations, in accordance with the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement. In the event of conflicting instructions, the Intercreditor Agreement specifies which set of instructions will prevail. See ``Description of Other Indebtedness-- Intercreditor Agreement.''

Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption . . . . . . .

Pending consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will, concurrently with the issuance of the Notes on the Issue Date, deposit the gross proceeds of the offerings of the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes into segregated escrow accounts (the ``Escrow Accounts'') pursuant to the terms of the Senior Secured Escrow Agreement and the Senior Escrow Agreement, respectively (the ``Escrow Agreements''), each in the name of the relevant Issuer. If the conditions to the release of the escrowed proceeds have not been satisfied on or prior to February 10, 2015, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption at a redemption price of each series of Notes equal to 100% of the aggregate initial issue price of such series of Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date to such special mandatory redemption date and additional amounts, if any, from the Issue Date. See ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption'' and ``Description of the Senior Notes--Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.''

Optional Redemption:

Euro Floating Rate Notes . . . . . . .

At any time and from time to time on or after August 15, 2015, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem all or part of the Euro Floating Rate Notes at the redemption prices set forth under the heading ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes-- Optional Redemption--Optional Redemption of the Euro Floating Rate Notes.''

18

At any time prior to August 15, 2015, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem all or part of the Euro Floating Rate Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, plus a ``make-whole'' premium, as described under ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Optional Redemption--Optional Redemption of the Euro Floating Rate Notes.''

NOK Floating Rate Notes . . . . . . .

At any time and from time to time on or after August 15, 2017, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem all or part of the NOK Floating Rate Notes at the redemption prices set forth under the heading ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes-- Optional Redemption--Optional Redemption of the NOK Floating Rate Notes.''

At any time prior to August 15, 2017, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem all or part of the NOK Floating Rate Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, plus a ``make-whole'' premium, as described under ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Optional Redemption--Optional Redemption of the NOK Floating Rate Notes.''

At any time and from time to time prior to August 15, 2017, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem up to 40% of the original principal amount of the NOK Floating Rate Notes with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to 107.9500% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the redemption date provided that at least 60% of the original principal amount of the NOK Floating Rate Notes remain outstanding after the redemption.

Euro Fixed Rate Notes . . . . . . . . .

At any time and from time to time on or after August 15, 2017, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may also redeem all or part of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes at the redemption prices set forth under the caption ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes-- Optional Redemption--Optional Redemption of the Fixed Rate Notes.''

At any time prior to August 15, 2017, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem all or part of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes redeemed plus the applicable ``make-whole'' premium set forth under the heading ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Optional Redemption--Optional Redemption of the Fixed Rate Notes.''

At any time and from time to time prior to August 15, 2017, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem up to 40% of the original principal amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to 107.0000% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date provided that at least 60% of the original principal amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes remain outstanding after the redemption.

Prior to August 15, 2017, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem during each 12-month period commencing with the

19

Issue Date up to 10% of the aggregate principal outstanding amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes at its option, from time to time, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date.

Euro Senior Notes . . . . . . . . . . . .

At any time prior to August 15, 2018, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem all or part of the Senior Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Senior Notes redeemed plus the applicable ``make-whole'' premium set forth under the caption ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Optional Redemption.''

At any time prior to August 15, 2017, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem up to 40% of the original principal amount of the Senior Notes with the net cash proceeds from specified public equity offerings at a redemption price equal to 109.5000% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the redemption date provided that at least 60% of the original principal amount of the Senior Notes remain outstanding after the redemption.

At any time on or after August 15, 2018, the Senior Notes Issuer may also redeem all or part of the Senior Notes at the redemption prices set forth under the caption ``Description of the Senior Notes--Optional Redemption'' plus accrued and unpaid interest to the redemption date.

SEK Floating Rate Notes . . . . . . . . .

At any time and from time to time on or after August 15, 2018, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem all or part of the SEK Floating Rate Notes at the redemption prices set forth under the heading ``Description of the Senior Notes--Optional Redemption--Optional Redemption of the SEK Floating Rate Notes.''

At any time prior to August 15, 2018, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem all or part of the SEK Floating Rate Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, plus a ``make-whole'' premium, as described under ``Description of the Senior Notes--Optional Redemption--Optional Redemption of the SEK Floating Rate Notes.''

At any time and from time to time prior to August 15, 2017, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem up to 40% of the original principal amount of the SEK Floating Rate Notes with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to 110.4550% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the redemption date provided that at least 60% of the original principal amount of the SEK Floating Rate Notes remain outstanding after the redemption.

Use of Proceeds . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

The gross proceeds from the sale of the Notes will be deposited into the applicable Escrow Accounts for the benefit of the relevant holders of the Notes, pending satisfaction of the conditions to release such proceeds. Upon release of the escrow proceeds, the Escrow Agents will transfer to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Senior Notes Issuer, as applicable, the proceeds from the Senior Secured Notes and

20

the Senior Notes, respectively. See ``Description of Senior Secured Notes--Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption'' and ``Description of Senior Notes--Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redmeption''. Subject to the conditions to the release of the escrow proceeds as set forth in ``Description of Senior Secured Notes--Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption'' and ``Description of Senior Notes--Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption'', the Issuers are expected to use the proceeds of the Notes as set out under ``Use of Proceeds''.

Additional Amounts . . . . . . . . . . . .

Any payments made by the Issuers or any Guarantor with respect to the Notes or any Guarantees will be made without withholding or deduction for taxes in any taxing jurisdiction unless required by law. If we are required by law to withhold or deduct for taxes of a relevant tax jurisdiction with respect to a payment to the holders of the Notes or any Guarantee, we will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by the holders of the Notes or any Guarantees after the withholding is not less than the amount that they would have received in the absence of the withholding, subject to certain exceptions. See ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Withholding Taxes'' and ``Description of the Senior Notes--Withholding Taxes.''

Optional Redemption for Tax Reasons . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuers may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. See ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Redemption for Taxation Reasons'' and ``Description of the Senior Notes--Redemption for Taxation Reasons.''

Asset Sales . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

The Issuers will be required to offer to purchase the Notes with excess proceeds, if any, following certain asset sales at a purchase price equal to 100% of the principal amount, and accrued and unpaid interest to the date of purchase. See ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Certain Covenants--Limitation on Sales of Assets and Subsidiary Stock'' and ``Description of the Senior Notes--Certain Covenants--Limitation on Sales of Assets and Subsidiary Stock.''

Change of Control . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control event, or if the Issuers sell all or substantially all of the assets, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will be required to offer to repurchase the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes Issuer will be required to offer to repurchase the Senior Notes, in each case, at a purchase price equal to 101% of their aggregate principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of the purchase. See ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Change of Control'' and ``Description of the Senior Notes--Change of Control.''

Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . . The Indentures will limit, among other things, our ability to:

· incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock;

· pay dividends on, redeem or repurchase our capital stock;

21

· make certain restricted payments (including dividends and distribution with respect to shares of the Issuers) and investments;

· prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity and, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, to make payments of principal of the Senior Notes;

· create or incur certain liens;

· impose restrictions on the ability of subsidiaries to pay dividends or other payments to the Company;

· transfer, lease or sell assets;

· merge or consolidate with other entities;

· enter into certain transactions with affiliates;

· impair the security interests in the Collateral; and

· change the nature of the business of the Group.

Each of the covenants is subject to a number of important exceptions and qualifications. See ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Certain Covenants'' and ``Description of the Senior Notes--Certain Covenants.''

Transfer Restrictions . . . . . . . . . . .

The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction except that an application will be made to list the NOK Floating Rate Notes on the Oslo Børs. Neither of the Issuers has registered, and neither of the Issuers intends to register, as an investment company under the U.S. Investment Company Act, in reliance on the exemption provided in Section 3(c)(7) thereof. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See ``Transfer Restrictions.'' Holders of the Notes will not have the benefit of any exchange or registration rights.

No Prior Market . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

The Notes will be new securities for which there is no market. Although the Initial Purchasers have informed us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any time without notice. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that an active trading market for the Notes will develop or be maintained.

Listing and Trading . . . . . . . . . . . .

Application has been made to the Irish Stock Exchange plc for the approval of this document as Listing Particulars (``Listing Particulars''). Application has been made to the Irish Stock Exchange for the Euro Floating Rate Notes, the Euro Fixed Rate Notes and the Senior Notes (together, the ``Euro-denominated Notes'') and the SEK Floating Rate Notes to be admitted to the Official List and trading on the Global Exchange Market which is the exchange regulated market of the Irish Stock Exchange. There can be no assurance that any such application will be successful or that any such listing will be granted or maintained. The Global Exchange Market is not a regulated market for the purposes of Directive 2004/39/EC. In addition, application has been made to the Oslo Børs for the NOK Floating Rate Notes to be admitted to trading on the Oslo Børs. However, there can be no assurances that the NOK Floating Rate Notes will be listed and admitted to trading on the Oslo Børs.

22

Governing Law . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

The Notes and the Indentures will be governed by New York law. The Intercreditor Agreement, the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and the Escrow Agreements will be governed by English law. The security documents will be governed by the laws of the jurisdiction in which the collateral that is the subject of such security documents is located.

SUMMARY HISTORICAL CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL AND OTHER DATA This Offering Memorandum contains the following financial information: · the audited consolidated financial statements and the accompanying notes thereto of the Company
as of and for the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, which have been prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (``IFRS'') as adopted by the European Union and audited by our independent auditors, PricewaterhouseCoopers AB, as set forth in their audit report included elsewhere herein; and · the unaudited interim consolidated financial statements and the accompanying notes thereto of the Company as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2014 and 2013, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the European Union and reviewed by our independent auditors, PricewaterhouseCoopers AB, as set forth in their review report included elsewhere herein. Unless otherwise indicated, the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is the historical consolidated financial information of the Company. The preparation of financial statements in accordance with IFRS requires the use of certain critical accounting estimates. These standards also require management to exercise its judgment in the process of applying accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or areas where assumptions and estimates are significant to the financial statements, are disclosed in the consolidated financial statements of the Company and its subsidiaries, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The following tables should also be read in conjunction with ``Presentation of Financial and Other Information--Non-GAAP Financial Measures,'' ``Capitalization,'' ``Use of Proceeds'' and ``Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.'' The summary unaudited consolidated financial information for the twelve-month period ended June 30, 2014 has been calculated by adding the unaudited consolidated interim financial information for the six months ended June 30, 2014, derived from the unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of the Company for the six months ended June 30, 2014, and the historical financial information for the year ended December 31, 2013, derived from the audited consolidated financial statements of the Company for the year ended December 31, 2013, and subtracting the unaudited consolidated financial information for the six months ended June 30, 2013, derived from the unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of the Company for the six months ended June 30, 2013. This data has been prepared solely for the purpose of this Offering Memorandum, is not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting and has not been audited or reviewed.

(1) Finance costs consist of interest on loans from financial institutions, fair value gains and losses on financial derivatives (interest swaps), interest expense on the Subordinated Loans, net financial exchange gains/(losses) on financing activities, write down of investments in associated companies and other financial expenses. Our previous majority shareholders Investor and Altor Funds converted e533 million of the Subordinated Loans to equity with effect from July 1, 2013, resulting in a carrying amount of the Subordinated Loans of e146 million and e137 million as of June 30, 2014 and December 31, 2013, respectively. (1) We define cash revenue as revenue for the period adding back amortization of purchased debt and revaluation of purchased debt.
(2) We define revenue from continuing operations as revenue for the period, excluding revenue from sold companies (which, during the periods under review, included Mirror Accounting Group, Match AS, Lindorff Decision AS and Lindorff Customer Services AB) and the one-off gain from the sale of subsidiaries in 2011. (3) We define Adjusted EBITDA as profit and loss for the period before income tax expense, net financial costs and depreciation and amortization. Adjusted EBITDA is calculated by adding back portfolio amortization and revaluations of purchased loans and receivables to EBITDA. We use Adjusted EBITDA as a measure of our operating cash flow generation and the liquidity of our business. Neither EBITDA nor Adjusted EBITDA is measure of financial performance calculated in accordance with IFRS and should each be viewed as a supplement to, not a substitute for, our results of operations presented in accordance with

27

IFRS. See ``Presentation of Financial and Other Information.'' The reconciliation of net cash (outflow)/inflow from operating activities to EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA is as follows:

Net cash (outflow)/inflow from operating activities . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Adjustment for other non-cash items . . . . . . Corporate income tax paid . . . . . . . . . . . . Net financial items . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Gain/(loss) from sale of subsidiaries . . . . . . Amortization and revaluation of purchased
debt . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Net changes in working capital . . . . . . . . .

(a) Includes a gain from the sale of subsidiaries amounting to e15 million.
(4) The carrying value of each portfolio corresponds to the present value of estimated gross future cash flows discounted by an initial EIR. The carrying value of purchased debt represents the aggregate carrying value of our portfolios of purchased debt as of the dates presented.
(5) Gross collection on purchased debt means the total principal, interest, collection fees and legal fees received on portfolios that we own.
(6) ERC means our estimated remaining collections on our portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables over an 180-month period, which represents the expected future gross cash collections of our portfolios over an 180-month period. See ``Presentation of Financial and Other Information.''
(7) Face value of purchase debt is calculated as the principal amount plus accrued fees and interest at the time of acquisition of debt portfolios.

(1) Adjusted cash and cash equivalents represents cash and cash equivalents as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions as if the Transactions had occurred on June 30, 2014. See ``Use of Proceeds'' and ``Capitalization.''
(2) As adjusted Total Secured Debt represents our total outstanding third-party secured indebtedness, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions as if the Transactions had occurred on June 30, 2014. Excludes any debt that may be drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Completion Date. See ``Use of Proceeds'' and ``Capitalization.''
(3) As adjusted Total Debt represents our total outstanding third-party indebtedness, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions as if the Transactions had occurred on June 30, 2014. Excludes any debt that may be drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Completion Date. See ``Use of Proceeds'' and ``Capitalization.''

29

(4) As adjusted Total Net Debt represents as adjusted Total Debt less as adjusted cash and cash equivalents. (5) As adjusted LTM Interest Expense represents interest expense in respect of the Notes, as if the Transactions had occurred on
July 1, 2013 and assuming, with respect to the Euro Floating Rate Notes, a constant EURIBOR rate for the twelve-month period ended June 30, 2014 based on a three-month EURIBOR of 0.208 per cent, with respect to the NOK Floating Rate Notes, a constant NIBOR rate for the twelve-month period ended June 30, 2014 based on a spot three-month NIBOR of 1.690 per cent, and with respect to the SEK Floating Rate Notes, a constant STIBOR rate for the twelve-month period ended June 30, 2014 based on a three-month STIBOR rate of 0.511 per cent. As adjusted LTM Interest Expense has been presented for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what our interest payments would have actually been had the issue of the Notes occurred on the date assumed, nor does it purport to project our interest payments for any future period or our financial condition at any future date.

31

RISK FACTORS
An investment in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. In addition to the other information in this Offering Memorandum, you should carefully consider the following risk factors before purchasing the Notes. The occurrence of any of the events discussed below could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. The risks described below are not the only ones we believe we are exposed to. Additional risks that are not currently known to us, or that we currently, based on our regular risk assessment, consider to be immaterial, could significantly impair our business activities and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. If any one of these events occurs, the trading price of the Notes could decline and we may not be able to pay interest or principal on Notes when due, and you could lose all or part of your investment. The order in which these risks are presented is not intended to provide an indication of the likelihood of their occurrence or of their severity or significance.
This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that are based on assumptions and estimates and are subject to risks and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of many factors, including, but not limited to, the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.
Risks Related to Our Industry and Business
The economic conditions in the markets in which we operate affect our business.
We are exposed to the economic, market and fiscal conditions in the markets in which we operate and any positive or negative developments regarding these conditions. If the economy suffers a material and adverse downturn for a prolonged period of time that, in turn, increases the unemployment rate and/or impacts interest rates and the availability of credit, we may not be able to perform debt collection services in connection with our debt collection business or on the debt portfolios we have purchased in a manner consistent with our past practice due to the inability of debtors to make payments, at the same levels or at all, as was the case during the recent economic downturn.
While leading indicators suggest that economic conditions may be improving in the markets in which we operate, with GDP growth in 2014, there can be no assurances that this will occur or that the net effect of any change in economic conditions will be positive. An improvement in the economic conditions in the markets in which we operate could impact our business and performance in various ways, including reducing the number of attractive portfolio opportunities that are available for purchase and increasing the competitiveness of the pricing for portfolios that we purchase and debt collection services that we offer. There can be no assurances that our business and results of operations will develop positively in this environment. Accordingly, any of these developments could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
We are active in competitive markets and may be unable to continue to successfully compete with businesses that may offer more attractive prices or have greater financial resources, less expensive funding or lower return requirements than we have.
The European CMS industry is fragmented and consists of several thousand companies with varying profiles. We face competition from new and existing debt collection providers, other purchasers of portfolios of overdue debt and other overdue receivables and debt originators that manage their own portfolios rather than outsourcing or selling them. This competition includes, but is not limited to, competition on the basis of price. New market entrants and existing competitors may offer more attractive pricing levels, both for debt collection contracts and for debt portfolio purchases, and accept lower returns in order to gain or increase market share. There can be no assurances that this price competition will not result in us paying higher prices for portfolios that we purchase or charging less for our debt collection services, both of which could decrease our margins and have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
We face bidding competition in our acquisition of debt portfolios. We believe that successful bids are awarded based on price and a range of other factors, including service, compliance, reputation and relationships with the sellers of debt portfolios. Some of our current competitors, and potential new competitors, may have more effective pricing and collection models, greater adaptability to changing market needs and more established relationships in our industry and geographic markets than we do. Moreover, our competitors may elect to pay prices for debt portfolios that we determine are not
32

economically sustainable and, in that event, our volume of debt portfolio purchases may be diminished. There can be no assurances that our existing or potential sources of debt portfolios will continue to sell their portfolios at recent levels or at all, or that we will continue to offer competitive bids for debt portfolios.
Some of our current competitors, and potential new competitors, may have substantially greater financial resources, less expensive funding or lower return requirements than we currently have. Additionally, in the future we may not have the financial resources to offer competitive bids for portfolio purchases and debt collection contracts, especially when competing with competitors who have greater financial resources than we have. There can be no assurances that we will be able to develop and expand our business or adapt to changing market needs as well as our current or future competitors. Any of these developments could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
There may not be a sufficient supply of debt, or appropriately priced debt, available for purchase, and a decrease in our ability to purchase portfolios of debt could materially and adversely affect our business.
The availability of debt portfolios at prices that generate profits depends on a number of factors, some of which are outside of our control, including:
· the level of consumer spending;
· the availability of credit to consumers, which is driven by a number of factors, including heightened regulation of the credit card and consumer lending industry, changing credit origination strategies, tighter lending criteria introduced by consumer credit providers and general economic conditions;
· the level of non-performance on consumer debt portfolios and the proportion of such portfolios that are written off by originators, which also in turn may affect the availability of credit to consumers identified above;
· sales of debt portfolios by originators, which could be jeopardized by a change in accounting policies or practices, the consolidation of credit card issuers or increased sophistication in internal collection efforts;
· potential concerns that the small value received for defaulted debt portfolios as a percentage of their face value may not outweigh the potential reputational risks or required management attention associated with selling defaulted debt portfolios;
· negative publicity or a loss of trust in our industry, whether due to the failure of one or more of our competitors to meet their legal or regulatory obligations or otherwise;
· increased government regulation of the circumstances in which originators, especially FSA-regulated entities, have a right to collect on debt; and
· the macro economic environments of the countries in which we operate.
Originators may develop technological tools that could override the advantages we believe we currently possess in terms of tracing technology and customer profile development. If originators choose to perform more of their debt collections internally as a result of these data quality improvements, the volume of debt portfolio sales or the quality of underlying debt sold could decrease and, consequently, we may not be able to buy the type and quantity of receivables at prices consistent with our historical return targets. In addition, there could be a reduction in the availability of debt portfolios sold early in the financial difficulty cycle and have had little or no exposure to collections activity. This ``fresh'' debt typically has higher collection expectations, because less work has been applied to the assets to obtain customer payments.
If we are unable to purchase portfolios from originators at appropriate prices, or if one or more originators stop or decrease their sales of portfolios due to one of the factors listed above or any other factors, we could lose a potential source of income and our business may be materially and adversely affected. If we do not replace the debt portfolios that we service with additional portfolios, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
33

A significant amount of our revenue is generated from clients active within the financial services industry.
We have derived, and believe that we will continue to derive, a significant portion of our revenue from clients active within the financial services industry. Financial institutions accounted for 68%, 64% and 60% of our revenue for the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, respectively. The departure, or potential risk of departure, from the euro by one or more Eurozone countries could lead to a reduction in market confidence and a weakening of European financial institutions. Adverse economic conditions and uncertainties, and any potential resulting failures or consolidations of financial institutions, may adversely affect us by significantly reducing our client engagements. Additionally, adverse economic conditions could lead to a reduction in the propensity of financial institutions to lend to debtors in the markets in which we operate, as was the case during the global financial crisis in 2008 and 2009. Adverse economic conditions may leading to a reduced supply of debt available for us to perform debt collection on or fewer opportunities for us to enter into forward flow agreements, as well as negatively affecting debtors by reducing disposable income levels or otherwise impairing their ability to fulfil their payment obligations. Any changes in the volume of business derived from clients active within the financial services industry could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
We generate a significant amount of our revenue from a small number of large financial institutions.
For the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011 our largest debt collection client accounted for 5.3%, 4.9% and 5.4%, respectively of total revenue annually. During the same period, we purchased portfolios from 103, 123 and 118 different clients and we performed debt collection on behalf of approximately 20,000, 19,500 and 19,000 different clients. However, a significant percentage of our purchased portfolios and external revenue derived from debt collection are concentrated with a small number of large financial institutions. For the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, we purchased 81%, 80% and 76%, respectively, of our portfolios from our largest five clients, measured by total amount paid, and 31%, 21% and 23%, respectively, of our external revenue derived from debt collection was from our largest five clients, based on the revenue we received. If we were to lose one of our large financial institutions clients, or experience a reduction in the volume of business from them, and we were unable to replace the lost revenue, then this could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
Errors in our collection process or other operational matters or negative attention relating to the CMS industry in general, or to us in particular, could have a negative effect on our business and reputation.
Our ability to accurately collect debt and treat debtors fairly is critical to our business and our reputation. Our reputation is fundamental to maintaining our relationships with current and potential clients, especially financial institutions, and regulators. The following events, among others, may have a negative effect on our reputation and/or our financial results: negative media publicity relating either to us or the wider CMS industry, allegations of unethical or improper behavior by us or third parties we use in the collection process, inability to collect debts on an accurate and timely basis, failure to respect and treat the debtors fairly, failures in our collection and data protection processes, the actions of third parties engaged by us in the debt collection process, IT platform failure or other operational issues, litigation, regulatory restrictions, investigations, fines or enforcement actions and matters affecting our financial reporting. The collection of debt, particularly historic debt, involves complex interpretations and calculations of contractual terms that may vary by client and/or country, which may impact the calculation of debtors' resulting payment obligations and the collection strategies we employ. Our processes and procedures are designed to ensure accuracy in the collection process and we review our collection strategies and payment calculations with a goal of ensuring that we apply best practices across our operations. However, there can be no assurances that the inherent complexity of debt calculation and historical inaccuracies will not result in any issues in the future. Any of the foregoing events could result in financial liability for us and could jeopardize our relationships with our clients, our ability to establish new client relationships, have a negative impact on a debtor's willingness to pay a debt owed to us or to our clients, diminish our attractiveness as a counterparty or lead to increased regulations of the CMS industry, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
34
