We may not be able to enforce claims with respect to the representations and warranties that the Sellers have provided to us under the Acquisition Agreement.
In connection with the Acquisition, the Sellers have given certain limited customary representations and warranties in the Acquisition Agreement related to their respective shares in the Target Companies, the Target Group and the business of the Target Group. The Acquisition Agreement also contains a tax indemnity. See ``--Risks Related to Our Industry and Business--Litigation, investigations and proceedings may negatively affect our business.'' There can be no assurance that we will be able to enforce any claims against the Sellers relating to breaches of such representations and warranties. Each Seller's liability with respect to breaches of its representations and warranties under the Acquisition Agreement is limited. Moreover, even if we ultimately succeed in recovering any amounts from the Sellers, we may temporarily be required to bear these losses ourselves.
The Target Group may have liabilities that are not known to us.
The Target Group will be acquired with certain liabilities, including certain pension liabilities and certain tax liabilities. There may be liabilities that we failed or were unable to discover in the course of performing
66

due diligence investigations into the Target Group. Any such undiscovered liabilities of the Target Group, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, such liabilities may not be recoverable against the representations and warranties given by the Seller under the Acquisition Agreement. As we integrate the Target Group, we may learn additional information about the Target Group that adversely affects us, such as unknown or contingent liabilities and issues relating to compliance with applicable laws. Some agreements with customers and sellers of debt contain change of control provisions which require us to provide notice to such customer or seller of any change of control of the relevant Group company or provide such customer or seller with the option to terminate the agreement upon such change of control. The Acquisition will result in a change of ownership of the Group. Some agreements require us to notify our debt collection customers or the sellers of debt we purchase prior to or upon a change of control of the Group or a relevant company within the Group. Such change of control may give rise to the right of the relevant customer or seller to terminate the underlying agreement or to repurchase the assets sold under the relevant debt purchase agreement. We therefore cannot assure you that these agreements will not be terminated or renegotiated.
67

THE TRANSACTIONS
The Acquisition of the Target Group
On July 18, 2014, Senior Secured Notes Issuer, as purchaser, and Altor Funds, Investor and certain minority shareholders, including members of management who hold an interest in one or more of the Target Companies, as sellers (the ``Sellers''), entered into the Acquisition Agreement regarding the direct or indirect, as applicable, acquisition of all the shares of the Target Group (the ``Acquisition''). Under the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will directly or indirectly, as applicable, acquire all of the issued and outstanding capital stock of the Target Companies as of the consummation of the Acquisition (the ``Completion Date''). The consummation of the Acquisition pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement will be subject to the clearance of (i) the EU Commission, (ii) the Russian Federation and (iii) the Norwegian Financial Supervisory Authority (together, the ``Acquisition Conditions''). If the Acquisition is not consummated by the one-hundred-fortieth (140th) business day after the signing of the Acquisition Agreement, the Acquisition Agreement may be terminated by either party. In connection with obtaining the approvals of the applicable regulatory and competition authorities, we may agree to divest certain of our assets or operations. We currently do not expect that we will be required to divest assets or operations that generate a significant portion of our revenue. See ``Risk Factors--Risks Related to the Transaction.''
Pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will acquire all of the issued and outstanding capital stock of the Target Companies for e1,352 million (the ``Purchase Price''), subject to certain purchase price adjustments. The interest on the Purchase Price shall be calculated on the basis of an agreed rate at eleven and a half (11.5) per cent per annum, and shall be calculated for the period between May 1, 2014 and the Completion Date (the ``Interest Payment Adjustment''). Further, the Purchase Price shall be adjusted upwards with respect to certain other components, such as the net cash amounts in some of the Target Companies and compensation due to certain intra-group loans. In addition, the Purchase Price will be reduced by the amount of any dividends or similar payment, asset transfers or certain other transfers of value from the Target Group to the Sellers that occur prior to the Completion Date that are not permitted under the Acquisition Agreement and certain payments to employees or directors or finding fee arrangements triggered as a result of the Acquisition.
The Acquisition Agreement includes customary restrictions on the activities of the Target Group prior to the Completion Date, including restrictions on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, as well as limited representations, warranties and covenants that are subject to limitations and exclusions. The Acquisition Agreement does not prohibit the Company from incurring additional debt under its existing revolving credit facility. Any such additional debt borrowed will be refinanced on the Completion Date as part of the Transactions.
The Financing of the Acquisition
We plan to use the proceeds from the offering of the Notes, together with an equity contribution from Nordic Capital Fund VIII, the Altor Funds, Investor and certain co-investors and the proceeds from the Shareholder Notes to finance the Acquisition, pay related fees and expenses and refinance (together with certain cash on hand) the Existing Credit Facilities and the Existing Vendor Loan. To the extent additional sources are required on completion, the Issuer may utilize the Revolving Credit Facility (in an amount up to e50 million) and/or additional equity. See ``Use of Proceeds.'' The Target Group had e956 million of outstanding third-party indebtedness as of June 30, 2014, including under the Existing Credit Facilities and the Existing Vendor Loan. We expect to repay all of the indebtedness outstanding under the Existing Credit Facilities and the Existing Vendor Loan on the Completion Date.
The Notes
The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is offering e252.5 million in aggregate principal amount of the Euro Floating Rate Notes, NOK 1.68 billion in aggregate principal amount of the NOK Floating Rate Notes and e550 million in aggregate principal amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes. The Senior Notes Issuer is offering e250 million in aggregate principal amount of the Euro Senior Notes and SEK 1.85 billion in aggregate principal amount of the SEK Floating Rate Notes.
The gross proceeds from this offering will be deposited into the Escrow Accounts pending the consummation of the Acquisition and the satisfaction of certain other conditions and will be controlled by, and pledged on a first-priority basis in favor of, the relevant Trustee for the benefit of the relevant
68

holders of the Notes. If the Acquisition is not consummated and such other conditions are not satisfied on or prior to February 10, 2015, we will be required to redeem the Notes at a special mandatory redemption price equal to the issue price of the Notes, together with any accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, from the Issue Date to the special mandatory redemption date. See ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes--Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption'' and ``Description of the Senior Notes--Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.'' On the Issue Date, Nordic Capital Fund VIII will enter into a guarantee agreement pursuant to which it will guarantee the Issuers' obligations under the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes in the event the purchase price payable on a special mandatory redemption of the Senior Secured Notes or the Senior Notes, as applicable, exceeds the proceeds in the relevant escrow account. The Revolving Credit Facility On or before the Issue Date, we will enter into the Revolving Credit Facility in the amount of e225 million. To the extent additional sources are required on closing, the Issuers may utilize the Revolving Credit Facility (up to an amount of e50 million) and/or additional equity. See ``Description of Other Indebtedness.'' We refer to the Acquisition, the financing of the Acquisition and the repayment of the Existing Credit Facilities and the Existing Vendor Loan, together as the ``Transactions.'' Please see ``Use of Proceeds,'' ``Description of Other Indebtedness,'' ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes'' and ``Description of the Senior Notes.''
69

USE OF PROCEEDS
The gross proceeds of the Senior Secured Notes will be e1,000 million (equivalent) and the gross proceeds of the Senior Notes will be e450 million (equivalent). We intend to use the gross proceeds from the offering of the Notes, together with the equity contribution from Nordic Capital Fund VIII, Altor Funds, Investor and certain co-investors, and the proceeds from the Shareholder Notes, to: (i) pay the purchase price for the Acquisition under the Acquisition Agreement; (ii) pay related fees and expenses; and (iii) refinance, together with certain cash on hand, the Existing Credit Facilities and the Existing Vendor Loans. To the extent additional sources are required on completion of the Acquisition, the Issuers may utilize the Revolving Credit Facility (in an amount up to e50 million) and/or proceeds from additional equity contributions.
For descriptions of our anticipated indebtedness following the offering of the Notes, see ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes,'' ``Description of the Senior Notes,'' ``Description of Other Indebtedness'' and ``Capitalization.''
The following table sets forth our expected estimated sources and uses of funds in connection with the Transactions. Amounts included in the table are based on June 30, 2014 data. In addition to the sources below, the Issuer expects to enter into the Revolving Credit Facility which provides for borrowings up to an aggregate principal amount of e225 million. Actual amounts will vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including the actual Completion Date, fluctuations in currency exchange rates, the amount of cash generated by the Target Group prior to the Completion Date and differences between estimated and actual fees and expenses.

Selected Statement of Financial Position Data

73

MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
The following is a discussion and analysis of the results of operations and financial condition of the Company, based on the audited consolidated financial statements of the Company and its subsidiaries as of and for the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011 and the unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of the Company and its subsidiaries as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2014 and 2013, in each case, prepared in accordance with IFRS.
You should read this discussion in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements and the accompanying notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. A summary of the critical accounting estimates that have been applied to the Company's consolidated financial statements is set forth below in ``--Significant Accounting Policies.'' You should also review the information in the section ``Presentation of Financial and Other Information.'' This discussion also includes forward-looking statements which, although based on assumptions that we consider reasonable, are subject to risks and uncertainties which could cause actual events or conditions to differ materially from those expressed or implied by the forward-looking statements. For a discussion of risks and uncertainties facing us as a result of various factors, see ``Forward-Looking Statements'' and ``Risk Factors.''
Overview
We are a leading pan-European CMS provider, focusing on overdue unsecured consumer debt, with a market leading position (by revenue) (Source: Company Market Study) in the European financial institutions sector. We provide debt collection services to, and acquire portfolios of overdue debt and other overdue receivables from, our clients, who include financial institutions, telecommunications companies, utilities providers, public sector and retail stores.
We are active along the entire CMS value chain, performing the functions as illustrated in the graphic below:
External Offering / 3rd Party Services

Information Services

Invoice/ Web Invoice

Debt Collection

Pre-legal

Legal

Surveillance and Recovery

Debt Purchasing

Lindorff Acting as Principal

12AUG201407150171

· Debt Collection: We engineer and implement tailored debt collection strategies and solutions to maximize cash flow streams from overdue debt and other overdue receivables for clients who have decided to outsource their debt collection function. We service NPLs for financial institutions clients, including credit card loans, car loans, overdrafts, consumer loans, business loans and mortgages, as well as insurance and factoring claims. We also collect overdue bills for other clients, including telecommunications providers, utilities and retail stores.

· Debt Purchasing: We purchase portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables from our clients, which we then typically service using our in-house debt collection function.

· Other Services: In addition, we provide our clients with a wide range of services before debt and receivables are overdue, including customer and credit information and analysis, data extraction and modelling, selection and scoring of potential customers, invoicing and web invoicing, reminder services, factoring solutions and turn-key solutions for web-shops.

From our origins in Norway, we have expanded our geographic footprint to serve clients in key markets across Europe, with local operations in Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Spain, the Netherlands, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Russia. We recognize revenue from debt collection services, which consists of fees from debtors and fees and commissions from third-party clients, when we collect on a claim. We recognize revenue from purchased portfolios according to the effective interest method.

74

According to this method, the carrying value of each portfolio corresponds to the present value of estimated gross future cash flows discounted by an initial effective interest rate (``EIR'') determined on the date the portfolio was purchased. The EIR is the interest rate that exactly discounts estimated future cash received through the expected life of the portfolio and which we calculate by considering the estimated level of gross collections over the next 180 months and the purchase price of the portfolio. Adjustments are recognized in our consolidated income statement, such that in cases where monthly cash flows from a portfolio are greater than the cash flow forecast for the same period, the excess collection amounts are recorded as revenue in the period and, conversely, monthly cash flows that are lower than the cash flow forecast for the same period are recorded as a reduction of revenue in the period. We recognize revenue from other services when the services are provided and revenue from subscription services is recognized proportionally over the duration of the agreement, usually one year.

Illustrative Economics
The illustration below gives a high-level overview of our business model and economics:
· In the debt collection segment, we collect overdue debt on behalf of our customers. As of June 30, 2014, we had e14.5 billion of third party debt under management. For the year ended December 31, 2013, we generated e228 million of revenue through fees and commissions.
· In the debt purchasing segment, as of June 30, 2014, the face value of purchased debt was e17.3 billion (calculated as principal including accrued fees and interest at acquisition of debt portfolios). The average purchase price was 8.7% of the face value or e1.5 billion. On average, we collect 2.6 times the purchase price over 15 years, which translates into e4 billion of collections. Typically, 3 years after the date of acquisition we have recovered the purchase price paid based on gross collections.
· We also performs a wide range of services before debt and receivables are overdue, including credit information and invoicing services, where we earn a fee for the services provided.

Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Our business and results of operations, as well as the key operating metrics discussed below, have been, and are expected to continue to be, affected by certain key factors including, in particular, level of

76

debt and other overdue receivables available for purchase and for third party collection, purchases of portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables at the right price, competition and pricing, gross collection levels, collection costs and operational efficiency, seasonality, acquisitions and geographic expansion, economic conditions, regulatory considerations, foreign currency effects and tax effects. Each of these factors is discussed in more detail below.
Level of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables Available for Purchase and for Third Party Collection
Our results of operations are linked to the overall level of debt and other overdue receivables available for purchase and for third-party collection in the markets and industry sectors in which we operate. During the periods under review, the level of sale and outsourcing of debt and other overdue receivables has increased, particularly in relation to NPLs originated by financial institutions, and we believe that this development will continue. This market growth opportunity is largely driven by three factors: a large buildup of NPLs by financial institutions, an increased propensity to sell NPLs as regulation has put pressure on financial institutions to delever and an increase in the number of financial institutions selling debt and outsourcing collection services as financial institutions have refocused their businesses by exiting non-core operations, such as in-house debt collection. During the periods under review, we benefitted from these industry trends and were able to expand our operations and increase our results of operations. We entered into new collection services contracts and successfully negotiated contract extensions with existing clients, and we purchased additional portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables.
During the global financial crisis, the CMS market was volatile. Debtors' repayment profiles were extended, which led to longer estimated remaining collections (``ERC'') horizons. In response to this development, we adopted a cautious approach and decreased our portfolio purchases. Instead, we shifted our focus to debt collection. Performing both debt collection and debt purchasing has helped us build a flexible and balanced business that we believe is well-suited to capture the increased overall level of use of CMS services across Europe. Regardless of whether a financial institution desires to manage its CMS requirements by selling debt and other overdue receivables or by outsourcing its debt collection function, we can offer these services and build a relationship with the client, enabling us to be the preferred choice if and when that client decides to shift or expand its usage of CMS services.
Historically, in our experience, debt that is long overdue has been predominantly offered for sale, whereas ``fresher'' debt (i.e., debt more recently declared overdue) is typically managed by debt originators through a combination of sales and outsourcing. During the periods under review, a number of major portfolios consisting of older debt were offered for sale to the market, which made debt purchases more prevalent in many markets during these years. Given the large buildup of NPLs by financial institutions in Europe since 2008, based on our analysis of the Company Market Study, we expect the volumes of NPL sales in Europe to remain at similar levels over the next five years. As markets mature, debt originators tend to outsource their CMS requirements at an earlier stage of the claim's life cycle, which typically results in a more even balance between debt purchase and debt collection. The growth in CMS services has been led by mature markets, such as the Nordic region, where the level of debt collection services has been particularly high, but with other European markets now realizing the benefit of engaging a specialist to handle their CMS needs, we believe there are significant opportunities for us to expand further, within both debt collection services and debt purchases. See ``Industry Overview--Overview of Selected European Markets.''
Purchases of Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables at the Right Price
Our ability to purchase portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables at the right price has been a key driver of our results of operations in the periods under review and will continue to be a key driver going forward. Purchased debt consists mainly of portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables purchased at prices significantly below the nominal face value and which are recognized at amortized cost. We expect to achieve collections in excess of the portfolio purchase price and as of June 30, 2014 our ERC was 2.6 times the carrying value of our purchased portfolios.
When purchasing portfolios, we engage in an extensive valuation of the portfolio in order to determine what price we should offer the client, see ``Our Business--Operating and Service Offerings--Debt Purchasing--Valuation and Due Diligence.'' Our performance is dependent on our ability to purchase portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables that meet our investment criteria, including prices that generate an appropriate return on purchased debt. After purchasing a portfolio, our performance is
77

further dependent on our ability to generate gross collection levels at or in excess of our expectations for that portfolio.
The global financial crisis reduced the propensity of debt originators to sell overdue receivables as prices decreased and also led to difficulties for debt purchasers to obtain funding for purchases of portfolios in 2008 and 2009. During this period, collection levels on portfolios decreased, thus reducing overall portfolio performance. This impacted not only the pricing of new portfolios, but also existing portfolios that debt purchasers owned at the time and which were typically secured under existing funding arrangements. Consequently, the years surrounding the global financial crisis created challenges for debt purchasers to obtain funding. We were able to adapt quickly to these challenging market conditions. During this time, our portfolios were primarily sourced from financial institutions in the Nordic region and we were able to mitigate the impact of the adverse market conditions by changing our collection strategies and adopting solution rates (i.e., expected collection relative to the principal amount) with long-term repayment profiles. The lower purchase prices resulted in reduced propensity of debt originators to sell overdue receivables. Instead, they shifted focus to debt collection services. Due to our full service business model, we were able to adapt our business mix and meet this client demand. Pure debt purchasers, who lacked in-house debt collection operations, were unable to react in this manner. Similarly, when the markets started to recover again in 2010, and pricing levels became increasingly attractive for sellers, we were able to respond rapidly by increasing portfolio purchases. We believe that our balanced business model allows us to adapt to a changing market environment and the dynamics of supply.
From January 1, 2011 to December 31, 2013, we invested e506 million to purchase portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables, including deliveries under forward flow agreements, with an aggregate face value of e6.0 billion. We invested substantially more in 2012 than we did in both 2011 and 2013, in large part due to the purchase in 2012 of a major portfolio with a face value in excess of e1 billion from one of the largest financial institutions in Germany. As of December 31, 2013, 87% of the face value of our portfolios across our geographic markets consisted of NPLs originated by financial institutions, with the remaining approximately 13% representing overdue receivables from clients in other industries. During the periods under review, the share of NPLs originated by financial institutions has been increasing gradually due to large NPL purchases in Germany and Spain where we have only minor exposure to utility or telecom industries. As of December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011 we had ERC of e1.70 billion, e1.66 billion and e1.29 billion, respectively, and as of June 30, 2014 and 2013 we had ERC of e1.89 billion and e1.7 billion, respectively. The resulting carrying value of purchased portfolios in our IFRS consolidated statement of financial position was e675 million, e658 million and e525 million, respectively, as of December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, and e760 million and e674 million, respectively, as of June 30, 2014 and 2013.
The table below presents information on the portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables that we purchased during the periods under review. In any period, we purchase portfolios that can vary in age, type and ultimate collectability, which results in period-to-period variation in average prices paid and face value.

For the year ended December 31,

8.9

There are two principal models for purchasing portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables, one-off agreements and forward flow agreements. The majority of portfolios for sale are currently offered to the market through competitive tender processes. In a one-off agreement, we agree to buy a portfolio of claims that we receive in one transaction upon payment. In a forward flow agreement, we agree to buy claims at a pre-defined price or price range for a given volume and quality from a client on an ongoing basis. Forward flow agreements are beneficial because they offer a predictable and certain flow of claims. As of December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, we had commitments for purchases of portfolios pursuant to forward flow agreements amounting to e66 million, e28 million and e17 million, respectively. Forward flow agreements are typically not long-term contracts and a number of our forward flow

78

agreements expire in 2014. Although we expect that many of these will be renewed, our current forward flow agreements provide no medium to long-term assurance on purchasing levels.
Our full-service business model allows us to offer flexible pricing arrangements to our clients that are tailored for the specific circumstances of the client and the relevant portfolio. For example, in certain circumstances we will co-invest with other debt purchasers to purchase a portfolio. Co-investment is beneficial for a number of reasons: (1) it typically provides us with a large portfolio to perform debt collection through master servicing agreements, (2) enhances our ability to purchase large portfolios, (3) gives us the opportunity to cooperate with external expertise and purchase diverse asset pools (e.g., SMEs), (4) enables us to diversify risk as we share the risk with a partner and purchase several portfolios as opposed to a single one and (5) facilitates entering into new markets and building both purchase and collection capabilities early on in a new jurisdiction.
Our ability to purchase portfolios is dependent on our internally generated funding resources and our access to financing at the time portfolios become available for purchase. We currently fund our purchases of portfolios, working capital needs and other expenditures with cash generated from our operating activities and borrowings under our credit facility. We believe that we will be able to continue to obtain financing (bank debt as well as capital markets debt) subject to market conditions. See ``--Liquidity and Capital Resources'' for additional information on the funding of our portfolio purchases and see ``--Economic Conditions'' for additional information on the effects of economic conditions on our business and results of operations.
Competition and Pricing
Competition and pricing levels in the markets in which we operate affect our ability to successfully and profitably purchase portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables and carry out our debt collection services. The European CMS market is fragmented, consisting of several thousand companies with varied profiles. In recent years, we believe that there has been a trend towards increased concentration of the CMS industry with a small core group of CMS providers, such as Intrum Justitia, EOS and us, expanding in scale as core clients, in particular financial institutions, are increasingly placing value on high-quality data assets acquired over an extended period of time, a robust compliance framework, a multi-national presence and long-term relationships with CMS providers. In addition, reputation and ethical behavior are fundamental competitive advantages in order to maintain relationships with current and potential clients, especially financial institutions. The pricing element of debt collection services has become increasingly competitive and resulted in decreased pricing levels for such services during the periods under review, particularly in the Nordic region.
Portfolios of unsecured consumer NPLs, which is where we focus our debt purchases, have become subject to increasingly competitive pricing as financial institutions have taken a strategic view to divest these types of portfolios. As these portfolios have grown in size and value, this has become an attractive sector and existing market participants, together with new market entrants, have intensified competition and pricing. Furthermore, the increased price levels are largely due, we believe, to the claims sold being ``fresher'', already paying or in the legal stage of collection, as opposed to older, non-paying claims depending on voluntary payments, which is the pattern for portfolios in some of the markets we have entered more recently. The global financial crisis led to unattractive pricing levels for purchases of portfolios in 2008 and 2009, mainly as a result of reduced ability of debtors to repay their debt, reduced propensity of debt originators to sell overdue receivables and difficulties for debt purchasers to obtain funding, but markets started to recover again in 2010 and pricing levels have been advantageous during the periods under review. Unlike companies that do not offer debt collection services, our balanced operations provide an efficient tool in this competitive landscape. Since we generate steady revenue and cash flow from our debt collection services, we can selectively choose which NPL portfolios to bid for and do not have to purchase portfolios we believe are priced too high simply to ensure sufficient cash flow into the operations. In this competitive landscape, our EBITDA margin has improved from 28% in the year ended December 31, 2011 (excluding the gain from sale of subsidiaries) to 31% in the year ended December 31, 2013. See ``Risk Factors--Risks Related to Our Industry and Business--We are active in competitive markets and may be unable to continue to successfully compete with businesses that may offer more attractive prices or have greater financial resources, less expensive funding or lower return requirements than we have.''
79

Gross Collection Levels
We primarily generate revenue from: (a) fees and commissions received from claims on which we perform debt collection services, pursuant to contracts that typically contain ``no cure no pay'' payment terms, which means that we are paid only if we are able to successfully collect on a claim; and (b) payments received from debtors linked to claims in our purchased portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables. The ability and willingness of a debtor to pay depends on several factors, such as his/her employment status, the availability of funds and asset ownership. We believe that our business benefits from the quality of the data that we can build about a debtor's circumstances and the analysis we can perform on such data in order to confirm the debtor's employment status and/or asset ownership, for example, and assess his/her ability or willingness to pay, and ultimately determine the best collections strategy for individual debtors.
We have a large and diverse collection of portfolios that have delivered consistent and stable revenue over time. In 2013, we received approximately 8 million payments and we had approximately 8.6 million claims in stock as of December 31, 2013. Our collections per month per full-time employee (``FTE'') employed in operations averaged approximately e131,536 in 2013, and the claims in stock per FTE employed in operations increased from approximately 3,800 at the start of 2013 to approximately 4,250 by the end of 2013.
Gross Collection Levels on Debt Collection Services
Since our client contracts for debt collection services are typically entered into on a ``no cure no pay'' basis, our debt collection revenue is directly linked to our gross collection levels. The volume of debt and other overdue receivables outsourced to us by our third-party collection clients, and consequently our revenue from debt collection services, is linked to our historic ability to collect on overdue debt and on our relationships with our debt collection clients, including our ability to demonstrate strong gross collection levels. In addition, by achieving strong collection levels, we can maximize the amount recovered by our clients, as well as the fees and commissions we receive on a particular claim. Our debt collection clients actively manage the outsourcing process by benchmarking our collections performance against that of our competitors on a regular basis. Depending on the outcome of such benchmarking, our clients may release more claims to us or, conversely, if we have performed poorly compared to our peer group, reduce the number of claims that we service. We offer flexible pricing arrangements to our debt collection services clients that are tailored for the specific circumstances of the client and the relevant claims to be outsourced. We believe that the benefits of our effective claims collection strategy are evident through our many long-standing client relationships where we are seen as a trusted, important and strategic business partner by entering into a master servicing agreement to provide collection services on the client's debt and other overdue receivables that we have not purchased. For more information about our debt collection services, see ``--Key Operating Metrics for Debt Collection Services.''
Gross Collection Levels on Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables
After we purchase a portfolio, we typically manage it in-house. Revenue generated from claims in our purchased portfolios is impacted by the gross collection levels that we are able to achieve. As we keep the entire amount we collect on purchased portfolios, we can strategically allocate additional resources and costs to optimize collection and increase collection levels on a specific portfolio, until we reach the stage when the resources and costs required exceed the expected revenue. We believe that our ability to convert non-paying claims into paying claims on our purchased portfolios illustrates the degree of accuracy of our analysis conducted through our data assets and analytical capabilities and the effectiveness of our scalable, multi-channel collections approach and we further believe that we operate our forecasts with an appropriate balance between prudent pricing and strong collection performance. From January 1, 2011 to June 30, 2014, we collected 106% of our original investment projections. During 2009 and 2010, following the global financial crisis, we experienced a change in market dynamics where there was an increase in our collection costs, while debtors were unable to pay back their loans on previous levels. This resulted in our actual collections being lower than our projected collections (based on our pricing model at the time of purchase). In order to mitigate the effects of the prevailing conditions, we shifted our collection strategies from more costly methods, such as bailiffs, to less expensive alternatives, such as long-term payment plans. After adapting our collection strategies in this way, we managed to meet our collection estimates and during the periods under review, actual collections on our
80

owned portfolios have consistently exceeded projected collections based on our pricing model at the time of purchase.
Ability to Extract Value and Maintain Collection Levels on Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables
We currently manage e30 billion of debt, of which e15 billion represents purchased portfolios that we own. We purchase these portfolios at significant discounts to face value and typically collect multiples of the purchase price. Our focus is on debt from financial institutions as we believe these have the most attractive characteristics: very long-term stable cash flows allowing for higher total collections and gross cash-on-cash multiples. We believe that these characteristics allow for sophisticated players, such as us, to impact collections and returns by applying the optimal collection strategies. For a description of how we manage and track the performance of our portfolios, see ``--Revaluation of Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables.''
Our ability to impact financial performance by extracting value from these portfolios is demonstrated by our track record of extending maturities and maintaining high and sustainable cash flows, resulting in total collections above expectations. Our ability to extract value from portfolios is also evidenced by the evolution of our old portfolios. For portfolios purchased in 2005 and before, we now expect to have total collections of 3.2 times the purchase price, compared to our initial business case expectations of 2.6 times the purchase price. This evolution can also be observed on our more recent vintages. For our portfolios purchased in 2010, we have already raised our expected total collections to 2.6 times the purchase price compared to 2.5 times the purchase price under the initial business case.
There is also potential to increase collections by further improving our collection rates from our ongoing optimization of surveillance portfolios. During the surveillance phase, debtors are monitored for any changes in personal circumstances, e.g., employment status, that may allow debtors to commence payment. Included in the face value under management, we currently have e19 billion face value of debt under surveillance, generating approximately e400 million in annual collections. The collection rates on these portfolios vary by geography and they tend to be lower in markets where we have less developed operations, such as Spain and Germany. Bringing the collection rates in these markets up to the same level as Norway, Sweden and Finland would have a meaningful impact on the yield of our portfolios. For a more detailed description of the surveillance phase, see ``Our Business--Operations and Service Offerings--Debt Collection--Surveillance Phase.''
Collection Costs and Operational Efficiency
Optimizing debtor contact at each stage of the collection life cycle is the key to our debt collection strategy. Our debt collection process is standardized and automated, with the goal of maximizing the total amount collected over the life of the debt through sustainable payment plans or affordable settlements achieved through an amicable and solution-oriented collection approach rather than exploiting short-term collection potential. We benefit when purchasing a portfolio since any effects resulting from allocating additional resources and cost to collect to such portfolio is attributed to us, whereas in debt collection the additional resources and cost merely produce a marginal increase in commissions and in many cases require our client to accept a higher commission in order for us to benefit from the additional revenue generated. Debt purchase does not require our client to take this risk, but the client can anyway realize some of the benefit by receiving an attractive price level.
Costs representing 18% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2013 were variable, i.e., attributable to phone, postage and packaging, print, temporary staff, legal fee cost, travel and consulting fees (compared to 20% for the year ended December 31, 2012 and 22% for the year ended December 31, 2011). The decrease in variable costs as a percentage of revenue during the years ended December 31, 2011 to 2013 was due largely to the decline in our collection cost ratio as discussed below. The ratio of variable costs to revenue for the six months ended June 30, 2014 was 17% (compared to 18% for the six months ended June 30, 2013). Our fixed costs are limited almost entirely to office accommodation, permanent staff, data platform, compliance and IT infrastructure expenses, providing us with scalability with a low level of incremental overhead costs. Our fixed costs as a percentage of revenue increased during the years ended December 31, 2011 to 2013 in line with the corresponding decrease in variable costs, primarily due to increased permanent staff costs and increased rent costs resulting primarily from our acquisition of Collection Platforms.
81

Certain of our collection costs in a given period are largely variable because they are primarily driven by collection activity performed in such period. Such costs mainly comprise temporary staff, legal fees (including bailiffs), phone, postage and packaging, debtor information services, travel and consulting fees and commissions to external debt collectors. We use external debt collectors in cases where we have purchased portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables that were already outsourced by the debt originator to the external debt collector, and thus it is more efficient in our view to retain this relationship. The aggregate commissions we pay to external debt collectors vary period-on-period. Our collection cost ratio for debt collection services decreased from 61% for the year ended December 31, 2011 to 59% for the year ended December 31, 2013, and from 57% for the six months ended June 30, 2013 to 59% for the six months ended June 30, 2014. The decrease in our collection cost ratio for debt collection services was mainly driven by increased scale as we managed to increase the number of third-party portfolios serviced while controlling our investment in collection resources. Our collection cost ratio for debt purchases increased from 22% for the year ended December 31, 2011 to 29% for the year ended December 31, 2013, and from 29% for the six months ended June 30, 2013 to 31% for the six months ended June 30, 2014. This increase in our collection cost ratio for debt purchases was mainly due to the increase in commission rates charged by our debt collection department for servicing our purchased portfolios, particularly in Germany and Spain as these countries' share of our total gross collection increased during the period.

Year-on-year trends in our collection cost ratio are not necessarily indicative of our operational efficiency and the return on capital we can achieve on purchased portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables, as they are impacted by the varying characteristics of the portfolios we purchase in different years and differences in the timing of portfolio purchases during the year. Specifically, we believe that recent trends in our collection cost ratio have been driven by: (i) significant improvements in the operational efficiency of our collections team, primarily due to our implementation of more efficient collection methods, such as text messages and other automated processes, and a well-balanced level of operating expenses; and (ii) changes in the volume, mix and timing of portfolio purchases in each year.
Operational efficiency is key to our business model and a main advantage of our business compared to competitors and financial institutions and other customer companies who handle their debt collection in-house. We begin the debt collection process by segmenting or scoring debtors according to the predicted likelihood that they will pay, based on criteria such as past payment history, size and type of debt, debtors' age and gender and whether the debt was incurred by a consumer or a business. We thereafter determine which collection method to use for the specific claim, such as calls, letters, text messages, emails and to some extent personal visits by agents, depending on various factors, including the geographical market, the claim size, the client we are acting on behalf of, the applicable laws and regulations and the individual debtor. We believe that we are able to lower collection costs due to our large scale and automation of the debt collection process and we are able to increase recovery rates through our data assets and analytical capabilities to optimally tailor debt collection strategies based on

82

past experiences. As a result, we believe that we can optimize collection efficiency over the lifetime of the claim. In December 31, 2013, our revenue per FTE employed in operations was approximately e214,500, and in the period from June 30, 2013 to June 30, 2014, our revenue per FTE employed in operations grew from approximately e107,000 to approximately e110,000.
We have systematically carried out projects that have had, and that we believe will continue to have, a positive effect on our operations. We have divested a number of non-core activities and smaller businesses during the periods under review. We sold Mirror Accounting Group in Norway in January 2013 and our 50% share in M.G. De Jong Bailiff Service in the Netherlands and Bu¨rgel Group in Germany in December 2013. The divested entities provided accounting services, bailiff services and information and scoring services, respectively. We recognized a net loss of e0.5 million from these sales. In addition, during the periods under review and concluded in 2013, we have restructured our organization in certain countries, such as Germany, Spain, the Netherlands and Sweden, with the aim of realizing cost reductions. This has been done, for example, by means of termination of leaseholds and relocation projects, leading to an improved quality of our operations, as well as an efficiency program that reduced the number of FTEs. Other projects include the shift to process-driven collection to ensure that all claims are being initiated, prioritized and worked on in time and that no claims are left unallocated pending resolution of prior claims, a process which we began in Norway and now have migrated into our other jurisdictions. These projects have also focused on maximizing collection and enhancing revenue by establishing ``big ticket'' teams, for example in Sweden and Germany, that specialize in resolving larger debt claims instead of leaving these claims in the regular workflow. We are currently in the process of implementing the Lindorff Group Collection System, which aims to increase our efficiency in managing our country-specific collection systems. In addition, we have systematically worked to improve our basic IT infrastructure, and have moved from operating a unique IT platform in each local operation to having one IT infrastructure platform, operated by our IT outsourcing provider, which services all of our local operations. We believe that over time we will be able to realize savings in our IT costs through the outsourcing of our IT platform.
Seasonality
The timing of our purchases of portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables is likely to be uneven during a financial year and from year to year due to fluctuating supply and demand within the market, with a corresponding impact on leverage and earnings. During the periods under review, we have generally purchased more portfolios, measured by purchase price, in the fourth quarter (when debt originators in general, and financial institutions in particular, often seek to sell assets) compared to each of the first three quarters. For example, in the fourth quarters of 2013 and 2011, we purchased portfolios for e35 million and e58 million, respectively, as compared to total portfolio purchases of e154 million and e117 million in the full years of 2013 and 2011, respectively. However, there may be exceptions in certain years where purchases of major individual portfolios are made in other parts of the year, such as in 2012, when we purchased only 20.3% of our portfolios in the fourth quarter, and our interim results for any given quarter may be impacted by the timing of the closing of a specific portfolio purchase. We believe that the fourth quarter will likely continue to be the most important quarter for financial institutions' management of their financial positions and thus when portfolio purchase levels will be highest. However, we believe that the impact on our operations may be lower going forward, given that claims purchased under forward flow agreements and smaller transactions (below e10,000,000) are expected to account for over 60% of portfolio acquisitions in 2014, which is in line with 2013, but indicates a higher share than 2012 due to the large transaction in Germany in 2012. In addition, the ECB Asset Quality Review, various stress tests and the increased importance of quarterly reporting in the financial calendars of larger institutions, may also result in a more even flow of sales throughout the year. Our interim results for a given quarter may also be impacted by seasonal factors, such as whether Easter occurs in the first or second quarter of the year.
Debt collection is also highly affected by seasonal factors related to debtors, including the number of work days in a given month, the propensity of debtors to take holidays at particular times of the year and annual cycles in disposable income. Collections within portfolios tend to have high seasonal variances, while our costs are more evenly spread out over the year, resulting in high variances of margins and profitability between quarters. Our margins are generally lower in the first quarter, whereas our collections will be seasonally higher in the second and fourth quarters of the year, due to debtors' receipt of tax refunds, holiday bonus payments and other factors.
83

Acquisitions and Geographic Expansion
We have a strong track record of expanding into new markets and making strategic acquisitions. We have been able to successfully integrate new businesses into our existing operations, achieve our strategic plans and leverage our strong client relationships to acquire businesses and assets from some of the largest financial institutions in Europe. We have focused on acquiring collection platforms divested by financial institutions, meaning that we have taken on entire collection functions from these institutions, including employees and debt collection services contracts and, in some instances, also portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables (``Collection Platforms''). In connection with acquiring Collection Platforms, we often also enter into a long-term service agreement to provide debt collection services to the financial institution selling the Collection Platform. These acquisitions have allowed us to enhance our business intelligence capabilities and local collection knowledge and generate steady streams of revenue. The value of the assets of the Collection Platforms is allocated to our consolidated statement of financial position as assets, and the residual purchase price is allocated as an intangible asset and amortized during the stipulated contract period. Acquisitions made during the periods under review were carried out to enter into new geographic markets, enter into long-term debt collection services agreements with specific financial institutions and complete a value chain, for example by establishing a local platform to better service a particular market. Expanding into a new geographic market may affect our overall balance between debt collection services and debt purchase, should the new market be particularly focused on one of these business areas. Geographic expansion may also serve to diverse our business and enhance our ability to manage the overall balance between debt collection services and debt purchase.
We acquired Collection Platforms for a total purchase price of e82 million during the periods under review. We believe that our acquisition track record is unrivalled in the European CMS industry. Specifically, during the periods under review, we made four acquisitions of significant scale:
· On January 7, 2011, we acquired 100% of the ordinary share capital in the debt collection company Reintegra Contact Center S.L., a subsidiary of Santander Group in Spain. The acquisition also included a number of portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables.
· On March 2, 2012, we acquired 100% of the ordinary share capital in the debt collection company Reintegra Comercial Espan~a S.A., a subsidiary of Santander Group in Spain. In connection with the acquisition, we entered into a long-term service agreement with Santander Group to carry out part of its debt collection.
· On December 1, 2012, we acquired 100% of the ordinary share capital in the debt collection company Solveon Incasso B.V., a subsidiary of ABN AMRO Bank N.V. in the Netherlands.
· On November 29, 2013, we acquired the assets of a collection business unit from Banco Mare Nostrum, S.A. in Spain. In connection with the acquisition, we entered into a long-term service agreement with Banco Mare Nostrum, S.A. to carry out part of its debt collection.
We expect to continue to selectively pursue potential acquisitions to expand our geographic footprint and to increase our market share in countries where we already operate. See ``Our Business--Our Strategy'' and ``--Recent Developments.''
Economic Conditions
The economic and market conditions in the countries in which we operate can have various effects on our operations. For example, adverse economic conditions and increased levels of unemployment may lead to higher default rates on claims, which in turn may increase the stock of portfolios available for us to purchase and positively impact our prospects of purchasing portfolios and Collection Platforms with attractive returns. Similarly, negative economic developments may increase the amount of debt and other overdue receivables possessed by our debt collection clients, thereby potentially increasing the number of claims outsourced to us for collection. If adverse economic conditions materially reduce the ability of debtors to repay their debts, our revenue from both debt collection services and debt purchase could decrease. Adverse economic conditions could also reduce debt originators' propensity to sell overdue receivables at the prices prevailing in the market, thereby decreasing the volume of portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables available for us to purchase and, thereafter, sales by debt originators could increase as they seek to sell portfolios in order to free up capital, thereby increasing the volume of debt and other overdue receivables available for us to purchase. This trend has been evident in the latest cycle; the global financial crisis in 2008 and 2009 led to dramatic slowdowns in purchases of portfolios
84

across our markets followed by a significant increase during the periods under review as debt originators sought to free up capital. Unfavorable economic conditions may also impact our ability to obtain funding and thereby our ability to purchase portfolios.
Improved economic conditions are likely to lower default rates on loans, which could negatively impact the growth of the stock of portfolios available for us to purchase, as well as decrease the amount of debt and other overdue receivables possessed by our debt collection clients, which would negatively impact our debt collection services. Generally, gross collection levels improve in times of decreased levels of unemployment. As a result, positive economic conditions could also be beneficial as they would enable debtors to increase repayments and enable debtors who were previously unable to pay their debts to have new payment plans arranged, thus increasing our revenue from both debt collection services and debt purchase. Positive economic conditions may also increase the underlying credit stock, driven by higher private consumption and continued low interest rates, in turn driving the amounts of consumer credits.
In our markets during the periods under review, Spain was one of the countries hardest struck by the financial turmoil and the Netherlands experienced lower growth and spending than expected, whereas Germany and the Nordic region, particularly Norway and Sweden, have improved and generally remained stable. Based on our analysis of the Company Market Study, we believe that overall macroeconomic conditions may recover over the next few years and that the overall net effect of this recovery would be positive for the CMS industry. See ``Our Business--Key Drivers of the CMS Industry-- Macroeconomic Recovery Improving Collection Rates.''
Regulatory Considerations
Our results of operations are affected by a number of laws and regulations in the jurisdictions in which we operate. We are subject to regulatory and compliance requirements relating to labor, license requirements, consumer credit, debt collection, default interest calculation, statutes of limitation, data protection, anti-corruption, tax and VAT, handling of client funds and other regulatory regimes. While regulations vary across jurisdictions, the general legal framework relevant for companies in the CMS industry is similar across the jurisdictions in which we operate. We have detailed policies and countryspecific procedures in place that are designed to ensure that we operate in compliance with applicable law and that compliance issues, if any, are identified and appropriately elevated within the organization. Our policy regarding regulatory compliance defines, among other things, governing principles regarding identification of governing laws and regulations, delegation of compliance responsibilities, guidelines on education and competence, testing and documentation of regulatory compliance control measures.
In each of the countries in which we currently have local operations, with the exception of Finland, we are able to extend the statutes of limitation on historic debt claims indefinitely (in Germany during court proceedings and for a period of 30 years thereafter) by taking legal actions or by notifying the debtor or otherwise interrupting the limitation period, and in Finland statute barring only applies to claims that are more than 15 years old. Any new laws or regulations that may be adopted, as well as changes to existing laws or regulations, in the jurisdictions in which we operate could constrain or prevent our ability to operate. For example, in 2008 when the 15 year statute of limitation entered into force in Finland, we implemented additional collection strategies to mitigate the negative effect of this change, such as intensified settlement campaigns for claims close to the 15 year limitation date, legal activities earlier in the collection process and continue to seek voluntary payments subsequent to the expiration of the 15 year limitation period. Furthermore, in the periods under review the amount of collection fees we are permitted to charge debtors in Finland and Norway were reduced through new legislation, which triggered re-negotiations of some of our client contracts, however, without having a material impact on our business. Conversely, new laws or regulations that may be adopted, as well as changes to, or the enforcement of, existing laws or regulations, could also have a positive impact on our business, as was the case in Sweden, where the collection fees we are permitted to charge debtors were increased as a result of new legislation in 2013 and 2014. See ``Regulations.''
Foreign Currency Effects
We currently have local operations in Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Latvia, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Norway, Russia, Spain and Sweden. Many of our subsidiaries transact business and report their financial results in currencies other than the euro, our consolidated reporting currency. Accordingly,
85

our results of operations are subject to currency effects, primarily currency translation exposure. Transaction-related exposure at our subsidiaries is limited because revenue and costs are largely incurred in their respective operating currencies. In addition, funding of our operations from our credit facility is drawn in local currencies and aligned with the portfolios purchased. For those countries with a reporting currency other than euro, profits and losses are translated into euro at average exchange rates, and assets and liabilities are translated into euro at closing exchange rates. Fluctuations in exchange rates against the euro result in period-on-period differences in our results of operations and can obscure period-on-period comparisons, for example between the quarterly results of two different years. For the year ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, 51%, 58% and 66%, respectively, of our revenue was reported by entities whose functional currencies are different than the euro, primarily Norwegian kroner, Swedish kronor and Danish kroner, which accounted for 34%, 12% and 4%, respectively, of our revenue in 2013, 36%, 15% and 5%, respectively, of our revenue in 2012 and 43%, 17% and 5%, respectively, of our revenue in 2011. For the six months ended June 30, 2014 and 2013, 50% and 51%, respectively, of our revenue was reported by entities whose functional currencies are different than the euro, primarily Danish kroner, Norwegian kroner and Swedish kronor, which accounted for 4%, 31% and 14%, respectively, of our revenue in the six months ended June 30, 2014 and 4%, 34% and 13%, respectively, of our revenue in the six months ended June 30, 2013. As a significant portion of our revenue and results of operations in Norway is linked to debt collection, fluctuations in the exchange rate between Norwegian kroner and euro can have a disproportionate effect on our debt collection revenue. We are expanding our operations in existing markets, as well as considering growth opportunities in new markets, mainly where euro is the operating currency and thus we expect the impact of foreign currency translation to be moderate as we grow further.
Tax Effects
The statutory corporate tax rate in Sweden for 2013, 2012 and 2011 was 22%, 26.3% and 26.3%, respectively. Our effective tax rate was lower due primarily to the interest paid on the Subordinated Loans (excluding the one-off effect in 2013 of a settlement with the Norwegian tax authorities described below). Loans of this type and size are regularly used by investment company and private equity owners to structure their investments and to provide funding to their portfolio companies. Following the conversion of part of the Subordinated Loans to equity in 2013 to restore the equity level in the Company, as well as due to the conversion of certain loans to equity in Norway following the tax settlement described below and due to new regulation in Norway and other countries, our taxes payable increased, which in turn impacted our effective tax rate. Our results may also be impacted by one-off tax payments, such as the e13 million settlement reached with the Norwegian tax authorities related to the interpretation of historic tax deductions of interest on internal group loans for the years 2008 through 2012. Our effective tax rate for the six months ended June 30, 2014 was 26%.
Recent Developments
On July 28, 2014, we agreed to acquire a collection unit from Banco Sabadell in Spain for a purchase price of e162,000,000. As part of the proposed transaction, the acquired unit will enter into a 10-year service agreement with the seller to perform debt collection services on its portfolio of existing and future debt and overdue receivables. Closing of the acquisition is expected to occur in the fourth quarter and will be subject to regulatory clearance (if applicable) and certain other customary closing conditions. The potential transaction is fully in line with our European strategy executed to date. We believe that the transaction would be accretive to our profile and our operating cash generation. The financing for this transaction will depend on several factors, including the timing for completion of this transaction in relation to the Completion Date, and is expected to be funded through a combination of sources, including potentially additional equity contributions by Nordic Capital Fund VIII, Altor and Investor and debt incurrence, including vendor financing secured by certain assets of the acquired business.
Recognition of Purchased Portfolios, Revenue Recognition, Estimation of Cash Flow Forecasts and Revaluation of Purchased Portfolios
The following sections describe how the IFRS accounting under the amortized cost methodology recognizes the carrying value of purchased portfolios in our consolidated statement of financial position, and the returns generated through debt collections on such portfolios in our consolidated income statement. These IFRS measures are derived from a number of other measures that are not defined in
86

IFRS and which involve a higher degree of judgment or complexity, including EIR and ERC, and these are areas where assumptions and estimates are significant to the consolidated financial statements.
Recognition of Purchased Portfolios
Purchased debt consists mainly of portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables purchased at prices significantly below the nominal face value and which are recognized according to IAS 39 for loans and receivables, i.e., at amortized cost using the effective interest method. According to the effective interest method, the carrying value of each portfolio corresponds to the present value of estimated gross future cash flows discounted by an EIR determined on the date the portfolio was purchased. The initial EIR is based on the relation between purchase cost and the projected future cash flows on the purchase date.
With the projection of future gross cash flows and the purchase price including transaction costs as a basis, each portfolio is assigned an initial EIR that exactly discounts estimated future cash payments or receipts through the expected life of the financial instrument or, when appropriate, a shorter period to the net carrying amount of the financial asset or financial liability at the time of purchase of the portfolio based upon estimated debt collections over the next 180 months that is then used to discount expected cash flows through the life of the portfolio. Portfolios with higher decay are estimated to have collections close to zero over the last few years of the life of the portfolio. If appropriate, the EIR is reassessed and adjusted up to 12 months after the purchase of the portfolio to reflect refinements made to our estimates of future cash flows based on enhanced data and analysis considered during that time period. This adjustment has historically not resulted in any material impact on our income from purchased portfolios.
Current cash flow projections are monitored over the course of the year and updated based on, among other things, achieved collection results and agreements reached with debtors on instalment plans. Cash flow projections are made at portfolio level. If the cash flow estimates are revised, the carrying amount is recalculated to reflect revised estimated cash flows by computing the present value of estimated future cash flows using the initial effective interest rate. An adjustment in the carrying amount is recognized in net revenue.
Changes over time in the book value can be divided into a time and interest rate component and a component related to changes in estimates of future cash flows. Changes in cash flow forecasts are treated symmetrically, i.e., both increases and decreases in forecast flows affect the portfolios' book value and, as a result, net revenue. The value of a portfolio is gradually amortized during the course of the expected life of the portfolio, leaving a carrying value of e0 at the end of the rolling ERC investment horizon.
From time to time, we also purchase portfolios on a forward flow basis. In a forward flow agreement, we agree to buy claims at a pre-defined price or price range for a given volume and quality from a client on an ongoing basis. Claims under forward flow agreements can be delivered on weekly, monthly or quarterly basis and the EIR of these claims is calculated per contract and used for each delivery of claims. If experience indicates a change in the attributes of claims under a specific agreement, we may decide to apply a new EIR for future claims. Each delivery under a forward flow agreement is treated as an individual portfolio purchase, using its own purchase cost and the pre-determined EIR. For reporting purposes, all individual deliveries under a forward flow agreement are added to the overall portfolio as an incremental purchase. These claims can therefore be assessed both by delivery and by portfolio. The ability to assess claims by delivery has the advantage that we can monitor performance more closely and react with corrective actions more quickly than would be the case if we could only assess claims by portfolio, in which case we would have to wait until any indication of non-performance would have an impact on the portfolio as a whole.
Recognition of Revenue from Purchased Portfolios
Revenue on portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables is accrued monthly based on each portfolio's EIR. Monthly cash flows that are greater than the cash flow forecast for the same period are recorded as an increase in revenue in the period. Conversely, monthly cash flows that are lower than the cash flow forecast for the same period are recorded as a reduction of revenue in the period. Compensation received from debt originators due to price adjustments made to purchased portfolios are recorded as an adjustment to the book value.
87

The table below sets forth an illustrative example of portfolio revenue recognition and change in portfolio carrying value under the EIR methodology under IFRS.

Estimation of Cash Flow Forecasts From Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables
The estimation of cash flow forecasts (i.e., ERC) is a key uncertainty within our policies on revenue recognition of purchased portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables. We establish estimates of cash flows that determine the EIR for each purchased portfolio. The estimates are based on our collection history with respect to portfolios comprising similar attributes and characteristics, such as date of purchase, debt originator, type of receivable, debtor payment histories, debtor location, and the time since the original charge-off, as well as on our experience and the existing schedule of repayment plans on the particular portfolio for which we are determining EIR.

88

Revaluation of Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables
At the end of each reporting period, currently every quarter, we evaluate portfolio forecasts to assess whether there is objective evidence that a portfolio should be subject to revaluation. Indications of negative revaluation may include a group of debtors experiencing significant financial difficulty, default of interest or principal payments, the probability that debtors will enter bankruptcy or other financial reorganization, and observable data indicating that there is a measurable decrease in the estimated future cash flows, such as changes in arrears or economic conditions that correlate with defaults. Conversely, there can also be positive revaluation in the event that a portfolio displays objective evidence of expected cash flows above the current forecast. During the periods under review, we have made one significant negative revaluation in Denmark in 2011, which resulted in a reduction of the carrying value of certain portfolios in the aggregate amount of e4.9 million.
We revalue the portfolios based on the rolling ERC at the revaluation date. The local management in the countries where we have operations regularly review and follow up on the portfolios. Group management carries out quarterly reviews of all portfolios with actual debt collection deviating more than 25% and e100,000 from forecasts during the last six months (cumulative). Management will also review portfolios that do not meet these thresholds, but that have been nominated for formal review by local management based on their regular review of portfolios. This structure aims to ensure that portfolios performing significantly outside of forecast will be reviewed by management. A formal review meeting is required prior to adjusting forecasts. The outcome of the review meeting may be: (i) adjustment of the forecast, which will influence the carrying value of the portfolio in our statement of financial position and the revenue in our income statement; and/or (ii) in cases of underperforming portfolios, a decision to implement actions or measures to increase the performance of the portfolio and to review the portfolio again at the next review meeting.

Key Operating Metrics for Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables
During the periods under review, we have experienced significant growth in our asset base and cash flow generation, which we believe is the result of: (i) the growing volume of portfolios we have been able to purchase; (ii) our pricing discipline; and (iii) the efficiency and sophistication of our debt collection operations.

As described under ``--Revenue Recognition, Revaluation of Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables and Estimation of Cash Flow Forecasts,'' the IFRS consolidated statement of financial position carrying value of purchased portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables is based on our latest ERC forecast for our owned portfolios. ERC growth over time is primarily due to portfolio purchases; as we collect on existing portfolios, the ERC on these portfolios will decline. During the periods under review, there have not been any material changes in forecast expectations at the overall portfolio level. Our ERC on purchased portfolios grew from e1,292 million as of December 31, 2011 to e1,891 million as of June 30, 2014. Based on our models, as of June 30, 2014, we estimate that the aggregate face value of purchased portfolios of e15 billion would generate approximately e1,891 million in gross collections over the next 180 months. We expect to receive 16.4% of these collections during the period from July 1, 2014 to June 30, 2015 and 29.9% of these collections during the period from July 1, 2014 to June 30, 2016. These expectations are based on historical data as well as assumptions about future collection rates. We can provide no assurances that we will achieve such collections within the specified time periods, if at all.

Returns on Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables
While returns achieved on an individual portfolio can vary, we have a consistent record of unlevered returns on our aggregate purchased portfolios. We have experienced increased gross cash-on-cash multiples as portfolios mature. The table below sets forth certain data related to our purchased portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables by vintage, such as purchase price, collections, ERC and gross

cash-on-cash multiple as of June 30, 2014. It demonstrates our ability to continue to extract value from our purchased portfolios over a long period of time.
