Description of Principal Consolidated Statement of Financial Position Line Items The following is a discussion of our key consolidated statement of financial position line items.

Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables
Purchased debt consists mainly of portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables purchased at prices significantly below the nominal face value and which are recognized at amortized cost using the effective interest method. The carrying value of each portfolio corresponds to the present value of estimated gross future cash flows discounted by an EIR. The initial EIR is based on the relation between purchase cost and the projected future cash flows on the date of purchase.

92

Description of Principal Income Statement Line Items The following is a discussion of our key income statement line items.
Revenue Revenue consists mainly of fees from debtors, fees and commissions from clients relating to third-party debt collection services and revenue on purchased portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables accrued monthly based on each portfolio's EIR. Changes in collection estimates resulting in a change in the carrying value of purchased portfolios and cash collections in the period in excess of, or below, the forecast for the period are also included here. The effects of the last two elements have been low historically. Purchases of portfolios increase our collections, although there may be a time lag between the date of purchase of the portfolio and the increase in collections resulting from the purchase of such portfolio, thus resulting in turnover being realized in a period subsequent to that of the portfolio purchase. Collections on existing portfolios tend to decrease as the portfolio age.
Other Income Other income includes gain from the sale of subsidiaries.
Employee Benefit Expense Employee benefit expense includes salary and other employee related expenses, such as vacation accruals, social security taxes and pension costs.
Legal Fee Cost We incur outlays for bailiff/court fees, summons, legal representation and enforcement authorities, which generally can be charged to and collected from debtors. Such outlays are expensed when incurred (even though collections are generated in subsequent periods), except in certain cases where we have agreements with our clients that any expenses that cannot be collected from the debtor are instead refunded by the client. In these cases, the amount that is expected to be recovered from the client is recognized as an asset in the statement of financial position.
Phone, Postage and Packaging Phone, postage and packaging includes costs related to sending collection letters, text messages and other communications in connection with establishing contact with debtors in the collection process.
Other Operating Costs Other operating costs consist primarily of costs related to premises, external IT services, debtor information services, commissions to external debt collectors, travel and consulting fees.
Depreciation and Amortization Depreciation and amortization includes the depreciation of tangible fixed assets and amortization of intangible assets for the relevant period, based on the expected economic useful life of the assets.
Finance Income Finance income includes interest on bank accounts.
Finance Costs Finance costs consist primarily of interest on loans from financial institutions, interest expense on shareholder loans, changes in market value on interest swaps and foreign exchange losses.
Income Tax Expense The tax expense comprises current and deferred tax. The current income tax charge is calculated on the basis of the tax laws enacted or substantively enacted at the balance sheet date in the countries where we operate and generate taxable income. Tax positions are periodically evaluated and positions taken in
93

tax returns with respect to situations in which applicable tax regulation is subject to interpretation. It establishes provisions where appropriate on the basis of amounts expected to be paid to the tax authorities.
Current tax assets and liabilities for the current and prior periods are measured at the amount expected to be recovered from or paid to the taxation authorities. Deferred income tax is provided using the liability method on temporary differences at the balance sheet date between the tax basis of assets and liabilities and their carrying amounts for financial reporting purposes.

Results of Operations
Consolidated Statement of Financial Position as of June 30, 2014 Compared to December 31, 2013
Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables
Our purchased portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables increased by e86 million, or 12.6%, from e675 million as of December 31, 2013 to e760 million as of June 30, 2014. The increase was driven primarily by our investment in portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, our purchased portfolios increased by e90 million, or 13.3%, as of June 30, 2014 compared to December 31, 2013. The increase in our portfolios was driven by investments in portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables of e144 million in the six months ended on June 30, 2014, offset by amortization of portfolios in the amount of e55 million.

Consolidated Income Statement for the Six Months Ended June 30, 2014 Compared to the Six Months Ended June 30, 2013

(1) Finance costs consists of interest on loans from financial institutions, fair value gains and losses on financial derivatives (interest swaps), interest expense on the Subordinated Loans, net financial exchange gains/(losses) on financing activities, write down of investments in associated companies and other financial expenses. Revenue
Our revenue was stable at e226 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2014. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, which primarily

94

impacted revenue in Norway and Sweden, our revenue increased by e8 million, or 3.9%, in the six months ended June 30, 2014 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2013. The increase was driven by the acquisition of a debt collection contract in Spain, several portfolio purchases--most notably in Spain and Denmark--and positive effects of certain operational improvements. The operational improvements consisted of site consolidations in Sweden, the Netherlands and Germany and asset segmentation, in which we segmented our portfolios into ``buckets'', such as non-payers, ``big tickets'' and recent payers, and thereby increased collection efficiency.
The table below sets forth, for each of the periods indicated, our operating revenue by segment, both in euro and as a percentage of consolidated revenue, and the percentage increase or decrease in operating revenue by segment from period to period. (1) Eastern and Central Europe consist of Finland, Russia, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania whereof the share of the regions total revenue in Russia was 2.3% for the six months ended June 30, 2014 (compared to 0.6% as of June 30, 2013).
Employee Benefit Expense
Our employee benefit expense decreased by e3 million, or 3.2%, from e85 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e82 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. As a percentage of revenue, employee benefit expense decreased from 37.4% in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to 36.3% in the six months ended June 30, 2014. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, employee benefit expense increased by e0.4 million, or 0.5%, in the six months ended June 30, 2014 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2013. The increase was driven by salary increases and partially offset by FTE reductions.
Legal Fee Cost
Our legal fee cost decreased by e0.6 million, or 3.3%, from e17.7 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e17.1 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. As a percentage of revenue, legal

95

fee cost decreased from 7.8% in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to 7.6% in the six months ended June 30, 2014. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, legal fee cost increased by e0.4 million, or 2.3%, in the six months ended June 30, 2014 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2013. The increase was driven by increased volume and activity level, which affected our legal fee cost as a larger portion of claims moved into the legal phase.
Phone, Postage and Packaging
Our phone, postage and packaging expense decreased by e0.1 million, or 1.5%, from e9.5 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e9.3 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. As a percentage of revenue, phone, postage and packaging expense decreased from 4.2% in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to 4.1% in the six months ended June 30, 2014. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, phone, postage and packaging expense increased by e0.2 million, or 2.5%, in the six months ended June 30, 2014 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2013. The increase was driven by increased volume.
Other Operating Costs
Our other operating costs increased by e2 million, or 5.5%, from e39 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e41 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. As a percentage of revenue, other operating costs increased from 17.2% in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to 18.2% in the six months ended June 30, 2014. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, other operating costs increased by e4 million, or 9.7%, in the six months ended June 30, 2014 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2013. The increase was mainly due to an increase in commissions paid to external debt collectors, which we incur when we purchase a portfolio already outsourced to a third-party collection company and we determine that it is the most efficient to maintain this outsourcing relationship.
Depreciation and Amortization
Depreciation and amortization increased by e2.7 million, or 65.3%, from e4.1 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e6.7 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. As a percentage of revenue, depreciation and amortization increased from 1.8% in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to 3.0% in the six months ended June 30, 2014. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, depreciation and amortization increased by e2.8 million, or 71.7%, in the six months ended June 30, 2014 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2013. The increase was due to amortization of the collection contract acquired in Spain.
Net Finance Costs
Our net finance costs decreased by e45 million, or 51.2%, from e88 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e43 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. The decrease was primarily attributable to a reduction in the interest expenses on shareholder loans of e 27.5 million, or 64.2%, following the conversion of a portion of the Subordinated Loans from debt to equity, and a decrease in the underlying interest rates applicable to our credit facilities.
Income Tax Expense
Our income tax expense increased by e10 million, from a negative expense of e3 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to an expense of e7 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014, due to the improvement in our operating profit in the six months ended June 30, 2014.
Net Profit/(Loss) for the Period
We recognized a net loss of e14 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 and a net profit of e20 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014.
Consolidated Statement of Financial Position as of December 31, 2013 Compared to December 31, 2012
Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables
Our purchased portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables increased by e17 million, or 2.6%, from e658 million as of December 31, 2012 to e675 million as of December 31, 2013. Excluding the effect of
96

foreign currency translation, our purchased portfolios increased by e33 million, or 5.2%, as of December 31, 2013 compared to December 31, 2012. The increase in our portfolios was driven primarily by portfolio purchases of e154 million, offset by amortization of portfolios in the amount of e116 million and the put back (meaning a forced repurchase by the seller e.g., due to inaccurate information having been provided by the seller in relation to the original purchase) of a portfolio in Spain in the amount of e5 million.

Consolidated Income Statement for the Year Ended December 31, 2013 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2012

Revenue
Our revenue increased by e22 million, or 5.2%, from e425 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e447 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, our revenue increased by e28 million, or 6.9%, in the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was driven by the increase of the number of third-party portfolios serviced by our debt collection teams and increased collection on our purchased portfolios as a result of acquisitions of Collection Platforms and portfolio purchases, as well as a full year of collections being carried out on the significant portfolios purchased throughout 2012. Spain experienced very strong growth due to several portfolio purchases and Collection Platform acquisitions coupled with outsourcing agreements. Our Dutch and German operations also grew considerably due to acquisitions of Collection Platforms and portfolios. Our underlying revenue growth in the Nordic region has been stable. However, headline numbers show a slight decline due to the effects of discontinued operations. On an underlying basis, we have experienced stable growth in Finland and Norway, while revenue has declined in Sweden and Denmark due largely to restructuring initiatives, largely the closure of certain non-core operations.

5.2

(1) Eastern Europe consists of Russia, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania whereof the share of the region's total revenue in Russia was 1% for the year ended December 31, 2013 and 2% for the year ended December 31, 2012.
Employee Benefit Expense
Our employee benefit expense increased by e3 million, or 1.8%, from e167 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e170 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. As a percentage of revenue, employee benefit expense decreased from 39.3% in the year ended December 31, 2012 to 38.0% in the year ended December 31, 2013. The increase was driven by restructuring costs incurred in connection with the restructuring of our organization with the aim of realizing cost reductions and the related closure of certain non-core operations in Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands, as well as the acquisition of Solveon Incasso B.V. in the Netherlands in December 2012, which increased our FTEs. The increase was offset by the execution of an efficiency initiative that reduced the number of FTEs, the early effects of which were realized towards the end of 2013. Employee benefit expense as a percentage of revenue, however, decreased as we maintained control of our employee benefit expense despite the expansion of our business.
Legal Fee Cost
Our legal fee cost increased by e0.5 million, or by 1.4%, from e34.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e34.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. As a percentage of revenue, legal fee cost decreased from 8.1% in the year ended December 31, 2012 to 7.8% in the year ended December 31, 2013. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, legal fee cost increased by e1.4 million, or 4.2%, in the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was driven by the continued growth of our business, including an increase in portfolio purchases in the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to the year ended December 31,

98

2012, and increased costs in Finland due to collection fees permitted to be charged to debtors being reduced through new legislation. See ``--Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations--Regulatory Considerations'' and ``Risk Factors--Risks Related to our Industry and Business--We are subject to regulations in the jurisdictions in which we operate and changes to the regulatory environments in which we operate or a failure to comply with applicable laws, regulations and codes of practice may negatively affect our business.'' Legal fee cost as a percentage of revenue, however, decreased as a result of an increase in the number of debtors that repaid their claims voluntarily without having to initiate legal proceedings.
Phone, Postage and Packaging
Our phone, postage and packaging expense remained stable at e19 million in the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to the year ended December 31, 2012. As a percentage of revenue, phone, postage and packaging expense decreased from 4.4% in the year ended December 31, 2012 to 4.1% in the year ended December 31, 2013. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, phone, postage and packaging expense also remained stable at e18 million in the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to the year ended December 31, 2012. The decrease as a percentage of revenue was driven by the implementation of more efficient collection methods, such as text messages and other automated processes, including the Group wide roll-out of automated collection systems, offset by the timing of purchases during 2012, with a number of portfolios purchased during the year closing in the fourth quarter, thus resulting in a large percentage of our costs for phone, postage and packaging following these purchases being incurred in 2013.
Other Operating Costs
Our other operating costs increased by e4 million, or 5.1%, from e79 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e83 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. As a percentage of revenue, other operating costs remained stable at 18.6% in the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to the year ended December 31, 2013. The increase was driven by additional facility rental charges and other restructuring costs incurred in connection with the restructuring of our operations, primarily in Germany, Spain and Sweden, and by additional IT costs incurred in connection with the transitioning of certain IT platforms to our IT outsourcing provider as part of the consolidation of all of our IT operations to one of the global datacenters of this provider. The increase was offset by lower consulting fees. Other operating costs as a percentage of revenue decreased, however, as we began to realize the benefits of the restructurings and the transitioning of our IT platforms.
Depreciation and Amortization
Depreciation and amortization increased by e1 million, or 13.5%, from e9 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e10 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. As a percentage of revenue, depreciation and amortization increased from 2.2% in the year ended December 31, 2012 to 2.3% in the year ended December 31, 2013. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, depreciation and amortization increased by e1 million, or 15.8%, in the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was driven by the acquisition of a Collection Platform in Spain, for which the part of the purchase price that exceeds the book value of the acquired assets is allocated to our consolidated statement of financial position as an intangible asset and amortized during the stipulated contract period.
Net Finance Costs
Our net finance costs decreased by e24 million, or 15.9%, from e151 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e127 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. The decrease was primarily attributable to a conversion of part of the Subordinated Loans to equity, amounting to e533 million, including accrued interest of e64 million. The conversion of the Subordinated Loans was carried out with effect from July 1, 2013, to restore the equity level in the Company.
Income Tax Expense
Our income tax expense increased by e36 million, from a negative expense of e15 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to an expense of e21 million in the year ended December 31, 2013, primarily
99

as a result of a e13 million settlement with the Norwegian tax authorities in 2013 related to tax deductions of interest on group internal loans for the years 2008-2012.

Net Profit/(Loss) for the Period
We recognized a net loss of e19 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 and a net loss of e18 million in the year ended December 31, 2013.

Consolidated Statement of Financial Position as of December 31, 2012 Compared to December 31, 2011
Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables
Our purchased portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables increased by e133 million, or 25.3%, from e525 million as of December 31, 2011 to e658 million as of December 31, 2012. The increase in our portfolios was driven by the purchase of a major portfolio from one of the largest financial institutions in Germany, which was the largest NPL portfolio we have purchased and was, we believe, at the time of the purchase the largest purchase of an unsecured NPL portfolio carried out in Europe in the ten years preceding the purchase. The increase was offset by amortization of portfolios in the amount of e113 million.

Consolidated Income Statement for the Year Ended December 31, 2012 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2011
The table below sets forth our results of operations and the period on period percentage of change for the periods indicated. Our revenue and operating expenses for the periods presented have been impacted by the sale of businesses.

Revenue
Our revenue increased by e39 million, or 10.1%, from e386 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e425 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was driven by the increase of the number of third-party portfolios serviced by our debt collection teams and the purchase of a major portfolio from one of the largest financial institutions in Germany. Spain experienced very strong growth due to several portfolio purchases and Collection Platform acquisitions coupled with outsourcing agreements. Our Dutch and German operations grew considerably due to acquisitions of Collection Platforms and portfolios. The increase was offset by a decline in revenue in the Nordic region, where increasing our debt collection market share is challenging due to our market leading position, as well as by pricing pressure in the debt purchase market. Our underlying revenue growth in the Nordic region

100

has been stable. However, headline numbers show a slight decline due to the effects of discontinued operations. On an underlying basis, we have experienced stable growth in Finland and Norway, while revenue has declined in Sweden and Denmark due largely to restructuring initiatives, largely the closure of certain non-core operations.

(2) Eastern Europe consists of Russia, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania whereof the share of the region's total revenue in Russia was 2% for the year ended December 31, 2012 and 1% for the year ended December 31, 2011.
Employee Benefit Expense
Our employee benefit expense increased by e11 million, or 7.1%, from e156 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e167 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. As a percentage of revenue, excluding other income, employee benefit expense decreased from 40.4% in the year ended December 31, 2011 to 39.3% in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was driven by the acquisition of Reintegra Comercial Espan~a S.A. in Spain. Employee benefit expense as a percentage of revenue, however, decreased as we maintained control of our employee benefit expense related to the growth generated by the acquisition of Reintegra Comercial Espan~a S.A, offset by a relatively high share of total FTEs (approximately 53%) being located in the Nordic region, where employee expenses are higher and thus even modest salary growth has significant impact on total employee benefit expense.

101

Legal Fee Cost
Our legal fee cost decreased by e1 million, or 1.9%, from e35 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e34 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. As a percentage of revenue, legal fee cost decreased from 8.7% in the year ended December 31, 2011 to 8.1% in the year ended December 31, 2012. The decrease was driven by an increase in the number of debtors that repaid their claims voluntarily without us having to initiate legal proceedings.
Phone, Postage and Packaging
Our phone, postage and packaging expense increased by e1 million, or 4.0%, from e18 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e19 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. As a percentage of revenue, phone, postage and packaging expense decreased from 4.5% in the year ended December 31, 2011 to 4.4% in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was driven by an increase in portfolio purchases in the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to the year ended December 31, 2011, as we incur a large percentage of our costs for phone, postage and packaging during the booking-on phase immediately following a portfolio purchase. Phone, postage and packaging expense as a percentage of revenue, however, decreased as a result of the implementation of more efficient collection methods, such as text messages and other automated processes.
Other Operating Costs
Our other operating costs increased by e12 million, or 17.9%, from e67 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e79 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. As a percentage of revenue, excluding other income, other operating costs increased from 17.4% in the year ended December 31, 2011 to 18.6% in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was driven by increased IT costs incurred in preparation of the outsourcing of our IT platform and by an increase in commission fees to external debt collectors related to the purchase in March 2012 of a major portfolio from one of the largest financial institutions in Germany, offset by lower consulting fees.
Depreciation and Amortization
Depreciation and amortization remained stable at e9 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to the year ended December 31, 2011. As a percentage of revenue, depreciation and amortization decreased from 2.3% in the year ended December 31, 2011 to 2.2% in the year ended December 31, 2012.
Net Finance Costs
Our net finance costs increased by e5 million, or 3.4%, from e146 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e151 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was primarily attributable to the increase in utilization of our credit facility.
Income Tax Expense
Our income tax expense decreased by e8 million, from a negative expense of e7 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to a negative expense of e15 million in the year ended December 31, 2012, primarily as a result of additional recognition of tax losses carried forward in Sweden.
Net Profit/(Loss) for the Period
We recognized a net loss of e24 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 and a net loss of e19 million in the year ended December 31, 2012.
Results of Operations on a Segment Basis
We have determined our operating segments based on the information we review for purposes of allocating our resources and assessing our performance. Revenue from external parties reported to our management is measured in a consistent manner in the income statement. We assess the performance of the operating segments based on a measure of ``Gross Contribution,'' which we define as total operating revenue of the segments less direct operating expenses of the segments, which include all direct costs related to the execution of collection processes and exclude costs related to IT and selling, general and administrative expense. Sales between segments are carried out at arm's length. For a
102

reconciliation of Gross Contribution on a segment basis to Group profit and loss before tax, see ``Note 5'' to our audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2013 included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.
Our inter-segment collection of debt is organized and allocated according to a blueprint model in one operational entity. Costs are allocated either to debt purchase or to debt collection according to actual resource consumption (``ABC costing'') or based on the number of FTEs involved. Our debt collection department services the portfolios we purchase. These services are charged based on actual resource consumption as if they were carried out between third parties, generating a reasonable profit for the debt collection segment. There are a number of Group IT projects and services that are organized as a shared function. These costs are charged to the segments in each country on an arm's length basis, applying segment or total revenue as allocation key. Costs for employees in our debt purchase department are booked in the debt purchase segment.

(1) Inter-segment revenue includes the revenue generated by our debt collection department from commission charged on debt collection services carried out on portfolios we purchase. The cost for this commission is recorded as a direct operating expense for our debt purchase department, together with certain other costs. These items are eliminated from the respective segments and recorded under eliminations and unallocated items.
(2) Direct operating expense includes all direct costs related to the execution of collection processes and excludes costs related to IT and selling, general and administrative expense.

Total Operating Revenue
An analysis of our revenue by segment is set forth below:
Debt collection: The operating revenue of our debt collection segment increased by e1 million, or 0.8%, from e157 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e158 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. The increase was driven by the acquisition of a collection contract in Spain, offset by currency effects in Norway and Sweden. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation and inter-

103

segment revenue, debt collection revenue from external customers increased by e2 million, or 1.7%, in the six months ended June 30, 2014 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2013.
Debt purchase: The operating revenue of our debt purchase segment increased by e4 million, or 4%, from e100 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e104 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation and revaluation of loans and receivables, debt purchase revenue from external customers increased by e6 million, or 6.0%, in the six months ended June 30, 2014 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2013. The increase was driven mainly by new investments in portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables and operational improvements.
Other services: Operating revenue from other services decreased by e1 million, or 11.1%, from e9 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e8 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. The increase was driven by negative currency effects in Norway and the sale of a subsidiary in Germany in December 2013.

Gross Contribution
An analysis of our Gross Contribution by segment is set forth below:
Debt collection: Our Gross Contribution for debt collection decreased by e2 million, or 3.0%, from e67 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e65 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. The decrease was driven by increased staff cost due to an increase in our FTEs and negative foreign currency effects. These were partly mitigated by the effects of operational improvements implemented in 2013, consisting of site consolidations in Sweden, the Netherlands and Germany and asset segmentation, in which we segmented our portfolios into ``buckets'', such as non-payers, ``big tickets'' and recent payers, and thereby increased collection efficiency. Our Gross Contribution margin (Gross Contribution as a percentage of total operating revenue) for debt collection decreased from 42.7% to 41.1% in the same period.
Debt purchase: Our Gross Contribution for debt purchase increased remained stable at e56.0 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2014. New investments in portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables and operational improvements, such as asset segmentation, were offset by increased commission rates in Sweden and the Netherlands. Our Gross Contribution margin for debt purchase decreased from 56.0% in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to 53.8% in the six months ended June 30, 2014.
Other services: Our Gross Contribution for other services decreased by e1 million, or 50%, from e2 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e1 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. The decrease was driven by negative currency effects in Norway and the sale of a subsidiary in Germany in December 2013, offset by improved performance of product offerings, particularly Invoice and Webinvoice.

(1) Inter-segment revenue includes the revenue generated by our debt collection department from commission charged on debt collection services carried out on portfolios we purchase. The cost for this commission is recorded as a direct operating expense for our debt purchase department, together with certain other costs. These items are eliminated from the respective segments and recorded under eliminations and unallocated items.

Total Operating Revenue
An analysis of our revenue by segment is set forth below:
Debt collection: The operating revenue of our debt collection segment increased by e22 million, or 7.6%, from e291 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e313 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation and inter-segment revenue, debt collection revenue from external customers increased by e21 million, or 11.9%, in the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was mainly driven by the increase of the number of third-party portfolios serviced, including as a result of our acquisition in December 2012 of Solveon Incasso B.V, which provided us with a solid footprint in the financial institutions sector in the Netherlands by acquiring a Collection Platform and entering into a long-term service agreement to provide debt collection services to a major Dutch financial institution. The increase was offset by decline in revenue in the Nordic region, where increasing our debt collection market share is challenging due to our market-leading position.
Debt purchase: The operating revenue of our debt purchase segment increased by e20 million, or 11.3%, from e179 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e200 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation and revaluation of loans and receivables, debt purchase revenue from external customers increased by e21 million, or 11.8%, in the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to the year ended December 31, 2012. While debt purchase revenue from external customers increased during the year, due primarily to increased collection on our portfolios and a full year of collections being carried out on the significant portfolios purchased throughout 2012, our growth in this area was offset by the timing of purchases during the year, with a number of portfolios purchased during the year closing in the fourth quarter, thus generating only limited revenue in 2013. The increase was also offset by pricing pressure driven partly by new market participants, for example in Spain, Finland and Germany, who were willing to purchase portfolios at estimated return on purchased debt levels in certain bid processes that were below our return on purchased debt target rate.
Other services: Operating revenue from other services decreased by e11 million, or 36.5%, from e29 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e19 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. The decrease was mainly driven by divestments of certain non-core activities and smaller businesses. Excluding the effect of these divestments, our revenue from other services grew, due primarily to continued growth from the launch of new products in the European markets, such as Invoice and Webinvoice, and increased demand for local products in certain jurisdictions, such as loan administration in Norway.

105

Gross Contribution
An analysis of our Gross Contribution by segment is set forth below:
Debt collection: Our Gross Contribution for debt collection increased by e9 million, or 7.6%, from e119 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e128 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. The increase was driven by the increase of the number of third-party portfolios serviced, including as a result of our acquisition in December 2012 of Solveon Incasso B.V, offset by slower growth in the Nordic region. Our Gross Contribution margin for debt collection remained stable at 40.9%.
Debt purchase: Our Gross Contribution for debt purchase increased by e12 million, or 12.1%, from e97 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e109 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. The increase was driven primarily by increased collection on our portfolios and a full year of collections being carried out on the significant portfolios purchased throughout 2012, offset by the timing of purchases during the year, with a number of portfolios purchased during the year closing in the fourth quarter, thus generating only limited revenue in 2013. Our Gross Contribution margin for debt purchase increased slightly from 54.2% in the year ended December 31, 2012 to 54.5% in the year ended December 31, 2013.
Other services: Our Gross Contribution for other services increased by e1.9 million, or 122.1%, from e1.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e3.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. The increase was driven by the decreased operating expenses attributable to certain divested non-core activities and smaller businesses.

106

Total Operating Revenue
An analysis of our revenue by segment is set forth below:
Debt collection: The operating revenue of our debt collection segment increased by e34 million, or 13.2%, from e257 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e291 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was mainly driven by the increase of the number of third-party portfolios serviced by our debt collection teams. The increase was offset by decline in revenue in the Nordic region where increasing our debt collection market share and thus revenue is challenging due to our market leading position.
Debt purchase: The operating revenue of our debt purchase segment increased by e33.9 million, or 23.3%, from e145.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e179.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was mainly driven by the purchase of a major portfolio from one of the largest financial institutions in Germany, which was the largest NPL portfolio we have ever purchased and was, we believe, at the time of the purchase the largest purchase of an unsecured NPL portfolio carried out in Europe in the ten years preceding the purchase.
Other services: Operating revenue from other services decreased by e21.2 million, or 41.8%, from e50.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e29.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. The decrease was mainly driven by divestments of certain non-core activities and smaller businesses, including the effect of gain from the sale of subsidiaries, which increased operating revenue by e15 million in the year ended December 31, 2011. Excluding the effect of these divestments, our revenue from other services grew, due primarily to continued growth from the launch of new products in the European markets, such as Invoice and Webinvoice, and increased demand for local products in certain jurisdictions, such as loan administration in Norway.
Gross Contribution
An analysis of our Gross Contribution by segment is set forth below:
Debt collection: Our Gross Contribution for debt collection increased by e18 million, or 17.8%, from e101 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e119 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was driven by the increase of the number of third-party portfolios serviced by our debt collection teams. Our Gross Contribution margin for debt collection increased from 39.3% in the year ended December 31, 2011 to 40.9% in the year ended December 31, 2012.
Debt purchase: Our Gross Contribution for debt purchase increased by e4.3 million, or 4.7%, from e92.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e96.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was driven by the purchase of a major portfolio from one of the largest financial institutions in Germany. Our Gross Contribution ratio for debt purchase decreased from 63.6% in the year ended December 31, 2011 to 54.0% in the year ended December 31, 2012.
Other services: Our Gross Contribution for other services decreased by e14.5 million, or 90.4%, from e16.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e1.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was mainly driven by divestments of certain non-core activities and smaller businesses.
Liquidity and Capital Resources
Our liquidity requirements consist mainly of debt and tax servicing requirements and funding of our purchases of portfolios, capital expenditure and working capital. Historically, our principal sources of liquidity have been our net cash generated from operating activities (before portfolio purchases) and borrowings under our Existing Credit Facilities, which will be repaid in full on or prior to the Completion Date, and the Subordinated Loans, which will either be repaid in full (in the case of the Existing Vendor Loan) or become an inter-company loan (in the case of the Mezzanine Facility) on or prior to the Completion Date. Going forward, our principal sources of liquidity will be our net cash generated from operating activities (before portfolio purchases) and borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility. We intend to draw e50 million under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Completion Date to finance part of the Acquisition.
While our collections have historically been predictable throughout the year, our debt purchase activity can vary greatly from one quarter to the next. This is driven by the timing of one-off debt sales by vendors during the year, the timing of which we do not control, along with our own desire to purchase a portfolio
107

at a given point in time. This could lead to volatility in our cash balances quarter on quarter. For example, we made a major portfolio purchase in the first quarter of 2012. This resulted in our portfolio purchases amounting to e142 million in the first quarter, compared with e26 million, e19 million and e47.8 million, respectively, for the three subsequent quarters.
Our ability to generate cash from our operations depends on our future operating performance, which is in turn dependent, to some extent, on general economic, financial, competitive, market, regulatory and other factors, many of which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in the section titled ``Risk Factors.''

Working Capital
It is our assessment that the available working capital is sufficient to meet our requirements for a period of twelve months from the date of this Offering Memorandum.

Net cash generated from operating activities
Our net cash generated from operating activities increased by e2 million from net cash generated from operating activities of e90 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e92 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. The increase in net cash generated from operating activities was due primarily to changes in working capital due to the timing of payments on accounts payable and accounts receivable, offset by the payment of a e13 million settlement reached with the Norwegian tax authorities related to the interpretation of historic tax deductions of interest on internal group loans.
Our net cash generated from operating activities increased by e36 million from net cash generated from operating activities of e186 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e222 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. This increase was primarily due to an increase in results from operating activities, which increased from e117 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e130 million in the year ended December 31, 2013, driven by increased collections. In addition, our cash generated from operating activities increased in 2013 due to net changes in working capital of e3 million and interest paid, which decreased from e51 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e42 million in the year ended December 31, 2013, driven by lower interest paid on our credit facility.
Our net cash generated from operating activities was e89 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 compared to e186 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. This increase in net cash generated from operating activities was primarily due to increased portfolio activity as a result of our purchase of a major portfolio from one of the largest financial institutions in Germany in 2012, which was the largest NPL portfolio we have purchased. The increase in net cash generated from operating activities was offset by decrease of other current liabilities, which decreased by e47 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 and decreased by only e3 million in the year ended December 31, 2012.
Net cash used in investing activities
Our net cash used in investing activities increased by e64 million from net cash used in investing activities of e99 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e163 million in the six months ended

108

June 30, 2014. The increase in our net cash used in investing activities was due primarily to an increase in portfolio investment of e48 million, or 50%, from e95 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e143 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014
Our net cash used in investing activities decreased by e13 million from net cash used in investing activities of e237 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e224 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. The decrease in our net cash used in investing activities was due primarily to a decrease in cash spent on acquisition of financial assets of e45 million, or 21.2%, from e212 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e167 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. The decrease was driven by a reduction in portfolio purchases in 2013, as 2012 included the purchase of a major portfolio from one of the largest financial institutions in Germany. The decrease in net cash used in investing activities was offset by an increase in 2013 in cash spent on acquisition of intangible fixed assets, driven by the acquisition of a Collection Platform in Spain, for which the purchase price exceeding the book value of the assets was allocated as an intangible asset.
Our net cash used in investing activities increased by e118 million from net cash used in investing activities of e119 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e237 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase in our net cash used in investing activities was primarily related to an increase in cash spent on acquisition of financial assets of e98 million, or 86.0%, from e114 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 to e212 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase was driven by increased portfolio purchases, as 2012 included the purchase of a major portfolio from one of the largest financial institutions in Germany, which was the largest NPL portfolio we have purchased.
Net cash from/(used in) financing activities
Our net cash from financing activities was e3 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 compared to e78 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014. The increase in net cash from financing activities was primarily due to financing of portfolio purchases.
Our net cash from financing activities was e65 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to e1 million in the year ended December 31, 2013. The decrease in net cash from financing activities was primarily related to a decrease in long-term liabilities, driven by a reduction in portfolio purchases, as drawdowns under our credit facility are recorded as long-term liabilities and 2012 included the purchase of a major portfolio from one of the largest financial institutions in Germany, which was the largest NPL portfolio we have purchased.
Our net cash used in financing activities was e14 million in the year ended December 31, 2011 compared to net cash from financing activities of e65 million in the year ended December 31, 2012. The increase in net cash from financing activities was primarily due to financing of portfolio purchases.
Capital Expenditure
Our capital expenditure (excluding portfolio acquisitions and carve-outs) consists mainly of: (i) IT hardware; (ii) IT software and development; and (iii) Collection Platforms, for which the part of the purchase price that exceeds the book value of the acquired assets is booked as an acquisition of an intangible fixed asset. Our capital expenditure increased by e10.2 million, from e5.1 million in the six months ended June 30, 2013 to e20 million in the six months ended June 30, 2014, due primarily to capitalized costs related to new functionality in collections systems, enhancing our ID platform and investment in new premises.
Our capital expenditure increased by e47 million, from e12 million in the year ended December 31, 2012 to e59 million in the year ended December 31, 2013, due primarily to the acquisition of a Collection Platform in Spain. Our capital expenditure in the year ended December 31, 2012 remained stable at e10 to e11 million compared to the year ended December 31, 2011.
Certain Indebtedness After Giving Effect to the Offering
On an adjusted basis after giving effect to the issuance of the Notes and the application of proceeds of the Offering as described in ``Use of Proceeds,'' as of June 30, 2014, our total financial indebtedness would have been e1,452.5 million. In addition, on or before the Issue Date, we will enter into the Revolving Credit Facility in the amount of e225 million. To the extent additional sources are required on closing of the Acquisition, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may utilize the Revolving Credit Facility (up to
109

an amount of e50 million) and/or additional equity. We will be highly leveraged upon completion of the issuance of the Notes and application of the proceeds of the Offering.
For a description of the material terms of our existing long-term financing arrangements and our anticipated long-term financing arrangements, see ``Description of Other Indebtedness,'' ``Description of the Senior Secured Notes'' and ``Description of the Senior Notes.''

Other Financial Obligations: Pension Obligations
For a description of certain pension plans and obligations, see ``Note 27'' to our audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2013 included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Off Balance Sheet Arrangements
We purchase portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables by way of forward flow agreements whereby we purchase non-performing debt based upon contracts that require us to make multiple purchases from a vendor at a fixed price. We typically enter into forward flow agreements with financial institutions. We invested e54 million, e44 million and e35 million, respectively, in forward flow in the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011 to forward flow arrangements. See ``Risk Factors--Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry--Failure to renew existing debt collection contracts, win new debt collection contracts, replace terminated forward flow agreements or successfully manage our commitments under forward flow agreements may adversely affect our revenue'' and ``Our Business-- Operations and Service Offerings--Debt Purchasing--Debt Purchase Commercial Process.''
We are not party to any other off-balance sheet arrangements that have, or are reasonably likely to have, a current or future material effect on our financial condition, changes in financial condition, revenue or expenses, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditure or capital resources.

Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
See ``Note 4'' to our audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2013 included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum for additional information on our exposure to market risk and the risk of loss that may result from the potential change in exchange rates, interest levels, refinancing and credit risks.

Market Risk
Market and Regulatory Environment
The main market risk is related to general macroeconomic conditions and local rules and statutory regulations in each of the geographical markets in which we operate and which, in turn, affect the

110

debtors' ability to pay and our clients' ability and willingness to sell portfolios of loans and receivables and potential commission from third party collection.

Foreign Exchange Risk
We operate internationally and are exposed to foreign exchange risk arising from various currency exposures, primarily with respect to Norwegian kroner and Swedish kronor compared to our reporting currency euro. Foreign exchange risk arises from future commercial transactions, recognized assets and liabilities and net investments in foreign operations. Our strategy is to manage and limit currency risk. Exchange rate risk can be divided into transaction exposure and translation exposure. We have investments in foreign operations, whose net assets are exposed to foreign currency translation risk. Currency exposure arising from the net assets of our foreign operations is managed primarily through borrowings denominated in the relevant foreign currencies.

Transaction Exposure: In each country, revenue and operating expenses are mainly denominated in local currencies, and thus currency fluctuations have only a limited impact on our operating earnings in local currency. National operations rarely have receivables and liabilities in foreign currency. Revenue and expenses in national currency are thus hedged in a natural way, which limits transaction exposure. The currency exposure that arises within the operating activities is limited to the extent it pertains to international collection operations. The subsidiaries' projected cash flow exposure is not hedged at present. At our group level financing, both the debt collection and the debt purchase operations are funded in the relevant currencies reflecting the underlying expected cash flow.

Translation Exposure: We operate in 11 countries. The results and financial position of our subsidiaries are reported in the relevant foreign currencies and later translated into euro for inclusion in our consolidated financial statements. 51% of our revenue was generated in foreign currency for the year ended December 31, 2013. Consequently, fluctuations in euro exchange rates against these currencies affect our revenue and earnings, as well as equity and other items in our financial statements. Our revenue is distributed by currency as follows:

Euro . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . If these currencies would have weakened/strengthened by 10% on average against the euro, with all other variable held constant, net revenue would have increased/decreased by approximately e23 million.
Liquidity Risk
Liquidity risk is the risk that we do not have the ability to fulfil our short and long-term payment obligations to outside parties. Our long-term financing risk is minimized through long-term financing in the form of committed lines of credit. The Existing Credit Facilities will be repaid in full on or prior to the Completion Date. We will enter into the Revolving Credit Facility in the amount of e225 million, of which we may draw up to e50 million to finance the closing of the Acquisition.
The Revolving Credit Facility is carried partly in foreign currency to hedge against translation exposure in relation to net assets in countries with other currencies than euro, which is our reporting currency. The Revolving Credit Facility has a number of operational covenants and one financial covenant, including a limit on net drawn super senior debt divided by the operating result after depreciation and amortization. If the limits are exceeded, amounts outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility may fall due. We

111

carefully monitor the key financial indicators, so that we can quickly take measures if there is a risk to exceed the covenant. Cash flow forecasting is performed in our operating entities and aggregated by Group Treasury. Group Treasury monitors rolling forecasts of our liquidity requirements to ensure we have sufficient cash to meet operation needs, while maintaining sufficient headroom on our undrawn committed borrowing facilities at all times so that we do not breach borrowing limits or covenants (where applicable) on any of our borrowing facilities. Such forecasting takes into consideration our debt financial plans, covenant compliance, compliance with internal balance sheet ratio targets and, if applicable external regulatory or legal requirement. Surplus cash held by our operating entities over and above balance required for working capital management is transferred to the Group Treasury (cash-pool). Group Treasury invests surplus cash in interest bearing current accounts.
Interest Rate Risk We are exposed to interest rate risks due to our need to finance our operations. Fluctuations in market interest rates may have a negative or a positive impact on our financial results by indirectly influencing the repayment of loans and investments. Following the Transactions, our indebtedness and other debt arrangements will be primarily comprised of the Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility. The Floating Rate Notes and drawings under our Revolving Credit Facility will expose us to interest rate risks relating to fluctuations in EURIBOR, NIBOR, STIBOR and other reference rates. Our Euro Fixed Rate Notes and Senior Notes bear interest at a fixed rate. For fixed rate debt, interest rate changes affect the fair market value of such debt, but do not impact earnings or cash flow. We evaluate our exposure to changes in interest rates on a regular basis and may decide to manage the foregoing risks through financial derivatives. Notwithstanding our potential use of hedging instruments, unexpected changes in interest rates could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Credit risk Credit risk is the risk that our counterparties are unable to fulfil their obligations to us. Each local entity is responsible for managing and analyzing the credit risk for each of their new clients before standard payment and delivery terms and conditions are offered. Credit risk arises from assets, such as cash and cash equivalents, guarantees and derivative financial instruments and deposits with banks and financial institutions, as well as outstanding receivables, purchased loans and receivables and outlays on behalf of clients. For financial assets owned by us, very limited collateral or other credit reinforcements have been received. Therefore, the maximum credit exposure for each class of financial assets corresponds to the carrying amount. There is also a limited risk of loss linked to our debt collection services, however, this risk is primarily carried by our clients. To minimize the risks related to purchase of portfolios, caution is exercised in purchase decisions. Purchases are usually made from clients with whom the Group has maintained long-term relationships and therefore has a thorough understanding of the receivables in question. Purchased loans and receivables are usually purchased at prices significantly below the nominal value of the receivables, and are not collateralized. We retain the entire amount we collect, including interest and fees. For more information on our purchased portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables, see ``--Purchased Portfolios of Debt and Other Overdue Receivables.''
Significant Accounting Policies See ``Note 2'' to our audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2013 included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.
112

INDUSTRY OVERVIEW Certain information set forth in this section has been derived from external sources, including industry publications and surveys, industry reports prepared by consultants, internal surveys, third-party reports commissioned by us and customer feedback. Industry publications, surveys and forecasts generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed. While we believe that these industry publications, surveys and forecasts are reliable, we have not independently verified them and cannot guarantee their accuracy or completeness. Certain information in this section has also been based on internal management analysis and in some cases combined with the aforementioned external sources. See ``Presentation of Industry and Market Data.'' The market projections and other forward-looking statements in this section are not guarantees of future performance and actual events and circumstances could differ materially from current expectations. Numerous factors could cause or contribute to such differences. See ``Risk Factors'' and ``ForwardLooking Statements.''
Introduction Debt is created when a debt originator extends credit to a person, who in turn becomes a debtor. Such arrangements occur routinely and include financial institutions extending loans or trade sector companies (including, inter alia, telecommunications and utilities companies) issuing invoices for services rendered. When a debtor does not repay the debt according to the terms on which it was extended, the debt becomes overdue. Overdue debt is a structural component of the credit industry, as debt originators typically expect a certain percentage of debtors to default, and price credit accordingly. Overdue debt is either collected by the originator itself or by a CMS provider, such as Lindorff. Unless otherwise indicated, information in this section is based on our analysis of multiple sources, including the Company Market Study we commissioned from the Market Consultancy Firm. See ``Market Data.'' Unless otherwise stated, references in this section to ``NPL'' and ``NPLs'' refer to unsecured consumer loans that have been in default for at least 90 days.
Market segments Credit management services include purchasing and performing collection services on debt. Debt is largely originated by either the financial institutions sector or by the trade sector. In 2013, the financial institutions sector accounted for approximately e3.5 to e4.1 billion in revenue for European CMS companies, which represent approximately 6-8% average annual growth over the last 5 years and the NPL stock amounted to e98 billion. We define the European CMS market to include companies operating in Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden (which collectively are referred to herein as the ``Nordics''), France, Portugal, the United Kingdom, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Russia, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain. The debt originated by financial institutions primarily consists of bank loans and typically includes mortgages, credit card loans, car loans, overdrafts and consumer loans. When such loans become more than 90 days overdue, they are categorized as NPLs. We view the CMS market for debt originated by the financial institutions sector as highly sophisticated and with high barriers to entry. Overdue debt in the trade sector mainly consists of overdue consumer bills from corporations. A number of industries are included in the sector, such as telecommunication companies, public sector, retail stores and utility companies. Compared to the financial institutions sector, debt portfolios originating from the trade sector that are serviced or purchased by CMS companies typically consist of a larger volume of debt claims with a lower average value.
113

Overview of the European Credit Management Services Industry Overview of Credit Management Services There are a number of stages in the debt lifecycle and CMS companies offer several services to clients throughout the cycle. A number of credit management services are illustrated in the following figure and described in the text below.
Illustration of a Typical Debt Lifecycle and Credit Management Services

Invoice Services

Debt Collection Debt Purchase

The CMS industry can be divided into the following three sub-segments:

Surveillance Debt Purchase
12AUG201407150307

Credit information services and invoicing services
Before debt originators extend credit to debtors, CMS companies provide credit scoring and other forms of credit information services such as data extraction and modelling. CMS companies also provide payment processing services including invoice administration, subsidiary ledger accounting, invoice printing, payment reminders and invoice purchasing. These services are provided before debt is overdue. For more information on these services, see ``Our Business--Operations and Service Offerings--Information and Invoicing Services.''

Debt Collection
CMS companies provide debt collection services to debt originators for overdue debt. The debt collection process consists of three phases: pre-legal, legal and surveillance. The pre-legal phase is the first stage in debt recovery and is where the collector seeks to find a voluntary solution with the debtor, e.g., through a payment plan. If it is unlikely that the debtor will pay voluntarily even if he or she could afford to pay and/or was aware if the claim, the case is moved to the legal phase where the court system is used to find a solution, e.g., through garnishment of wages or sale of collateral. If the debtor is insolvent and the claim is uncollectable the case moves to the surveillance phase. During this phase debtors are monitored for any changes in personal circumstances, e.g., employment status, that may allow debtors to commence payment. For more information on how we collect debt, see ``Our Business--Operations and Service Offerings--Debt Collection.''

Debt purchase
Debt originators will often sell overdue debt to CMS companies. Selling overdue debt helps debt originators increase their liquidity, strengthen their balance sheets, release resources to focus on earlystage delinquencies and reduce operational risks, reporting requirements and regulatory demands. The decision to sell overdue debt can occur at one of several stages throughout the debt collection cycle, depending on the type of debt, pricing and time since default. Typically, debt is sold after more than one year in default and following the performance of various non-legal and legal measures. As discussed below, the volume of debt sold by European debt originators has grown significantly in recent years. For more information on how we purchase debt, see ``Our Business--Operations and Service Offerings-- Debt Purchasing.''

Key Drivers of the CMS Industry
According to the Company Market Study, the volume of unsecured consumer NPLs in Europe has grown from approximately e51 billion in 2008 to e98 billion in 2013, a growth of 92.1%. Revenue generated from the European CMS market have increased from e5.9 billion during the year ended

114

December 31, 2008 to e7.8 billion during the year ended December 31, 2013, a growth of 32.2%. According to the Company Market Study, we believe that the financial institutions sector will grow by approximately 8-10% per year from 2013 to 2018 and the trade sector will grow by approximately 3-5% per year during the same period. We expect that the strong growth in the CMS industry will continue in the near term as positive macroeconomic developments improve debt collection rates and debt collection outsourcing continues to increase due to an increased focus by clients on their core businesses. Unless otherwise stated, references in this section, ``--Key Drivers of the CMS Industry'', to ``NPL'' and ``NPLs'' refer to unsecured consumer loans that have been in default for at least 90 days and references to ``Europe'' or ``European'' refer to Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden, France, Portugal, the United Kingdom, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Russia, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain.
We have identified four main market trends that we believe are particularly important to the further development of the CMS industry, and in particular the financial institutions sector.
· Banks' large build-up of NPLs in recent years;
· High sales volumes of NPLs as banks are under pressure to delever;
· Clear industry value proposition resulting in increased volume of outsourcing; and
· Macroeconomic recovery typically improving collection rates.
Banks' large build-up of NPLs in recent years
According to the Company Market Study, the main driver of growth for companies in the CMS industry over the next five years, in particular for companies with large exposure to financial institutions, is the current build-up of NPLs for European banks. The stock of total European bank NPLs has grown over the last five years from e459 billion in 2008 to e951 billion in 2013, corresponding to a CAGR of 16%. NPLs within our focus area (unsecured consumer loans) accounted for approximately e98 billion out of the total and have grown at the same rate as the overall market. The trend of increasing default rates over the last five years is also visible when looking at corporate bankruptcies and private payment remarks, which we measure as part of our European Credit Outlook Report, and which have increased in Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, and the Netherlands over the last five years whereas Germany has seen decreasing corporate bankruptcies but an increase in consumer payment remarks.
The graphic below shows the growth in the volume of NPLs and the ratio of NPLs as the share of total loans in Europe from 2008 to 2013.

High sales volumes of NPLs as banks are under pressure to delever
Annual bank NPL sales increased from approximately e1-2 billion for 2008-2010 to approximately e9 billion in 2012 before slightly decreasing to approximately e7 billion in 2013. There are a number of underlying factors for the increase in NPL sales volumes. In addition to the back-log of NPLs on banks' balance sheets, stricter regulations and increased provisioning levels have incentivized banks to delever

115

and clean up their balance sheets and sell NPLs. Selling NPLs often provides banks with immediate benefits to liquidity and to the profit and loss statements as the overdue debt sold has been substantially written down or written off.
The European Banking Association and European Central Bank asset quality review and stress tests scheduled for 2014 are further potential catalysts for NPL sales as they will further incentivize banks to delever and clean up their balance sheets. Given the above factors the company expects debt sales volumes to remain at similar levels as in 2012 and 2013 for the next five years.
The graphic below shows the growth in unsecured consumer debt sales in Europe from 2008 to 2013.

Clear industry value proposition resulting in increased volume of outsourcing
In the financial institutions sector we estimate that outsourcing levels for debt collection have grown from approximately 19% to 24% over the last five years in Europe. We have seen a trend of banks turning away from non-core activities and being unwilling to spend resources on internal debt collection capabilities. At the same time, mature CMS providers have emerged and add value to banks through their proven track record and scale. Debt collection requires a substantial amount of resources and know-how, and we believe this is performed most efficiently by specialists. Consequently, CMS providers have become an integral part of the credit industry and are frequently viewed as trusted partners to their clients. We believe this relationship will continue to grow over the coming years, especially in markets with lower outsourcing levels such as Germany, Spain and Italy.
The graphic below shows the increase in debt collection outsourcing levels since 2008. We believe significant upside for revenue growth exists as debt collection outsourcing levels continue to increase.
