116

Macroeconomic recovery improving collection rates
In 2014 we believe, as stated in our European Credit Outlook Report, that European growth will continue to be subdued and that corporate bankruptcies and consumer payment defaults will continue to increase. However, over the next five years the macroeconomic situation in Europe is expected to improve, which will lead to a decline in unemployment and an increase in disposable income. We believe that an improved ability of debtors to repay their debts is beneficial for CMS companies as it enables debtors to increase repayments and to have new payment plans arranged for debtors who were previously unable to pay their debts. This is also likely to lower default rates on loans moving forward, which would have a negative impact on the growth of the stock of overdue debt. However, this effect may be mitigated by an increase in the underlying credit stock, driven by higher private consumption and continued low interest rates, in turn driving the amounts of consumer credits. Overall, we believe that the net effect of the macroeconomic recovery will be positive for the CMS industry.
Competitive landscape
The European CMS industry is a fragmented market consisting of several thousand companies with varied profiles. When viewing the competitive landscape, three factors should be considered:
· Product offering: Companies either offer a full-service business model and operate in all stages of the CMS value chain or they focus on particular areas, such as debt collection or debt purchase.
· Geographic presence: Smaller participants tend to only operate in local markets. Medium and large companies typically have broader geographical footprints while only a few firms, including Lindorff, have operations across several European countries.
· Scale: The majority of firms (encompassing 80% of revenue generated by the European CMS industry) are small or mid-sized (under e100 million revenue and with a limited geographic presence) with limited scale, skills, experience and information. In contrast, larger firms have the necessary scale to provide a full-service offering.
Based on these considerations, the industry can be grouped into three categories of participants:
Large international companies
There are only a few large CMS companies in Europe, of which we are one. These companies typically have operations in several countries and a broad service offering, typically including both debt collection and debt purchasing. The large companies have experienced strong growth and high profitability in recent years by capitalizing on scale in skills, experience, information and origination sources.
The large European CMS companies generally have different focuses and service offerings. We believe our full-service offering in combination with our focus on the financial institutions sector is very attractive to potential clients and will enable us to capture anticipated growth opportunities across a variety of markets in the future.
Local CMS providers
Most European CMS providers are small or medium sized companies active only in local markets, and have varying scale and business focus. This comprises companies such as Lowell and Wescot in the UK and GFKL in Germany. While the above referenced companies have a large presence in their domestic markets, they have a limited or non-existing international presence. This segment also consists of several thousand participants without sizable operations who tend to focus on debt collection, as it has lower scale requirements.
Portfolio investors
The third group of participants in the CMS industry comprises international investors specializing in acquisitions of portfolios with distressed assets, such as Cerberus Capital Management, Lone Star Funds and Fortress Investment Group. The core competency of portfolio investors is the evaluation of portfolios and the raising of capital. Portfolio investors compete with other CMS companies in the debt purchasing segment; however they can also be strategic partners since they typically outsource debt collection. In recent years, we have also acted as a co-investor together with portfolio investors to acquire portfolios and have handled the debt collection process relating to the portfolios acquired.
117

Lindorff's place in the industry
We believe that we have a unique market position and business model with a focus on financial institutions clients and with a full service offering and a balanced business mix between third party debt collection and purchased debt. The large international competitors, EOS and Intrum Justitia, are more focused on third party debt collection and the trade sector. Smaller competitors such as Cabot, Arrow, Hoist and Lowell are mainly active in debt purchasing with varying focus on either the trade or financial institutions sector in only one or few jurisdictions. We believe that our full service offering offers tangible benefits to our clients, provides diversification and allows us to extract operational and financial synergies between debt collection and debt purchasing.
Structural Considerations: High barriers to entry
We believe that the European CMS industry has significant barriers to entry, in particular within the Financial Institutions sector, due to a number of structural factors:
· Client relationships: Debt originators, in particular financial institutions, are highly sophisticated and sensitive to reputational risk and are hence unwilling to switch CMS providers, in particular to a new entrant that does not yet have an established track record and reputation.
· Scale advantages: CMS is a scalable business with clear operational, strategic and financial scale benefits that provide a competitive advantage.
· Data and pricing capabilities: A large database built over many years combined with strong data enhancement capabilities are critical both for pricing portfolios and for developing collection strategies.
Overview of Selected European Markets
The markets that we operate in are different in terms of overdue debt volumes, levels of outsourcing, portfolio sale volumes and regulatory and legal frameworks. For more information on the regulatory and legal frameworks in the countries that we operate in, see ``Regulation.''
The volume of overdue debt sold depends on a variety of factors, including macroeconomic factors, NPL rates, the size of economy, the regulation as well as the attitude and position of financial institutions in each market.
Debt collection outsourcing levels also vary between countries and depend on the maturity and sophistication of local markets. Mature markets, such as the Nordics, tend to have higher debt collection outsourcing levels because companies typically see debt collection as a non-core activity and want to streamline their organizations. As such, financial institutions will sometimes seek to sell their Collection Platform together with NPL portfolios. Outsourcing levels are increasing in most countries in Europe and the proportion of outsourcing in Europe has increased from below 20% in 2008 to approximately 20-25% in 2013, and we believe that the trend of increased outsourcing will continue.
Nordics
We believe, based on the Company Market Study, that the stock of NPLs originated by financial institutions in the Nordic countries has more than tripled since 2008 and amounted to approximately e5 billion at the end of 2013. We believe that this was caused by increased unemployment rates and the economic decline after the financial crisis. Over the last five years we have experienced an increase in bankruptcies and consumer payment remarks. We expect this trend to continue through 2014, however in Sweden and Denmark corporate bankruptcies are expected to decrease. In recent years, the Nordic countries have had higher real GDP growth than average European levels according to the IMF World Economic Outlook. The trend is expected to continue in the coming five years according to the IMF. Furthermore, the IMF expects unemployment rates in the Nordic countries to decrease slightly until 2018. Although it is believed that this will improve credit default rates, the stock of overdue debt in the Nordic countries is expected to remain consistent due to increasing volumes of credit extended as the economy grows and consumer confidence improves.
The debt collection industry in the Nordic countries matured following the financial crisis in the 1990s, when companies such as Lindorff and Intrum Justitia grew their businesses and supported clients in their deleveraging of large, overdue debt portfolios. We estimate, based on the Company Market Study, that outsourcing levels for debt collection services have been approximately 60% in the Nordic countries
118

in recent years, which are substantially higher than in the rest of Europe. According to the Company Market Study, outsourcing levels by financial institutions are expected to increase slightly in the next five years. We believe that annual debt portfolio sales have more than doubled in the Nordic countries since 2011 and will remain stable in the coming years. The increase in debt sales is mainly driven by the build-up of overdue debt and the increased use of forward flow contracts. For more information on forward flow contracts see ``Our Business--Operations and Service Offerings--Debt Purchasing--Debt Purchase Commercial Process.''
Germany
According to the Company Market Study, the stock of overdue debt in Germany is one of the largest in Europe, experiencing a moderate growth rate in recent years due to a stable economy and improving unemployment rates. From 2008-2013, Germany's average real GDP growth was 0.7% according to the IMF and the unemployment rate decreased during the same period. From 2012-2018, according to the IMF, Germany is expected to have real GDP growth of 1.2% on average and stable unemployment rates. Over the last 10 years we have seen a steady decrease in corporate bankruptcies and an increase in consumer payment remarks. This trend is expected to continue in 2014, however we also expect corporate bankruptcies to increase. We believe that stable economic growth and low interest rates will drive an increase in loan volumes, however this will be mitigated through decreasing default rates supported by expectations of continued low unemployment rates. As such, we expect the stock of overdue debt in Germany to be stable in the years to come. We estimate, based on the Company Market Study that the stock of NPLs originated by German financial institutions amounted to approximately e11 billion at the end of 2013.
The German CMS industry matured from 2003-2007 after an economic downturn in the early 2000s when banks sold and outsourced the collection of a large amount of overdue debt. While lower than in the Nordic countries, we estimate German debt collection outsourcing levels to currently be approximately 25% having increased from approximately 20% in 2008 and we expect it to continue to grow. According to the Company Market Study, outsourcing levels by financial institutions are expected to continue increasing in Germany in the next five years following the increase that has occurred in the last five years.
Debt sales in Germany have been characterized by large, forward flow transactions with many participants in the sales processes. Activity decreased during the financial crisis from 2008-2010, increased from 2011-2013 and is expected to continue to grow, driven by a second wave of transactions of NPLs originated by financial institutions. The main drivers of this wave are a decreasing bid-ask price gap of buyers and sellers, the focus of banks on dealing with regulatory pressures and a focus on achieving better cost efficiency.
Spain
Spain's stock of overdue debt has increased rapidly in recent years following an economic double dip recession, a significant fall in real estate prices and increasing unemployment rates. According to the IMF, Spain's unemployment rate increased from 8.3% in 2007 to 26.9% in 2013, while GDP growth was negative throughout the same period. Although Spain is recovering, we still expect to see an increase in late payments, defaults and corporate bankruptcies in 2014. However, over the next five years, Spain is expected to have positive real GDP growth average of 0.7% and unemployment rates declining from 26.9% to 24.9%. According to the Company Market Study, we estimate that the stock of NPLs originated by Spanish financial institutions amounted to approximately e6 billion at the end of 2013 and we expect the stock of NPLs to be stable going forward.
In recent years, there has been a significant increase in Spain's debt collection outsourcing following several large sales of Collection Platforms by large Spanish financial institutions. We estimate, based on the Company Market Study, that debt collection outsourcing levels in Spain has increased from approximately 15% in 2008 to 45% in 2013 and we believe that trend towards outsourcing will continue. According to the Company Market Study, outsourcing levels by financial institutions are expected to continue increasing in Spain in the next five years following the increase that has occurred in the last five years.
In the last three years, Spain has been the most active market in Europe for debt sale transactions, driven by the large NPL volume and financial institutions being subject to stricter regulations. Although large volumes of debt portfolios have been sold in recent years, we expect Spain to continue to provide
119

attractive debt purchase opportunities due to a stable inflow of overdue debt. In addition, an increasing secondary market is expected in 2-4 years as several investors who acquired overdue debt from 2011-2013 are expected to sell their acquired portfolios. The Netherlands In the Netherlands, the stock of overdue debt increased significantly following the financial crisis, driven mainly by negative real GDP growth and increasing unemployment rates. From 2008 to 2013, the Netherlands' average real GDP growth was 0.8% according to the IMF. The unemployment rate increased from 3.1% to 7.1% during the same period. We expect this trend to continue in 2014, although we expect corporate bankruptcies to fall. We estimate that the stock of NPLs originated by Dutch financial institutions amounted to approximately e2 billion at the end of 2013 and we expect the stock to decline slightly over the next five years as GDP growth picks up and unemployment rates decrease. We estimate that debt collection outsourcing levels in the financial institutions sector has increased from approximately 10% in 2008 to approximately 20% in 2013. According to the Company Market Study, outsourcing levels by financial institutions are expected to continue increasing in the Netherlands in the next five years following the increase that has occurred in the last five years. Historically, the market for NPL sales in the Netherlands has been characterized by a few transactions from the large banks and by small banks not having NPL portfolios large enough to use a debt sale as a strategy. We, however, expect NPL portfolio sales to increase in the coming years.
120

OUR BUSINESS
We are a leading pan-European credit management services (``CMS'') provider, focusing on overdue unsecured consumer debt, and have a market leading position in the financial institutions sector. We provide debt collection services to, and acquire portfolios of overdue debt and other overdue receivables from, our clients, who include financial institutions, telecommunications companies, utilities providers, public sector and retail stores. For the year ended December 31, 2013, we had revenue of e447 million and EBITDA of e141 million.
We are active along the entire CMS value chain, performing the functions as illustrated in the graphic below:
External Offering / 3rd Party Services

Information Services

Invoice/ Web Invoice

Debt Collection

Legal

Surveillance and Recovery

Debt Purchasing

Lindorff Acting as Principal

12AUG201407150171

· Debt Collection: We engineer and implement tailored debt collection strategies and solutions to maximize cash flow streams from overdue debt and other overdue receivables for clients who have decided to outsource their debt collection function. We service NPLs for financial institutions clients, including credit card loans, car loans, overdrafts, consumer loans, business loans and mortgages, as well as insurance and factoring claims. We also collect overdue bills for clients, including telecommunications providers, utilities, public sector and retail stores. As of June 30, 2014, we provided debt collection services in 11 countries and managed overdue debt and other overdue receivables with an aggregate face value of e14.5 billion. For the year ended December 31, 2013 and the twelve months ended June 30, 2014, we generated external revenue of e228 million and e224 million, respectively, from debt collection, excluding revenue generated from portfolios that we own

· Debt Purchasing: We purchase portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables from our clients, which we then typically service using our in-house debt collection function. As of December 31, 2013, 87% of the face value of the overdue receivables portfolios we own across our geographic markets consisted of NPLs originated by financial institutions, with the remaining 13% representing overdue receivables purchased from clients in other industries. From January 1, 2011 to December 31, 2013, we invested e506 million to purchase portfolios of debt and other overdue receivables, including each delivery under forward flow agreements, with an aggregate face value of e6.0 billion. For the year ended December 31, 2013 and the twelve months ended June 30, 2014, we generated revenue of e200 million and e204 million, respectively, from debt purchasing.

· Other Services: In addition, we provide our clients with a wide range of services before debt and receivables are overdue, including customer and credit information and analysis, data extraction and modelling, selection and scoring of potential customers, invoicing and web invoicing, reminder services, factoring solutions and turn-key solutions for web shops. For the year ended December 31, 2013 and the twelve months ended June 30, 2014, we generated revenue of e19 million and e18 million, respectively, from other services.

We have built a flexible and balanced business by performing both debt collection and debt purchasing, which we believe allows us to maximize revenue by offering solutions to clients along the entire CMS value chain. As a result of our business model, we believe that we are able to efficiently allocate resources to the opportunities that we find most attractive. Additionally, we believe that our comprehensive databases, which consist of data gathered through our collections, experience and pan-European presence allow us to accurately price portfolios that we purchase and to design effective and efficient debt collection strategies for individual debtors.

121

From our origins in Norway, we have expanded our geographic footprint to serve clients in key markets across Europe, with local operations in Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Spain, the Netherlands, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Russia. By employing dedicated country managers and debt collection teams in each of these jurisdictions, we are able to closely follow local market dynamics and develop strong long-term relationships with our clients.
We have a track record of consistent revenue growth and for achieving growth in Adjusted EBITDA that has exceeded revenue growth. During the three years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, our revenue, increased from e386 million (excluding gain on sale of a subsidiary of e15 million) to e447 million representing a CAGR of 8%, while our Adjusted EBITDA increased from e200 million (excluding gain on sale of a subsidiary of e15 million) in 2011 to e256 million in 2013 representing a CAGR of 13%. We generate high, stable and predictable long-term cash flows from our purchased debt portfolios. We focus on purchasing portfolios from financial institutions, which represented 87% of our portfolios for the year ended December 31, 2013, as these portfolios typically have longer and more stable cash flows than other types of portfolios. We acquire these portfolios at a discount to face value and we expect to collect multiples of the price paid. During the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, the price we paid for portfolios averaged 8% of face value. As of June 30 , 2014 our existing portfolios had an ERC of e1.9 billion, which is 2.5 times the carrying value of e760 million. Our portfolios typically generate stable, long-term cash flows. The long-term nature, and the low decay rates, of our portfolios are illustrated in the chart below, which shows our ERC distribution by year.

We have a track record of extending the cash flow duration on our portfolios and maintaining low decay rates so that we can continue to collect beyond the initial 15-year period, resulting in total collections significantly above our initial estimates. This is evidenced by the evolution of our old portfolios. For portfolios purchased in 2005 and before, we now expect total collections to be 3.2 times the purchase

122

price compared to our initial business case expectations of 2.6 times the purchase price. We are also observing this evolution on our more recent vintages, and for our portfolios purchased in 2010 we have already raised our expected total collections to 2.6 times the purchase price, compared to 2.5 times the purchase price under the initial business case.
There is potential to increase collections by further improving our collection rates from our ongoing optimization of surveillance portfolios. We currently have e19 billion face value of debt under surveillance, generating approximately e400 million in annual collections. The collection rates on these portfolios vary by geography and they are lower in markets where we have less developed operations, such as Spain and Germany. Bringing the collection rates in these markets up to the same level as Norway, Sweden and Finland would have a meaningful impact on the yield of our portfolios.
Our Strengths
We believe our business benefits from a number of strengths, including:

Balanced and diversified business model with full service offering
· A balanced business model. Our operations span 11 countries, where we provide our clients with services along the entire CMS value chain and our largest customer represented 5.3% of revenue in 2013. For the year ended December 31, 2013, our debt collection business and debt purchasing business generated 51% and 45% of Group Revenue, respectively.

· Unique ``one-stop shop'' with significant benefits for clients. When selecting us as a CMS provider, our clients have access to a flexible range of solutions along the entire CMS value chain, including credit information and invoicing services, debt collection and debt purchasing.
· Business model resilient to economic cycles. We believe that our business model, covering debt collection and debt purchasing, increases our strategic flexibility across the economic cycle. We are able to efficiently allocate resources to the opportunities that we find most attractive, for example, focusing on third-party debt collection during competitive pricing cycles and on debt purchasing when attractive opportunities are abundant.
· A source of operational synergies. We believe there are significant operational synergies among our business segments. First, debt collection serves as an origination source for debt purchasing. Second, an efficient debt collection service maximizes the return on purchased debt on portfolios that we purchase. Third, debt purchasing increases the size of our database. Finally, our credit information services are enhanced as our databases increase in size.
Strong and long term market growth outlook
· Positive underlying market trends. We have identified four main market trends that we believe are particularly important to the further development of the CMS industry, and in particular the financial institutions segment:
· banks' large build-up of NPLs in recent years;

123

· high sales volumes of NPLs as banks are under pressure to delever;
· clear industry value proposition resulting in increased volume of outsourcing; and
· macroeconomic recovery typically improving collection rates.
· Strong market growth momentum. According to the Company Market Study, the volume of unsecured consumer NPLs in Europe has grown from approximately e51 billion in 2008 to e98 billion in 2013. During the same period, sales of unsecured consumer debt in Europe originated by financial institutions increased from e1.3 billion to e7.1 billion. As a consequence and according to the same study, we believe that revenues will grow approximately 8-10% in the financial institutions sector and 3-5% in the trade sector from 2013 to 2018.

Europe's leading CMS provider for financial institutions
· Financial institutions is the most attractive business segment. Based on our experience financial institution assets typically have higher cash-on-cash multiples, longer duration and more stable cashflows.
· Europe's leading specialist in the financial institutions sector. Our core strategy is to serve the financial institutions sector, in which we hold a market leading position. We believe that we have a unique business model as we are currently the only large pan-European full service provider focused on the financial institutions sector.
· Preferred partner for European banks. Our market leading position was established through long-standing relationships with major Nordic financial institutions. Historically, we have entered new markets through a combination of organic growth, portfolio purchases and acquisitions of banks' Collection Platforms. As a result, we now believe that we are the CMS provider of choice to our financial institutions clients.
· Our clients recognize our strong reputation for ethical and fair treatment of debtors. We believe that compliance and fair treatment of debtors are at the forefront of our financial institutions clients' priorities when selling portfolios. In recent auctions, our reputation for ethical and fair treatment of debtors has played an important part in securing additional contracts from financial institutions.
· Strong organizational focus on ethical and fair treatment of debtors. We do our utmost to minimize reputational risk, and in order to do so we have developed robust practices and procedures to ensure the fair and ethical treatment of debtors. Our debt collectors go through rigorous screening and assessments before interacting with debtors, and receive formal training on how to manage the debt collection process in a fair manner.

Strong pricing discipline and an established pricing advantage over our competitors
· Established pricing advantage and discipline. Based on our significant experience, extensive database and long track record, we believe that we have a clear pricing advantage compared to most of our competitors. Our policy is to maintain strict pricing discipline through an institutionalized investment process in order to maintain high portfolio returns and avoid overbidding for portfolios. We take a centralized approach to pricing, coupled with appropriate local input in each specific case, which we believe provides strong cross-organizational pricing discipline.

124

· Extensive databases and sophisticated data analysis tools provide high forecasting accuracy. Our comprehensive databases of purchased debt, including 8.5 million individual claims as at June 30, 2014, and our sophisticated data analysis capabilities serve as integral parts in the process of pricing portfolios ahead of acquisitions and allow us to establish more efficient debt collection strategies. Additionally, we have depersonalized details in our databases on approximately 19 million claims and recent contact information for debtors we have worked with in the past.
· Track record of achieving collections against original investment projections. From January 1, 2011 to June 30, 2014, we collected 106% of our original investment projections. Our disciplined portfolio acquisition process, robust database and forecast model underpin this result.

Strong cash flow generation embedded in our business model
· Long-term client relationships. Our debt collection business generates consistent cash flows at limited investment requirements, underpinned by long-term client relationships. As of June 30, 2014, we manage debt under 20,600 service contracts with an average duration of 3 years. In the Nordic region, some of our largest contributors to revenue and longest dated relationships go back to the 1980's. Outside of the Nordic region, we have entered into long-term servicing agreements, including with Santander in Spain and ABN AMRO in the Netherlands. We tend to experience strong client loyalty and limited attrition through protective contractual terms (e.g., break fees) and systems integration between Lindorff and clients, which can make it operationally and financially unattractive to switch CMS provider.
· Significant cash flows embedded in purchased debt portfolios. As of June 30, 2014, we expect to collect e1.9 billion of cash over the next 15 years from our existing backbook of purchased debt portfolios, with e310 million expected in the next year. Financial services assets account for 87% of our ERC and have a higher average balance and longer weighted average life than our retail and telecommunications assets, generating long-term annuity like payments. Portfolio assets are typically repaid through repayment plans set up with customers, with average monthly payments of e136.

· Track record of extending payments beyond 15 years. This is driven by continuous improvement of collection strategies and data analysis. As an example, we have collected 5.3x the purchase price

125

for our 2000 vintage and still expect to collect e6.3 million, which is 0.6x the purchase price, over the next 15 years, resulting in a total expected multiple of 5.8x. For pre-2006 vintages, we estimated at the time of portfolio acquisition that we would be able to collect 2.6x times the aggregate purchase price. As of June 30, 2014, we have collected 2.5x times the aggregate purchase price of the pre-2006 vintages, and as of that date expected to collect 3.2x times the aggregate purchase price over the life of the portfolios purchased prior to 2006.
· Efficient conversion of profit into cash flow. From 2011 to 2013, 91-95% of Adjusted EBITDA was converted into operating cash flow (before income tax expense and net financial items), resulting in aggregate operating cash flow (before income tax expense and net financial items) over this period of e650 million. Total debt purchases over this period totaled e506 million.
Experienced executive management team with strong support from operational and market specialists
· Strong leadership of experienced senior management. We are managed by a strong executive team comprising individuals with many years of relevant experience and providing leadership across all functional areas of the business. Endre Rangnes, our CEO, held various managerial roles at IBM in Europe and was the Country Manager of Norway from 2000 to 2003. Between 2003 and 2010 Endre was the CEO of EDB Business Partner, a publicly listed information technology company. Our CFO, Scott Danielsen, is a Certified Public Accountant (inactive) and was formerly CFO of publicly listed European debt purchaser, Aktiv Kapital, after spending 21 years at Ernst & Young and PricewaterhouseCoopers.
· Supported by a strong team in our group central functions and local markets. Our senior management team is supported by a skilled team of managers operating our central functions and assisting in the execution of our strategy at group level. In addition, our expert regional and country managers are responsible for the local execution of our strategy in the various countries where we operate. Our regional and country managers have significant experience and knowledge of the specificities of our local markets.
Our Strategy
We believe that we have a well-developed strategy for pursuing growth within our existing regions and through geographical expansion. Our strategy includes:
Building on our strong relationships with originators
Over the coming years, we expect significant opportunities in the CMS market. We will strive to maintain our leading market position by establishing new bank partnerships, acquiring new portfolios and by entering into service agreements with new clients.
We believe that we are in a strong position to successfully enter into new partnerships, conclude future acquisitions of portfolios and collection platforms and maintain and expand our existing client relationships, in particular with financial institutions, due to our strong reputation for ethical, fair and efficient debt collection as well as our track record of successful acquisitions. In addition to our strategy of capturing market growth opportunities, we plan to continue to emphasize our high level of underwriting discipline in order to maintain forecast accuracy and to ensure that we only acquire portfolios that generate attractive returns.
Continuing to drive operational scale and excellence across countries to capture full value potential
To maintain our market position and extract further value from our large and scalable platform, we are continuously looking for improvements across the organization to strengthen our client offering and operate more efficiently. We have developed and introduced a ``Global Operating Model'' to set one common operational blueprint and consolidate our general IT infrastructure platform across countries. We will focus on further optimizing our cost structure by continuing to streamline our operating platform, centralizing internal procedures and functions and by improving our IT efficiency through the consolidation of our collection systems. These efficiency improvements strengthen our client offering by extracting further value from portfolios and optimizing cash flows over time. We believe there are still
126

meaningful variations in performance across geographies and we intend to increase portfolio yields and profit margins in the future through the full realization of multinational synergies.
Maintaining a disciplined portfolio acquisition process
Our strict pricing discipline and institutionalized investment process has allowed us to collect 106% of our original investment case cash flow forecasts from January 1, 2011 to June 30, 2014. We plan to continue to emphasize our high level of underwriting discipline in order to maintain forecast accuracy and to ensure that we only acquire portfolios that generate attractive returns. We will continue to build and leverage our extensive databases and sophisticated data analysis tools in the processes of pricing portfolios ahead of acquisitions, and to establish more efficient debt collection strategies.
Selectively considering expansion into selected new geographies
We have a strong track record of selective expansion into new markets and we have established operations in 11 countries. This expansion has been driven by a combination of strategic acquisitions and our ability to leverage strong client relationships. We believe that our strong relationships with international clients will lead to attractive opportunities to enter new markets by following our clients to other markets in which they operate as we have done in the past. We also foresee the potential for attractive portfolio acquisitions and carve-out opportunities for debt collection platforms and may enter selected European countries in the coming years, including Italy in 2014.
Certain statements in the section titled ``--Our Strategy'' constitute forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future financial performance and our actual results could differ materially from those expressed or implied by these forward looking statements as a result of many factors, including but not limited to those described under ``Forward-Looking Statements'' and ``Risk Factors.'' Investors are urged not to place undue reliance on any of the statements set forth above.
History
We were founded in 1898 in Norway by Eynar Lindorff. From our origins in Norway, we have grown to become a leading pan-European provider of CMS. In 2003, Altor 2003 Fund acquired Lindorff Holding AS from Gjensidige NOR, and in a concurrent transaction acquired Contant Oy, a Finnish debt collection company, from Sponsor Capital and Nordea, which subsequently were merged to create Lindorff Group AB, the largest CMS company in the Nordic region at the time. Until 2008, the Lindorff Group was owned by Altor 2003 Fund together with certain other shareholders and management persons at that time. In 2008, the Altor Funds and Investor invested in the Group, whereby Lindorff AB became the parent company of the Lindorff Group, with the Altor Funds and Investor as the sole shareholders (and the shareholding divided evenly between the Altor Funds and Investor). Our owners have maintained their strong commitment to the Company since that time. As a result of subsequent investments in the Company, Investor currently holds 50% of the votes and approximately 51.22% of the shares and the Altor Funds altogether currently hold 50% of the votes and approximately 48.78% of the shares of Lindorff.
We solely operated in Norway until 1998 and through 2005 we expanded in the Nordic and Baltic countries. Since 2005, we have experienced significant European expansion. For the year ended December 31, 2011, 84.7% of our revenue was from Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Finland (including our operations in Eastern Europe) compared to 67.1% of our revenue coming from those countries for the year ended December 31, 2013. From 2010-2013 we focused on increasing the scale of our European presence. Our geographic expansion has recently been fuelled both organically and by a number of acquisitions.
In March 2012, we purchased a Collection Platform from a major European financial institution and concurrently entered into a debt collection contract with that same financial institution. In that same month, we also separately announced a e130 million investment in portfolios held by a separate major European financial institution. Additionally, in January 2011 and December 2012, we acquired debt collection companies from two different major European financial institutions. We believe that these recent transactions have helped to solidify existing long-term relationships with major European institutions who are already clients and to build relationships with other major European institutions. We intend to continue to selectively pursue potential acquisitions to expand our geographic footprint.
127

Operations and Service Offerings
We have a full-service offering throughout the CMS value chain, consisting of information and invoicing services, debt collection and debt purchasing. We believe that these offerings enable us to offer various solutions to our clients depending on their specific needs. For example, some clients do not have the scale to efficiently or effectively perform certain functions in-house, so we are able to offer them a full suite of services both before and after debt or receivables become overdue. Further, other clients have significant incentives to outsource their debt collection or sell their portfolios of overdue debt and other overdue receivables, due to changes in regulatory regimes and an increasing focus on their core businesses. We believe that our full-service offering enables clients to view us as a valuable partner in their business.
The table below sets forth our revenue and other income by segment for the periods under review.

Information and Invoicing Services
We offer our clients a wide range of information and invoicing services before debt is considered non-performing. We believe these services help to establish relationships with clients at the beginning of the CMS value chain and enhance our ability to win debt collection contracts or to purchase related debt once it becomes non-performing from these clients.
Information Services
Information services include credit information and analysis, data extraction and modelling and scorecard input and development. We believe that our information services enable our clients to mitigate credit risk and reduce potential losses from sales to new clients by providing efficient and reliable information on the creditworthiness of their customers.
Invoicing Services
Invoicing services include invoicing and web invoicing, reminder services, factoring solutions and turn-key solutions for web-shops. We believe that our invoicing services provide reliable and cost efficient solutions for clients with high invoicing volumes and helps clients to increase sales by enabling credit sales without credit risk or need for a credit process.
Debt Collection
Overview
We primarily focus on working with debtors to collect overdue debt and other overdue receivables for our clients in selected European markets and specialize in engineering and implementing tailored collection strategies and sustainable, affordable solutions for the resolution of claims. We provide debt collection for clients on 4.6 million active cases with an aggregate face value of e14.4 billion. Our highly trained staff works directly to collect debt where we have local operations, and works closely with a trusted network of debt collection partners elsewhere around the world to collect debt when debtors move abroad to a country where we do not have local operations.
We believe that our clients benefit from outsourcing their debt collection to us as we create value for them by lowering the cost of collection and increasing recovery rates. We are able to lower collection

128

costs due to our large scale and automation of the debt collection process, and we are able to increase recovery rates by combining a thorough understanding of each local market where we operate and using our comprehensive databases and experience to optimally tailor debt collection strategies. Additionally, our clients are able to focus on their core business by outsourcing debt collection to us as opposed to performing this function internally.
Our client-centric focus is also evident in our approach to fee arrangements. Generally, during the initial, pre-legal, legal and enforcement phases of debt collection, we typically work on a ``no cure no pay'' basis at fixed rates. During the surveillance phase, we typically work on a commission basis, taking a percentage of the cash collected from the debtor. Additionally, we also offer a profit-sharing model, where we charge commissions on collections received up to a certain threshold and, in addition, the client shares with us a percentage of collections received over that agreed threshold. We believe that the benefits of our effective claims collection strategy are evident through our many long-standing client relationships, which has resulted in a ``partnership model'' with many clients where we are seen as a trusted, important and strategic business partner.
Debt Collection Process
Optimizing debtor contact at each stage of the collection life cycle is the key to our debt collection strategy. Our debt collection process is standardized and automated, with the goal of maximizing the total amount collected over the life of the debt through sustainable payment plans or affordable settlements achieved through an amicable and solution-oriented collection approach rather than exploiting short-term collection potential. The process consists of the following key phases: the initial phase, the pre-legal, legal and enforcement phase and the surveillance phase.
The debt collection process we undertake is the same whether we engage in debt collection for external clients or for portfolios that we own. Nevertheless, when we perform debt collection on behalf of our clients, we operate within the guidelines that they set regarding settlements as well as specific procedures to utilize. In contrast, we have the flexibility to set our own guidelines and to decide when to settle a claim and what procedures are utilized when we perform debt collection on portfolios we own. Actions taken during the debt collection process are designed to take into account applicable country specific laws and regulations, and to preserve our clients' reputations.
Initial Phase
In the initial stage of the debt collection process, we segment or score debtors according to the predicted likelihood that they will pay, based on criteria such as past payment history, size and type of debt, debtors' age and gender and whether the debt was incurred by a consumer or a business. We are able to segment debtors in this fashion using information on debtors from our internal database, supplemented by external credit bureau and other information. We believe that this process has the potential to increase the amount of revenue that we generate.
We send each debtor a letter stating that we have purchased his/her claim from the debt originator or have been instructed by our clients to collect the claim on their behalf. We typically allow the debtor approximately two weeks to pay the principal amount outstanding on the claim and offer them a variety of contact options, including telephone, email or online debtor portal options. If we determine that it is probable or highly probable that a debtor will pay, we engage in the pre-legal phase of collecting on the claim. If we determine that it is uncertain that a debtor will pay, we will assess which measures are to be taken on a case-by-case basis and taking into account the debtor's affordability and ability to pay.
Pre-legal Phase
The pre-legal phase typically lasts 30-60 days, during which time we seek to agree to a voluntary payment plan or settlement with the debtor. Our goal during the pre-legal phase is to maximize the amount of resolved claims while minimizing costs. Any repayment arrangements with debtors are structured in accordance with specific internal policy guidelines and client contract requirements, if applicable, and are designed to be sustainable and affordable for the debtor. To enhance efficiency during the debt collection process, we leverage information in our comprehensive databases in order to tailor an optimal collection strategy for each individual debtor. We have the ability to view data from a claim level, such as what collection methods have been more successful in the past for claims with certain characteristics, and on a debtor level, such as what collection methods have been more successful in the past for debtors with various employment statuses, indebtedness levels and average incomes.
129

Collection methods in the pre-legal phase include calls, letters, text messages, emails and to some extent personal visits by agents. Ultimately, the combination of collection methods that we use for a specific client depends on various factors, including the geographical market, the claim size, the client we are acting on behalf of, the applicable laws and regulations and the individual debtor.
Legal and Enforcement Phase
A claim moves into the legal phase, which typically takes between 60-180 days, if we determine that the debtor is unlikely to voluntarily pay or if we have been unable to agree to a solution with the debtor in the pre-legal phase. While we aim to resolve claims by working with debtors without relying on legal enforcement, we will direct a debtor directly to this phase if we believe that this is the optimal strategy. The legal phase may involve turning to the court system to find a solution to the debtor's debt. Some examples of solutions we seek in the legal phase include garnishment of wages, sale of collateral, bankruptcy proceedings and debt restructuring.
Upon successfully resolving a claim in the legal phase, we then typically utilize bailiffs to enforce claims under e15,000. Bailiffs typically work on fixed-fee arrangements and have the legal authority to enforce claims on our behalf. Bailiffs assist with seizure of property, garnishment of wages and other court ordered solutions. If a claim is valued above e15,000, then we typically rely on the court system to enforce the claim.
Surveillance Phase
The surveillance phase typically commences for a third-party collection client when a claim is written off due to the debtor being insolvent and the claim is deemed presently uncollectable. We believe that collections on this large pool of claims can be improved over time both due to improvements in the debt collection process as well as positive macroeconomic developments, such as decreasing unemployment. Claims can be deemed presently uncollectable in various circumstances, including when claims have undergone pre-legal and legal collection strategies for at least one year without being able to collect the total amount due or if collateral attached to the claim has been enforced. Third-party collection claims are typically 2-3 years old when they are transferred to surveillance.
During this phase, we place claims in one of 12 ``buckets'' where we utilize different activities, such as campaigns or channels, in order to optimize collection profitability. We also monitor changes in circumstances of the individual debtor in order to determine whether there is an enhanced ability to begin payment. When it appears through surveillance that a debtor has an enhanced ability to begin payment, we then look to both pre-legal and legal means to collect on the claim. We ensure that we perform any country specific requisite actions during the surveillance phase to ensure that claims are not barred by statutes in order to protect our ability to collect on a claim if a debtor later becomes solvent.
Standardization of the debt collection process
We believe that the standardization and automation of key aspects of the debt collection process increases the efficiency of our operations by reducing the need for manual case handling. In order to make our debt collection service more efficient and to ensure optimal debtor contact, we have integrated several automated processes into our debt collection process. These processes include:
· Courses: a sequence of predefined actions to occur according to a set schedule. Courses determine when our agents should call a debtor, automatically send out a letter, text message or contact the debtor in another fashion.
· Campaigns: the implementation of common processes for a group of claims. Campaigns will typically begin around a time when we expect debtors to have an enhanced ability to pay.
· Event engines: software driven processes that prescribe a series of actions to be taken in connection with 65 different external events such as debtor bankruptcy, death or address modification. For example, these actions could include periodic telephone calls, text messages and other methods typically utilized in the pre-legal collection process.
Additionally, we believe that the standardization of the debt collection process is crucial to implementing best practices across our local operations.
130

Our ethical approach to the debt collection process
Our debt collection process is designed to yield financial results while protecting our clients' reputations. We believe in:
· polite persistence, where collectors take a fair and reasonable stance when interacting with debtors;
· ensuring a fair outcome for the debtor, taking into account sustainability and affordability of payments; and
· treating debtors with respect and dignity.
We are dependent upon relationships characterized by trust with clients, authorities and society at large. In order to achieve the necessary level of trust, we must act with professionalism, expertise and high ethical standards at all levels. Our internal standards, the Lindorff Business Practice Principles, are applicable to all employees and all employees are expected to become acquainted with and comply with these standards. These standards mandate that all employees are expected to always work within the law, have sound moral principles and behave in an upright and sincere way. We have implemented a robust and centrally coordinated compliance monitoring program, which evaluates and assesses compliance with legal, regulatory and industry best practices, as well as our stringent internal standards. For more information on compliance, see ``--Compliance and Quality Control.''
Debt Purchasing
Overview
We have extensive experience in acquiring portfolios of overdue debt and other overdue receivables, providing clients with an up-front payment for non-core assets at an attractive price level. Among the investment criteria that we currently consider when deciding whether to purchase a portfolio is whether a portfolio fits our focus on unsecured consumer NPLs, the portfolio's expected return on purchased debt and a number of other factors. We generate revenue after purchasing portfolios by seeking to extract stable long-term returns by agreeing to one-off payments, together with sustainable payment plans over the lifetime of the debt. We believe that we can generate attractive yields over a longer period of time than our competitors, sometimes in excess of 15 years, due to our expertise in pricing unsecured consumer NPLs, knowledge of the portfolios we purchase and our debt collection abilities.
We believe that one of our core strengths, in comparison to companies that only purchase debt portfolios, is that we typically service the portfolios we purchase in-house. By typically servicing the portfolios we purchase in-house, we control the entire debt collection process and we are able to implement optimal debt collection strategies. Additionally, by controlling the entire debt collection process we believe that we can ensure that debtors are treated fairly and with respect. We believe that the efficient, fair and respectful manner in which we conduct our business upon purchasing a portfolio is evident through our many long-standing client relationships.
As of December 31, 2013, we owned portfolios of overdue debt and other overdue receivables, consisting of approximately 4.0 million active claims in 11 countries with a gross outstanding principal of approximately e13 billion. For the year ended December 31, 2013, 2.4 million payments were made to us by debtors, with an average payment of e131.
Debt Purchase Commercial Process
There are two principal models for purchasing portfolios, one-off agreements and forward flow agreements. In a one-off agreement, we agree to buy a portfolio of claims that we receive in one transaction upon payment. In a forward flow agreement, we agree to buy claims at a pre-defined price or price range for a given volume from a client on an ongoing basis. We allocated e53.4 million, e44.6 million and e34.5 million of the amount spent on portfolio purchases in the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011 to forward flow arrangements. We currently have 12 forward flow agreements with an annual capital expenditure over e1 million per agreement, with an average contractual duration of ten months. We believe that forward flow agreements are beneficial to us as they provide us with certainty of a minimum volume of claims that we can perform debt collection on. Similarly, these agreements are beneficial to the seller as they provide a certain level of predictability of the volume of claims being sold.
131

We have the capability and experience to buy large portfolios, which typically require an initial investment of more than e10,000,000. For example, we purchased a portfolio of NPLs from a major financial institution for over e100 million in March 2012. However, the majority of our portfolio purchases are of smaller portfolios, which typically require an initial investment between e500,000 and e10,000,000. These smaller portfolios, when combined with forward flow agreements, account for approximately 60% of our annual portfolio purchases and provide us with a consistent base of claims to generate revenue from.
The majority of portfolios for sale are currently offered to the market through competitive tender processes. In certain circumstances we will co-invest with other debt purchasers to purchase a portfolio. Co-investment is beneficial as it provides us with a large portfolio to perform debt collection through master servicing agreements and allows us to purchase unsecured, consumer NPLs even if they are bundled in a portfolio with other claims that are outside our area of focus. We acquired approximately 16%, 7% and 0% of the face value of portfolios that we purchased in the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011 via co-investment arrangements.
During the debt purchase process, we involve a fully integrated team, which, depending on the size of the transaction, includes a combination of country level management, our group-level debt purchasing and debt collection teams, and senior executive management. We believe that close and early cooperation between our debt collection and debt purchasing teams during this process maximizes cross functional synergies. Our typical portfolio acquisition involves an origination process, a valuation and due diligence process, an offer phase and a contract and closing phase. The acquisition process follows a template, which ensures consistency across our operations.
Origination
Our local sales teams maintain close relationships with key debt originators in countries where we have local operations. In addition, our senior management maintains close relationships on a cross-border level with our major key debt originators and is actively involved in our largest transactions with these sellers. From these relationships we are often invited to partake in competitive tender processes for portfolios and receive requests for proposals (``RFPs'') in relation to the portfolios for sale. A key driver of our success in debt purchasing, which we believe differentiates us from our competitors, has been our ability to leverage our relationships with clients for whom we collect debt through outsourcing contracts. While the majority of portfolio purchases take place through the RFP process, we also engage our clients in discussions to purchase portfolios through bilateral negotiations whenever opportunities arise.
Valuation and Due Diligence
We engage in an extensive valuation of the portfolio in order to determine what price we should offer the client. First, we look at certain characteristics, including the age of the claims in the portfolio, the size of the portfolio, the type of receivable the portfolio contains and the collection process already undertaken in order to determine whether the portfolio for sale is suitable for us. Once we have determined that a portfolio for sale is suitable to us, we collaborate with our debt collection team and engage in an extensive valuation of the portfolio. Our holistic use of multiple valuation methods takes into account, among other factors, the below analyses:
· vintage analysis where we use historical cash flow information to forecast future returns;
· production models where we analyze the portfolio and make assumptions on conversion rates and average payment levels based on our internal experience;
· scorecards using all available data (both internal, external and client data) to evaluate the propensity of each debtor in the portfolio to pay and what amount;
· debt profiles where we identify the key value drivers in the portfolio and segment the portfolio based on these key value drivers and evaluate the total likely recovery for each claim; and
· paying books, where we identify different payment profiles and segment accounts based on historic payment behavior.
The emphasis we put on each valuation method depends on the specific circumstances, information available and characteristics of the portfolio for sale. We believe that we have the flexibility, experience and data analysis capabilities to choose the appropriate method or combination of methods to appropriately and accurately value a portfolio.
132

In conjunction with the valuation process, we also perform due diligence on the portfolio prior to making a final bid. The purpose of this due diligence process is to identify any areas of risk that would impact our ability to successfully manage the portfolio if we purchase it. As part of the due diligence process, we request and work to verify certain data fields including claim balances, payment history on claims, details of credit agreements and legal enforceability. Additionally, we undertake a detailed review of the assumptions that we apply as part of the valuation process and determine whether those assumptions need to be adjusted. For certain transactions, we also engage external advisors for this process. We seek to leverage our relationships with clients to assist us with this process by obtaining guidance on pricing where possible.
We believe that our model of integrating the debt collection process into the process of purchasing portfolios is critical to our success in valuing portfolios. We believe that we have a competitive advantage when we are invited to bid on a portfolio that we perform debt collection on because we are able to accurately assess the potential uplift that can be generated due to being familiar with the debt collection measures that have been undertaken, allowing us to accurately price the portfolio. This results in being able to confidently offer an attractive value proposition to clients, which makes us a strong contender for portfolios that we find attractive.
Offer
Depending on the size of the transaction, the assessment and final pricing of a portfolio involves input from country-level management and operations, our debt purchasing and debt collection teams, our IT team and senior executives. This group works together to use the information gathered in the process to prepare the final bid, and the relevant country level team uses its knowledge and expertise to provide a current and accurate reflection on the competitive environment in order to ensure that any final bid is aligned with the competing offers the client is likely to receive. The final bid is determined based on an analysis of various scenarios, which are designed to test our models at the high and low ends of prior experience, and is evaluated and signed off on by pre-defined levels of management depending on the size of the bid before being submitted to the client. The final price that we offer for a portfolio takes into account the return that we require in order to compensate for the risk present in the transaction, the possibility that actual performance of the portfolio may deviate from the expected performance and the level of competition that we face in the market. We have a standardized process for approving offers that we consistently follow and we believe that the involvement of various levels of management, with the levels of management involved in the offer increasing as the value of a transaction increases, in approving offers for portfolios ensures that each offer is properly reviewed and is consistent with our belief in pricing discipline.
We believe that a key driver of our success in debt purchasing is due to our ability to leverage our relationships with clients. We use these relationships to engage in a dialogue with the client in order to assist us in putting together a competitive bid. These relationships can also be used to propose alternative structures to those that were requested if we believe it will create value for us and the client. We also frequently receive a ``first and last look opportunity'' at a portfolio due to these pre-existing relationships we have with our clients.
Contract and Closing
The majority of our portfolio purchases are priced in a manner where the client receives a one-off cash payment for the portfolio. However, we also have entered into purchases using different pricing models in an effort to address specific needs or desires of our clients. One such alternative pricing model is an ``earn-out model,'' which provides for profit sharing, where the client receives an upfront cash payment for the portfolio based on an initial forecast and then receives from us a percentage of any gains above the initial forecast.
Upon being chosen as the purchaser of a portfolio, we enter into a portfolio purchase agreement (``PPA''). It is our goal to further our client relationships, and to ensure that we enter PPA negotiations mindful of the ramifications a transaction can have on long-term relationships. We pride ourselves on having a commercial mind-set and we work with clients to find solutions to any problems that arise during this part of the process. We seek to obtain customary representations and warranties and other clauses in the PPAs including representations that claims are legally enforceable, a putback clause to allow us to return any invalid claims, a minimum threshold for documentation availability and data warranties over the information used to value the portfolio.
133

Implementation
The most significant operational risk we face after purchasing a portfolio is the conversion process. If we do not already perform debt collection on the purchased portfolio, we must ensure that claim balances are accurately recorded, funds paid between the determination date and the closing date by debtors are received by us, and debtors are diverted to the appropriate phase of the collection process. We also screen individual claims against various databases to determine whether any of the individual claims do not meet the specified criteria and should be returned, if contractually permitted. If we already service the purchased portfolio, the risks associated with the conversion process are minimized, since many of these steps have already been undertaken as part of our debt collection services.
Contact and Collection Process
After acquiring a portfolio, we typically manage the portfolio in-house. Our understanding of the debt collection process enables us to tailor customized approaches for each debtor and to determine whether we can extract additional value from a debtor and uplift on a portfolio by applying different collection methods than were used previously. By typically servicing purchased portfolios in-house, we also provide stability and scale to the debt collection segment of our business, which allows us to improve and enhance our debt collection methods. For a further discussion on the debt collection process, please see ``--Debt Collection--Debt Collection Process.''
Business Intelligence
The characteristics of the debt purchase and debt collection markets provide a competitive advantage to participants with the strongest data assets and analytical capabilities. Unlike many of our competitors in the debt purchase sector, who rely on third-party debt collection agencies to service claims, we believe that directly employing, training and monitoring debt collection specialists is essential to extracting value from claims and pricing portfolios accurately. We believe that our data assets and analytical capabilities are a core strength of our business and we often find opportunities to improve performance in a large portion of the portfolios that we purchase due to analysis of our data assets.
We have developed comprehensive databases of debtor and credit information over 20 years as a result of the high volume of debt collection we perform in-house. We have depersonalized details in our databases on approximately 19 million claims and recent contact information for debtors we have worked with in the past. We analyze these databases to assist in the pricing of potential purchases of portfolios and to devise optimal collection strategies for debtors. For example, we are able to model anticipated performance of a portfolio based on the past performance of claims with similar characteristics, which allows us to determine if there are opportunities to extract additional cash flow that may not be apparent from traditional pricing models. Additionally, in devising optimal debt collection strategies, we can determine what collection methods have been most successful in the past on debtors with similar traits. We continually look to improve our data analysis processes in order to operate our business more efficiently.
We believe that our data assets and analytical capabilities enable us to view portfolios, as well as collection strategies, in a different and more proactive way than many of our competitors. Companies that only purchase portfolios typically have limited access to data on debtors and associated payment trends until a portfolio is purchased, when the specific debtors in the portfolio can be matched to a credit referencing agency database. In addition, it is often the case that debtor files in a portfolio contain inaccurate or incomplete information on the name, address or telephone number of the debtor, which can make it difficult to locate the debtor or otherwise complicate the debt collection process. As a result, many of our competitors typically experience a significant data asymmetry in valuing portfolios prior to purchase and through the collection process.
Geographic Presence
We believe that we have positioned ourselves to be an attractive candidate for multinational companies, especially financial institutions, and have a presence in 11 countries across Europe. The table below

Our underlying revenue growth in the Nordic countries has been stable. However, headline numbers show a slight decline due to the effects of discontinued operations. On an underlying basis, we have experienced stable growth in Finland and Norway, while revenue has declined in Sweden and Denmark due largely to restructuring initiatives. We expect these initiatives to return Sweden and Denmark to profitable growth with Norway and Finland continuing their stable performance. Improved operational efficiency is expected to increase the overall financial performance in the region. Our strategy is to defend our market-leading position and potentially outgrow the market through specific initiatives, such as developing our product offering and attracting new clients. These initiatives are underpinned by the market trend of increased NPL sales and forward flow agreements, which is a source for further growth.
Spain has experienced very strong growth due to several portfolio purchases and Collection Platform acquisitions coupled with outsourcing agreements. We expect significant continued growth from bank carve-outs and further NPL sales. Over the last years, we have seen a steady improvement in margins, a trend which we believe will continue as our operations grow, allowing us to extract operating leverage benefits. Furthermore, the improving macro-economic conditions could potentially be a source of additional upside. Our Dutch and German operations have also grown considerably due to acquisitions of Collection Platforms and portfolios. As these are integrated, we will increase operational efficiency and further improve profitability. In the medium term we expect to continue our expansion in purchased debt, third party outsourcing and forward flow agreements, together with the potential for further Collection Platform acquisitions in the region.
Certain statements in the section ``--Geographic Presence,'' including in particular the operational targets described immediately above, constitute forward looking statements. These forward looking statements are not guarantees of future financial performance and our actual results could differ materially from those expressed or implied by these forward looking statements as a result of many factors, including but not limited to those described under ``Forward-Looking Statements'' and ``Risk Factors.'' Investors are urged not to place undue reliance on any of the statements set forth above.
We believe that clients are able to ensure ethical, consistent and professional service across country lines by utilizing our services as opposed to contracting multiple, smaller suppliers from many different countries where there may be different market practices. Our local product offerings vary depending on several market characteristics, including the level of debt collection outsourcing, the maturity of the market, the propensity of clients to sell portfolios and the overall supply of portfolios available in the market to purchase. For example, in the Nordic market debt collection outsourcing levels are substantially higher than the rest of Europe, so debt collection is a strong driver of revenue in that region. On the contrary, Spain has been among the most active market for debt purchasing in recent years driven by financial institutions being subject to stricter regulations and internal capacity constraints. For more information on the differences in the markets that we operate in, see ``Industry Overview--Overview of Selected European Markets.''
